text: The classic facade, built over an earlier facing, was copied from a first century Roman book, Spanish edition, published in Madrid 1787.  The three statues, left, right and top represent Faith, Hope and Charity.  The fourth added in 1927 is Santa Barbara.  Of all the 21 mission this one is the most imposing and offers a large open space in front for the admiration of this structure.

Remarkable food with beach access for the whole family, flip flops acceptable.  You step up to the counter, order, get a number and bus you own food to a table inside or out.  The locals know about this place and really love it just as we did on our first visit.  Highly recommended.  Probably good enough to drive from Santa Barbara to eat here.  Local beer on tap, kids are more than welcome.

I loved everything about this lovely train station.  The staff was friendly and helpful.  The station was beautiful.  Every aspect of passing through was wonderful.  It is a great place.  Thank you Philadelphia for making our vacation special and providing such a great place.

The Praline Connection makes a mean po' boy.  The restaurant is located just outside the French Market on Frenchman St, in a lower-key, musically-influenced area of town.  I was looking forward to trying out their fried oyster po' boy, but unfortunately, the restaurant was out of oysters.  They use only Louisiana oysters and because of the oil spill in the Gulf, they cannot serve any dishes with oysters.  Boo.

I subbed in a fish (catfish, I assume) po' boy instead and it was delectable.  It had catfish, shredded lettuce, slices of tomato, mayo, and pickles, inside a loaf of French bread.  With a side of fries, it was yummy and filling.

Small note on the fries: the menus have printed the fries are only $1.50 extra when ordered with a po' boy.  However, the restaurant charged us $2.00 and the server told us there was a sign out front that noted the change.  The menus still say $1.50 though.  The restaurant needs to correct this.  How are you just going to leave incorrect pricing in your menu (50 cents isn't a lot, but it's the principle)?

We were told by our waitress to try their fried chicken next time.  The waiters and waitresses are dressed in white dress shirts and black slacks with black top hats and suspenders.  The floor is tiled in black and white tiles.  The restaurant is connected to a small praline/candy shop where you can buy fresh daily-made pralines.  The pralines are about $2 apiece.  I bought a few of the original on my way out and they were pretty good.  Super sugary for sure.

We walked over to Tennessee Brew Works, one of Nashville's popular craft breweries, after hitting up Jack White's Third Man Records shop nearby. Both businesses are located in Pie Town, a neighborhood on the southern edge of downtown Nashville. There's not a whole lot of stuff in this part of town. These are definitely two of the highlights.

Tennessee Brew Works opened on August 18, 2013. It's popular. This place has won numerous awards and earned plenty of recognition including the best brewery in Tennessee according to Yelp. These folks are all about being local, green, and sustainable. The taproom is two stories with views of the brewery from both floors. There's a patio with both covered and uncovered spaces (mostly uncovered) as well as a small, string-lit rooftop patio. As this is a brewery, the property has an industrial, warehouse feel to it, much like the other businesses in Pie Town. It's clean and modernized. The first floor of the brewery features a small stage for live music (a band was setting up on our way out) and the room upstairs, which is much more spacious, has TVs playing sports and nice overhead views of the brewery floor below.

Brewery tours take place every Saturday at 3pm, 4pm, and 5pm. It costs $10 plus tax and a fee per person. Tickets for the tour can be purchased online.

Along with high-quality craft beer, the brewery also serves food. Their limited menu includes apps/snacks like Baja fish tacos, Springer Mountain chicken wings, salads, burgers, and sandwiches (including a Nashville Hot Chicken Sandwich). Food prices range from $8 to $18 per plate.

We grabbed a few beers and hung out inside the taproom downstairs. Downstairs, they use barrels (some with tabletops) for tables with bar stools. We showed up around 2pm on a Saturday and the place was busy. It wasn't slammed or jam-packed, but most of the tables upstairs and downstairs were taken. Our group of six was lucky to find a table in a corner next to some brewery windows. The atmosphere was very relaxed and laid back. The staff was cool and friendly. We all enjoyed our time here.

I don't think Tennessee Brew Works has dedicated parking. We parked for free on the street (Middleton Street because we also went to Third Man Records). This isn't the nicest neighborhood so I wouldn't leave any valuables in your car.

Logan Circle, also known as Logan Square, is a public park located in the center of the Logan Square neighborhood (yes, same name) in Philadelphia. It's managed by the city's Parks & Rec department. This is a great sightseeing spot in Philly. I recommend it. The views are beautiful.

Some quick Q&A:

1. Why is it called Logan Circle?

Because it serves as a major traffic circle for Benjamin Franklin Parkway (https://www.yelp.com/biz/ben-franklin-parkway-philadelphia), connecting it to North 19th Street, Vine Street, and Race Street.

2. Why is it called Logan Square?

Because it was one of five squares originally planned for the city in 1864 by William Penn, founder of Pennsylvania.

3. Who is the circle/square named after?

James Logan, 14th mayor of Philadelphia.

Logan Circle is actually surrounded by three other parks: Aviator Park, Sister Cities Park, and Shakespeare Park (small). Combined, the land area for these four parks, including the roads (Benjamin Franklin Parkway is wide and scenic) is about four city blocks. So for a city park, it's not huge, but not small neither.

The highlight of Logan Circle is a large fountain in the center called the Swann Memorial Fountain: https://www.yelp.com/biz/swann-memorial-fountain-philadelphia-2. We visited on a bright and sunny Sunday afternoon and the park was filled with people, both locals and tourists. Even though there were signs that said no swimming in the fountain, I can't tell you how many kids I saw swimming and playing in the fountain. A lot. It almost looked more like a pool or water park than a historic fountain.

Logan Circle is centrally-located between Philadelphia City Hall and the Philadelphia Museum of Art (Rocky Steps: https://www.yelp.com/biz/rocky-steps-philadelphia). Benjamin Franklin Parkway connects all of it. If you've never been to Philly before and want to sight-see, I think walking the parkway between city hall and the museum is a must. Including the aforementioned adjacent parks, Logan Circle is surrounded by sights and attractions including the Franklin Institute, the Academy of Natural Sciences of Drexel University, and the Cathedral Basilica of Saints Peter and Paul.

Note: At the time of writing this review, there's another Yelp listing for Logan Circle. It's called Logan Square Park: https://www.yelp.com/biz/logan-square-park-philadelphia. Technically, the two listings should be merged, but the Yelp moderators disagree.

I had a great experience with Assurant. I purchased my old Google Pixel phone from the Google Store (online). One of the options I could add to my phone was Device Protection for $99. Device protection is the same thing as phone insurance and Assurant was the provider.

The coverage I purchased was good for two years from the date I received my phone. The maximum number of accidental damage repairs or replacements under Device Protection was two during the coverage period. My Pixel's camera lenses, both front and back, got scratched. The scratches caused light streaks in my photos and videos so I decided to file a claim and get a replacement.

Per the Device Protection welcome and terms and conditions email I got from Assurant, I filed my claim at https://mydeviceprotect.com/. It was really quick and easy to do, especially since Assurant had most of my information on file from my phone's IMEI/serial number. I filed my claim on a Friday night. In less than 24 hours, someone from Assurant called to verify my information and approve my claim. I received a claim approval email after the call and a shipping notification that Monday (first business day after my claim was approved). I received my replacement Pixel on Tuesday afternoon; basically, in two business days. Fast!

I did have to pay a $79 deductible, but it was totally worth it to me. It was like I got a brand new Pixel for only $178 ($99 for Device Protection + $79 deductible). Technically, the phone was refurbished, but it looked and worked like new - the battery too, which was huge, since my old battery was on its way out. Considering my particular phone model at the time, a 32-GB Pixel 1, originally retailed for $649, I thought this was a good deal. Plus, I had one more replacement remaining on my contract before my two years were up. It was nice to have that peace of mind.

Google made it easy to transfer all of my apps and data from my old Pixel to my new Pixel. I just connected the two phones with a USB-C cable and followed the prompts. The entire transfer took about an hour (my new Pixel had to download and install almost 100 apps). I was really pleased with how simple and seamless the transition was. My old phone was essentially mirrored to my new one which was exactly what I wanted. I did have to set up new fingerprint recognition and log in to all of my apps again, but that was it. I was back up and running with a "new" phone with hardly any interruption.

I returned my old Pixel in the same packaging that my new Pixel came in. Assurant emailed me a shipping label to print and tape to the outside of the box. I had to return my old Pixel within 14 days from the date my new Pixel was shipped. Otherwise, I could've been charged an "unrecovered equipment fee" of up to $2,000.

In the end, I am very happy with the Device Protection I purchased from Assurant. I already bought it again for my latest phone, the Pixel 3, for $129 (unsurprisingly, the insurance price went up).

The Philadelphia Phillies are one of the oldest American professional sports franchises, established in 1883. Unlike other storied teams, the Fightin' Phils have never left their original city.

It took nearly 100 years, but the Phillies were able to win their first World Series championship in 1980 and then again, 28 years later, in 2008. In 1980, future Hall-of-Famer and perhaps the greatest third baseman of all time, Mike Schmidt, led Philadelphia to a 4-2 series win over the Kansas City Royals. In 2008, four-time All-Star pitcher Cole Hamels led Philly in a dominating series performance over the Tampa Bay Rays, 4-1. (Since 2020, Hamels has played for my favorite team, the Atlanta Braves.)

The Phillies play at Citizens Bank Park, located in South Philly. The ballpark opened in 2004 and is part of the South Philadelphia Sports Complex which includes the adjacent Lincoln Financial Field (home of the NFL's Philadelphia Eagles) and Wells Fargo Center (home of the NBA's Philadelphia 76ers). You can see the complex from the interstate (I-95) as you drive into the city from the airport. It's just across the Delaware River from New Jersey.

The Phillies haven't done well since 2011, the last year they made the playoffs. From 2012 to present, they've yet to finish a single season above .500 (they finished at exactly .500 twice, in 2012 and 2019), a far cry from their 2008 championship. However, the Charlie Manuel (manager) years (2005-2013), immediately preceding the current playoff drought, comprise a great era in Philadelphia's baseball history. Under Manuel, the Phillies made the playoffs five straight seasons (including that '08 World Series title), had first baseman Ryan Howard named NL Rookie of the Year in 2005 and then NL MVP the following year in 2006, shortstop Jimmy Rollins named NL MVP in 2007, and pitcher Roy Halladay named NL Cy Young Award winner in 2010. Unfortunately, the team hasn't been the same since Manuel's firing during the 2013 season.

At the time of writing this review, the Phillies have an all-time win percentage of .472 (9,853 wins against 11,032 losses).

We stayed at the Courtyard by Marriott Philadelphia Plymouth Meeting and really enjoyed our stay. Everyone at the hotel seemed nice, especially Kim, the lady who checked us in. Kim set the tone and was really welcoming and affable. The hotel and amenities were nice considering the tier of hotel and price paid. We were part of a wedding block and were charged $119.90 per night after taxes. Not bad.

If you're not familiar with Philadelphia, this hotel is located in the suburbs northwest of town. There's plenty of free parking and the hotel is located within walking distance of a big shopping mall, Plymouth Meeting Mall, that is anchored in part by a Whole Foods. Aside from the mall, if you don't have a car, you're going to have to Lyft/Uber to get anywhere.

This Courtyard by Marriott is four stories. Our room was 335 on the 3rd floor. It was a "KSOF" (king with sofa bed) room with a view of the parking lot and office building to the north. The hotel is surrounded by several office buildings so I suspect a lot of business travelers stay here to work at those buildings.

From the outside, the hotel looks like your standard Courtyard by Marriott. Inside, it looks like some renovation work has been done. The place was clean and looked fairly modern. While there's no full-service restaurant or shop, there is a fast-casual counter where you can order made-to-order food and drinks, a small retail corner with grab-and-go items, some dining and lounge-like areas, and a business center of sorts. There's also an indoor pool, hot tub, and gym. The gym is tiny. Outside in the back is a little courtyard with nice landscaping and additional seating. It's worth exploring and checking out.

When we checked in, Kim handed us two bottles of water and two Peanut Chews, delicious candy bars that are manufactured in Pennsylvania.

Our room was clean and comfy, and contemporary in design. The toiletries, such as the shampoo, conditioner, and body wash, were Paul Mitchell Tea Tree brand. The bathroom had a standard tub and shower with a floor that was tastefully tiled. The bed was very comfortable, from the soft-yet-firm mattress to the silky-smooth and smell-good sheets. There was an artsy-looking couch (sofa bed) with a conveniently-angled end table. The office desk was extendable which was great for more surface space. The TV was a smart TV with apps like Netflix and YouTube installed. There was a coffee maker, iron and ironing board, luggage rack, and hair dryer. The Wi-Fi was free and fast enough. And there was free, self-serve, tasty coffee and fruit-flavored ice water in the lobby.

Standard check-in time is 3pm and check-out is 12pm. I used the Marriott Bonvoy app to keep track of my reservation and make an early check-in (12pm) request. The hotel (Kim) was quick to respond to my chat messages in the app and she remembered me from our chat conversation when I showed up in person to check-in. I like how they stay on top of that. Saturday night, when the lobby was used for the wedding after-party, I called in a request for additional toiletries and housekeeping was reasonably quick to respond despite the craziness going on downstairs. I appreciated that.

Overall, I think this is a very good mid-tier hotel. I recommend it.

In terms of points percentage, the Philadelphia Flyers are currently the third-most successful team of the 31 active teams in the NHL. The Flyers won back-to-back Stanley Cups in 1974 and 1975. The team's number of championships (2) is tied for 11th best in the league. Historically, the Flyers have been a perennial playoff team. All time, the team ranks in the top 10 in total playoff seasons. However, over the last decade, the Flyers have only made the playoffs on average about every other year. All things considered, Philadelphia has been home to one of the NHL's better-performing franchises.

The Flyers are among the NHL's second-oldest members. They were part of the second wave of franchises that joined during the league's 1967 expansion. That expansion saw the league size double from six teams (the Original Six) to 12 teams. Of the 1967 expansion teams, Philadelphia was the first to win the Stanley Cup. Another 1967 expansion team, the in-state rival Pittsburgh Penguins, have won the Stanley Cup five times (the most of any of the expansion teams from that year). After winning back-to-back titles in 1974 and 1975, the Flyers went on to appear in six more Stanley Cup Finals, the latest in 2010.

Four of the Flyers' six retired jersey numbers belong to players who won the Stanley Cup. They include goaltender Bernie Parent, defenseman Barry Ashbee, left-winger Bill Barber, and center Bobby Clarke. Parent is a legend among goalies and a Philadelphia sports icon. Clarke was the captain of both teams that won the Stanley Cup. Parent, Barber, and Clarke were all inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame. Ashbee was a member of the 1974 championship team, but his career was unfortunately cut short from an eye injury he suffered in the Flyers' series preceding the Stanley Cup Finals. Tragically, only about three years later, Ashbee passed away from leukemia at age 37.

The Flyers' home arena is the Wells Fargo Center. With a present seating capacity of 19,600 (the number can vary depending on where you look; 19,600 is from the Wells Fargo Center website), the Wells Fargo Center is the fourth-biggest arena in the NHL. The Flyers and the NBA's Philadelphia 76ers have been the building's only two full-time occupants since the building opened in 1996. The seating capacity for Sixers games is slightly larger at 21,000. Wells Fargo Center is part of the South Philadelphia Sports Complex which includes Lincoln Financial Field (Philadelphia Eagles; NFL) and Citizens Bank Park (Philadelphia Phillies; MLB).

#AnytimeAnywhere

I'm rating the Edmonton Oilers five stars based on their dominance from 1983 to 1990. Sadly, Edmonton has only made the playoffs twice since losing to the Carolina Hurricanes in a heartbreaking Game 7 in the 2006 Stanley Cup Finals. However, their history in the 80s cannot be denied. The Oilers won the Cup five times in seven years: 1984, 1985, 1987, 1988, and 1990. To date, the Oilers are tied with the Pittsburgh Penguins for the sixth-most number of Stanley Cup championships. The Oilers and the Penguins have the most NHL titles outside of the Original Six. A finer point, the Oilers franchise did not join the NHL until 1979 while the Penguins were part of the league's 1967 expansion. It's impressive how many championships Edmonton racked up after being a member of the NHL for only about a decade.

"The Great One" Wayne Gretzky, started his NHL career with Edmonton. He is the franchise's all-time scoring leader in both goals (583) and points (1,669). Unlike many of the great hockey players today, Gretzky was not drafted. He played in the now-defunct World Hockey Association (WHA) for Edmonton for one season before the WHA folded. After that, the Oilers joined the NHL and the rest is history. Gretzky won all four of his Stanley Cups with Edmonton. He left the team in 1988 when he was traded by the Oilers to the Los Angeles Kings. The Oilers would go on to win the following Stanley Cup without him and Gretzky would never win another Cup again.

Today, Connor McDavid is the Oilers' best player. He's currently considered one of the best players in hockey. Edmonton drafted him with the No. 1 overall pick in the 2015 NHL Entry Draft. Already, McDavid has won the Hart Memorial Trophy (NHL regular season MVP in 2017; Gretzky won the Hart Trophy nine times), the Ted Lindsay Award twice (NHL regular season most outstanding player in 2017 and 2018), and the Art Ross Trophy twice (NHL regular season most points in 2017 and 2018). He was also on the cover of EA Sports NHL 18. He's quickly climbing up in the franchise record books.

The Oilers' current home is Rogers Place, located in downtown Edmonton. Opened in 2016, Rogers Place is one of the NHL's newest arenas. It has over 1,250 TV screens and the largest HD center ice scoreboard in the league. For hockey, Rogers Place has a seating capacity of 18,347. The Edmonton Oil Kings of the Western Hockey League (WHL) have also called Rogers Place home since 2016. Both teams are owned by Daryl Katz.

If you've never been to Philadelphia Chinatown before, it's worth checking out. It's located just one block away from Philadelphia City Hall and is adjacent to the very popular Reading Terminal Market, so it's convenient to other must-see spots in the city.

By my count, Chinatown takes up about 21 city blocks. The Pennsylvania Convention Center takes up roughly a quarter of the neighborhood. Like other Chinatowns in big American cities, Philly's Chinatown is relatively old and densely-packed. Food is a big draw, of course, with restaurants serving not only Chinese food like dim sum and Peking duck, but also Japanese ramen and yakitori, Korean fried chicken, Malaysian, Thai, and Vietnamese cuisine, and vegetarian food. There are also Asian bakeries and bubble tea galore.

The official entrance to Chinatown is located on the south side of the neighborhood on N 10th St at Arch St. The gate is known as the Friendship Gate or Friendship Arch (https://www.yelp.com/biz/chinatown-friendship-gate-philadelphia). It's a vehicular gate and, ironically, traffic flows only one-way: out of Chinatown. N 10th St is also home to the Chinese Cultural & Community Center as well as the Mandarin-language campus of the Chinese Christian Church & Center (https://www.yelp.com/biz/chinese-christian-church-and-center-philadelphia-2).

I attended a wedding at the church's Vine Campus which is less than a five-minute walk away. Vine St forms Chinatown's north border with N Broad St to the west, N 7th St to the east, and Arch St to the south. The neighborhood immediately north of Chinatown, Callowhill, is referred to by many as Chinatown North. The Asian Arts Initiative, a non-profit community and arts center, is located there (https://www.yelp.com/biz/asian-arts-initiative-philadelphia).

If you want to sight-see and explore Chinatown, N 10th St at Race St is a good place to start. From there, there's a lot of stuff to see in every direction.

In addition to being close to City Hall and Reading Terminal Market, Chinatown is also only a block away from the National Constitution Center, Independence National Historical Park, and other historic spots on the east side of town.

I've reviewed a lot of things on Yelp, from bridges and tunnels (http://bit.ly/2YCOtxX) to gas stations (http://bit.ly/2GXPRAi), but never a gate. This is my first review of a gate.

The Chinatown Friendship Gate, also known as the Chinatown Friendship Arch and the China Gate, is the "official" entrance to Philadelphia's Chinatown. The gate is located on N 10th St at Arch St. It's 40 feet tall and weighs 88 tons. It's called the Friendship Gate because it symbolizes the friendship between Philly and its sister city in China, Tianjin. The gate officially "opened" (was dedicated) in January 1984 with a rededication in 2008.

This is a neat landmark and worth checking out if you've never been to Philly Chinatown before. It's ornate and colorful and makes for a nice photo/selfie. The architectural style comes from the Ming (1368 to 1644) and Qing (1644 to 1912) dynasties. I think Philly's Chinatown gate trumps San Francisco's Chinatown gate, Dragon Gate (http://bit.ly/2Yy21uu), in terms of size and decor, but SF's gate is actually three gates in one (two gates for pedestrians and one for vehicles). This gate is built over vehicular traffic only: two one-way car lanes and one one-way bike lane, all heading south out of Chinatown and into Center City.

If you're visiting Philly from out of town, I recommend going to Tea Do (http://bit.ly/2M9XSWV) one block north of the gate and Reading Terminal Market (http://bit.ly/2OOoUFG) two blocks east.

After leaving a review for this gate, I realized I never left one for the SF version (http://bit.ly/2Yy21uu). Now I have to do it.

Drago's was a bit disappointing.  The restaurant is known for their charbroiled oysters which were created by Drago Cvitanovich himself.  The oysters are prepared with garlic, parsley, butter, black pepper, and two cheeses.  I ordered a dozen of these, but only received 10.  After letting the server know, he (eventually) brought out three additional oysters.

The charbroiled oysters were hot off the grill, very buttery, and quite tasty.  However, many of the oysters were quite small (the key to good charbroiled oysters is to use big fat oysters).  At $16.95 for one dozen, it may not have been worth it.

We also tried to order raw oysters of which they had none.  Our server tried to explain to us why they did not have raw oysters and all we could surmise from his explanation was that there were not a sufficient number of oyster boats due to the BP oil spill, but he also mentioned something about a one-hour refrigeration time, so it left us a bit confused.  Oh well.  No raw oysters = bad.

Drago's serves higher-end Creole cuisine and also specializes in a variety of lobster dishes.  The restaurant is located at the ground level of the Hilton.  They do not take reservations (first-come, first-serve only).  The restaurant is popular and thus service can be slow.  Valet parking is available, but if you are staying anywhere near the French Quarter, you can walk it.

The Roosevelt is an elegant and grand old-school hotel.  As soon as you step through the revolving doors, you feel like you're in a luxurious five-star hotel from the 1930s.  Crystal chandeliers and large columns run the length of the long hallway-like lobby with beautiful mosaic tile on the floor, marbled walls and ornate ceilings, fine furniture, etc.  The elevators are tiny.  The hallways to the rooms are wide with decorated carpet and more chandeliers.  The hallways remind me of the the hallways from the hotel in the movie "The Shining."

The rooms are equipped with Samsung plasma TVs, crystal lamps, views of downtown New Orleans, TVs in the bathrooms, walk-in closets with full ironing boards, and more.  The maids are dressed in traditional black and white French maid outfits, which is a nice touch.  There is complimentary Wi-Fi Internet for Hilton Gold and Diamond members.  The Roosevelt is part of the Waldorf Astoria collection of hotels.  The hotel is tucked down a quiet street just around the corner from Bourbon St, making it a great location to stay if you're visiting town and want to be near the French Quarter.

I love this place. I found it on yelp while in reno this past weekend. This has to be one of the best little places to have breakfast.

Its located in a tiny strip mall next to a bar. There are limited indoor seats so come earlier or you might have to take your food to go.

I had the "special" which was a rendition of eggs benedict. a piece of crispy toast, topped with a nice piece of ham which was topped with 2 over easy eggs. Instead of hollandaise sauce there was a great chorizo gravy covering the eggs. It was marvelous. It was probably the best breakfast I have had in years if not ever. My bf had the el jefe which was just a breakfast burrito with chorizo, bacon, ham, eggs and fresh salsa verde. 

Both dishes were spectacular. To top it off they serve coffee, fresh baked ham and cheese scones, croissants and even have gelato. The service was great also. The young lady was very attentive, nice and made us feel comfortable even though we were obvious out of townies.

Try this place out if you're in the area. You won't be disappointed

Came back here today with some friends and once again this place is nothing but amazing. Some of my friends are picky when it comes to food but everyone thoroughly enjoyed their breakfast! I highly recommended the 5th street benedict which I got last time and it didn't fail to impress my friends. The sandwiches were amazing and this time we finally got to get some chocolate croissants and ham & cheese scones. Once again, the service was great. Super friendly and made everyone feel comfortable. I'm so glad that we got the chance to come back here for breakfast because I probably won't be back in the area till next year (at the soonest that is).. I'll definitely miss the great breakfast that they serve here..

Come to San Jose and open up a location here!! Thanks in advance haha.

What everyone else has said -- cute trendwear that's total garbage quality-wise and probably made by small Indonesian children but you get what you pay for. Large selection, lots of frothy lacy things floating around this season, and a bunch of accessories are available. I did not see the Shoe Nami store, which I wanted to because WHAT AN AWESOME NAME.

I can't afford any of it but loved trying it on.

The shopgirls were total candy babes and even sweeter than that.
This is where you can get a bottle of water and candy bar at normal convenience store prices in the quarter.

We don't actually dress like this but if you live in New Orleans and are having a California-themed party -- go for it, just don't tell me about it and I won't tell you about what we wear when we have our New Orleans-themed parties. xo.

We went at the tail end of dinner on a weeknight and didn't have to wait at all for a table. Service wasn't slow at all considering that the restaurant was full, we had drinks right away and our food came out quickly enough that we weren't sitting there with our bellies rumbling.

Our server was super chatty and we loved her. The other servers also chimed in on our conversation and that was also awesome. Anyone complaining about how the folks here spend too much time talking instead of serving is in the wrong town and has a stick up their butt and doesn't deserve to eat here.

1. The fried pickles as recommended by Tim P. and my sister: the portions, as pretty much everywhere else we went, were ridiculous. We ordered the appetizer and received a giant bowl of these delicious bites. The couple at the table next to us had ordered the fried okra [also delicious], so we traded off and still had a full take-out container left over.

2. Daughter got a side of red beans and rice [e.g. a giant flippin' platter] and a sausage. Delicious.

3. Chad and I split the mixed plate. I can't even remember anymore what-all came with this -- jambalaya, gumbo, various fried seafood, beans & rice, corn bread, something else probably -- and of course it was a giant mountain of food that was far too much for us. All incredible. Oh! the mac and cheese! I'm not even a huge mac & cheese fan. and OMG BEST EVAR.

4. I'd get just what we had again, except I would bring a couple more people and skip D's side of beans & rice because she could've had some of ours.

5. I bought some pralines, haven't even tried them yet because honestly, New Orleans left me wanting to eat nothing but raw spinach for the next couple months. Hopefully they'll hold up in my fridge for a bit.

6. Super bonus: high school kids' brass band playing in the vacant lot cater-corner.

First time eating here.  Two of us had the burgers and they were amazing.  The French fries are home made and delicious.  One person in our group had the chicken and waffles but did not like at all.  They basically give you a dry waffle with two dry chicken stops on top.  My husband had the Cubano and liked it.  Could use a dill pickle in it.  Service was good.

This steak house is amazing.  We shared a bone in ribeye and a add on small lobster tail!  The stark melted in your mouth. It was cooked to perfection!  The lobster was one of the best I have had. Sweet and delicious.  The potatoes that are pan fried with onions and gravy are quite amazing as well.  I am a baked potato person but these were better!  Ok enough about the food.....lets talk about the service.  We had Marcos as our waiter and he was point on!  Very helpful with us picking the right selection. He knew the menu well and guided us to perfection.  You won't be disappointed in eating here!  One of the best steakhouses I have ever eaten at.

I love me some Philly. 

Sure, we've got gogo dancers here in NYC. And yea, we've got bacon mac 'n' cheese. But then again, I don't know where I can eat that and watch a bare ass jiggle and keep my appetite. Love the 60's inspired throwback dancers shakin' what their mama gave 'em on the lit stage blocks here. Throw in some awesome music, fans blowing everyone's hair back and it is instant music video time. 

And then I find out that drinks are $4 and I figure that I'll have to make a pilgrimage here at least every few months. Yep.

Nestled into the end of a strip mall in Montecito, Sakana is a true hidden gem of the locals scene in Santa Barbara. Pulling up to this unassuming and intimate restaurant right next to a Vons, you'll find a dim-lit and charming interior boasting incredibly creative sushi with picture-perfect presentations. 

Like Nicolette Sheridan, this is what we call a sure thing.

First, the menu is huge. If you're a strict traditionalist then you'll be disappointed since their spin on sushi is quite novel; combining fish, textures and flavors in ways I had never before seen. We ordered the Surfer's roll...twice...maybe three times because every time it hit the table everyone began using their chopsticks as weapons of war. We went on to devour the Red Dragon and Montecito rolls with impatient precision. The ahi tuna appetizer is also worth noting. The sushi is served in press box form so you won't find any seaweed holding things together or impacting the overall taste. Every dish is positioned like artwork with splashes of colorful sauces striped across and as you eat and dip the image on the plate transforms. 

It's not cheap but it's also completely worth the price tag. Plus, they are cool with BYOB so our feast for four ended at under $40 each. For a bonus, see if you can convince your dining companion that the HD fish screen is actually a live feed of the tank in the back kitchen. The fish is fresh enough for it to be convincing...

I'm in Philly. I want cheesesteak. 

But with a limited time schedule and a requirement for credit cards accepted we took a crapshoot and went with Top Tomato for our work lunch delivery needs via GrubHub. 

And it was good. Really, friggin' good. My cheesesteak hoagie came with all the fixin's and despite the lack of Paesano's oomph, I scarfed that sucker down more than happily. Delivery was 15 minutes earlier than quoted and lunch for five landed under $50. Ain't nothin' wrong with that, son.

Is it sacreligious to say that the Philly cheesesteaks here were less than amazing? Perhaps I ordered wrong but then again, is that possible when you're ordering hunks of meat wedged between two oiled up halves of bread?

First off, provolone was an extra dollar which made me forget to order mine with provolone - lame. Then they didn't whiz our stuff like we had asked and PD had to go back for heaping cups of whiz for us to smear ourselves (free of charge thank you) along with hot sauce which didn't appear readily available (thought there were pickle slices galore). I ordered the meat with spinach which actually tasted a lot like meat and garlic bread...weird. The cheese fries were ok but Shake Shack's waffle fries easily kill Jrs. 

So needless to say I was underwhelmed. I love me a cheesesteak but I've had better from Jake's Steaks in San Francisco. Ok, now you 'delphians have at me!

Good place to catch a train if you're running late, great place to wait if you're running early.

Beautiful high ceilings and plenty of food options make this train terminal both quite functional and gorgeous at the same time. Unlike Penn Station (where I wait all too often) there is plenty of seating at 30th. The traffic at the front can get bad if your trying to get in or out during a rush or snow storm but ultimately you'll get in.

Coffee, tea, magazine or coffee. Despite the wait, the Philly folk at Amtrak will help you get where you need to go.

YEAAAAA found the best pizza in Houston!!! better than p1nks & r0man0s.

Customer service is bar none!

Granted people have their opinions of their favorite pizza and get all butt hurt if theirs isn't the best. So you just have to try it for yourself and be a ponzo fanatic too :)

Out of town for the month and was craving a pizza. I was staying at the Hilton Garden Inn near the airport and called this Papa John's around 10pm. They couldn't deliver my pizza because of a high robbery alert in the area.. well... :(
Great Tennessee wet ribs! I can't wait to go back. They also had live bands performing which made it fun.

I think this place will be much better once they iron the kinks out and the newness wears off.  Right now the seating capacity is no where near the demand and they seem to rush everything to turn the tables over.  We ordered 2 pies and a salad.   They had everything come out at the same time so there was no flow to the meal. 

The pizza where good the crust was good but the escarole salad was terrible.   The dressing was flavorless,  the anchovies were old and had been opened for a while but the worst part was the greens.  Escarole salads need to be the younger greens or the hearts.  They server the main leaves which are tough and almost inedible.

Honestly was excited to find an iron chef place in Philly.  I knew I would have to wait to get in but that is something you are used to when it comes to "hot spot" eating.   There was over a 2 hour wait which is not great but still doable.  What was unacceptable was the hostess at the front.  She was flat out rude, could care less about the customer.   No I am sorry about the wait or have a drink at the bar or anything. She never even asked if we wanted to put our name in like most other places in the area.   Someone should coach her to tell her she works in the service industry.  

Shame just a pure shame this hostess is the experience she gives customers when they go there to have an Iron Chef experience.

Fun little downtown cafe for coffee, light lunch, or gelato. I enjoyed a house coffee (served in a ceramic cup, not paper) and Caprese sandwich. It was not small or giant, but was filling and fresh. The interior is fun with art hanging and an all important fire place. I'll add this spot to my 'when nearby next' list for sure.
These good people at National provide top notch service every time I'm there.  If there is an issue they get on top of it immediately.  I'll use them any chance I get!

Maybe I'm a brave soul, but I don't mind eating off/at street vendors, and this was the same case as Lucky Dogs.  They are apparently a New Orleans/French Quarter institution and on several corners in the area.  

My other half got Krystal Burger that evening, and I went for the Lucky Dog.  When I approached, one of the vendors friends sized me up, and said, "You want a Lucky Dog with chili and mustard, don't you?".  Not knowing any better, I said, "Sure!  Sounds good!".  

The result was actually pretty decent, but I was surprised with the price at ~$6, and then the vendor asked for a tip.  Strange ... I'm not getting that much service and you expect a tip?  

Be careful if you get one with chili, cause they do put a bit on and can end up on your clothes.  Not like I'm saying that happened to me, or anything. ;-)

I HEART Bacchanal! Imagine if your best friend had a great backyard, the skills of a celebrity chef, had tons of musicians friends  and told you could come by whenever you liked and grab a plate of pure yumminess --- Got the image? OK, now THAT is Bacchanal. . . . Food there is always great (and SO MUCH cheaper than those restaurants that get som much hype)!!

The only reason this place isn't 5 stars is that I often find the layout awkward . . . even more so when it is crowded. You buy wine and cheese in the front . . . have to squeeze through table to get to the counter and place your order and pick it up. . . 

Still, all said, Bacchanal is WONDERFUL and my go-to favorite restaurant in NOLA!

This is definitely a must see for those who truly enjoy the Holidays and all of its Seasons Joy. Such a wonderful happening for one neighborhood community to gather together and put such a marvelous show of display of bright lighting and shimmering decors for one and all to enjoy. Some of which are quite grand and extravagant while others are of simple yet joyful sights.

If you've never seen these dazzling array of christmas lighting and decorations, be aware that it does get quite crowded and be prepared to do a lot of walking to take in all the surroundings. Also unless you don't mind parking about half a mile to a mile away, just opt to pay for one of the many nearby parking options for $5.00. It after all a free community event on display by this wonderful neighborhood.

At one of the entrances ( we entered from E Prince Rd onto N Treat Ave ) you'll have volunteers handing out maps and various vendors and tents set up. There is also a trailer and cable trolley ride that you can pay for and just ride along through the neighborhood. But if you're walking, be wary of these trailers as they go by because they tend to be oblivious to pedestrians walking along the streets. 

As you walk, you will encounter an abundance of activities and goings on; a high school band performing songs on the front lawn of one home, carolers singing on a street corner, an area for children of all ages to write letters to Santa and hang on a tree, playing by the snow making machine, even though hardly any snow was coming out of it  o(^-^)o  and much much more. You'll even see several home owners just cozying up outside of their home or in their drive way around a metal fire pit and maybe roasting some marshmallows and have a warm beverage just watching all the revelers walking "THEIR" neighborhood. 

So get on your walking shoes, definitely get the stroller or wagon for the little ones, cash for vendors and beverages, take photos, and enjoy the holiday season.

I came here with my friends after dinner, and we got a table and some drinks. The place was super colorful and brightly lit, and most of it was part of the outside patio. It was still pretty cozy though!

Our server was nice, but she disappeared for a while and we had to look for someone else when we wanted to order more. But other than that, the service was okay.

The one thing that I didn't like as much was that there were a handful of bachelorette parties going on. There was clashing music, girls hitting on random strangers, and etc. I mean it wasn't such a big deal that it bothered me much, but it was just a little odd. And if I were having a bachelorette party, I don't think I'd want to look over at the next table and see another bride-to-be with pretty much the same thing going on there.

I came here last time I was in SB to try tandem biking for the first time, and it was fun!

It was really easy to rent the bikes, and the staff was friendly. No fuss - you sign some papers, take the bike out, and pay for it when you return.

My friend and I opted for an hour and we rode around the beach. They have some paths for you to follow, and an hour was good for us. We couldn't go that far, but we still got to bike around for a while. 

Besides bikes, they offer other options like surreys, choppers, scoot coups, so you can take your pick! :)

It's the best. I make a pilgrimage for Los Angeles at least once a year for this.

Amazing.
This is affordable decent Chinese food.  Nothing special, but everything is done well and the food arrives hot and the order is accurate.

Went on girls night out here this past Tuesday and there isn't much to say about this place but just mediocre.  Its a fairly narrow restaurant with a pub like feeling.  There were four of us and they seated us at a fairly small table with hardly any wiggle room.  The servers wear white lab coats which remind me of medical students instead of wait staff.  It would be nicer if they used real linen napkins instead of raggedy kitchen rags.  Besides that the food was ah.. I've had better.  We started off with the assiette De charcuterie which is an assortment of the pate.  It was very good and out of all of the 4 pates my favorite was the rabbit and the condiments were also delicious.  For entrees we had the moules-frites (mussels with french fries basically) which was a large serving for dinner, entrecÔte grillÉe et frites (grilled rib eye steak with fries), jÄgerschnitZel (panned veal ) and the ÉtouffÉe of blue crab & brown shrimp.  The food was nothing spectacular but truthfully I think Besh's restaurants are overrated since I've never had a memorable dinner at any of them. So will I be back, probably not.

I find it kind of funny how I find myself missing this place when I never found it entirely delicious when I lived in SB. Perhaps its just the memories of my 8 friends and I weekly gathering along the long sushi bar after a long 6 hour class at Brooks... Or perhaps it was the half-price weekday lunch special that kept our wallets AND our stomachs pleased. The fish wasn't always daily fresh and the rolls could never be compared to Edomasa but the service was decent and the food usually hit the spot. For poor, hungry college students, something fishy is a great lunch spot.

Awesome! Only would have been better with an additional bathroom/drink break.

Our tour guide was knowledgeable and told the ghost stories without being overly dramatic, giving them a more realistic feel. The history on the tour is great. I've been on many ghost tours throughout the country, and this was by far, my favorite. 

With a "pay what you feel" policy, this tour is a no brainer! 

Although, I'm sure at the end of the tour, you'll have no qualms paying the tour guide an ample sum :)

I wish they were in every city!

5 stars all the way. Even with the crowd. But a crowd usually  means it's good, right?

Mazzaros is huge Italian market in one of the most unexpected places in Florida, I mean really, St. Petersburg?

You can get pretty much get anything here; huge raw meat case where you can get anything from beef tongue to swordfish steaks. Next you'll come to the frozen foods case, don't pass this one up! You can find their homemade lasagna , cannoli cream, and some other frozen, homemade, Italian fare. Some of the best lasagna I've ever had, great to grab and heat up for a crowd.

After the frozen case you'll pass the wine and cheese room. Enormous wine selection and they make their own mozzarella. I always grab some every time I pass through!

The final, and largest area has the coffee bar, dessert case, deli counter, and market area. The sandwiches at the deli are all AMAZING, not to mention super affordable. Just had an ahi tuna sandwich with wasabi mayo recently. GREAT. There is also a large selection of prepared deli items, but frankly it's always so crowded in there it feels rude to crowd up to front and browse......maybe another time.

The dessert case is also enormous, one stand out I can remember is the cannoli cake, which I thought just had a canolli on top. WRONG, it has canolli cream LAYERS. Seriously, when I get married, this is what is going in the layers of my wedding cake.

Every time I come here I always bring an ice chest; so I can take some Mazzaros goodness all the way back to Gainesville.

The bottom line first: it doesn't matter how good your cevapi are, Bosna Gold, if I'm too thirsty to enjoy 'em. Seriously... waiting for ice cubes to melt so you can suck down an inkling of hydration is not cool.

Argh.

Such is the problem with many European restaurants. You want authentic Bosnian fare? You got it. However, that also comes with a heaping side of blatant disregard for good service. If I may make a suggestion, order a soft drink or Fructal juice in addition to a glass of water (the food is salty and you'll be dying mid-meal if you're depending on a refill). You're welcome!

But I digress. The food is solid-- I tried the salad with feta (no lettuce, just cucumbers, green peppers, tomatoes and feta) as well as the cevapi. The meat is excellent, and the homemade lepinja bread is more buttery than most I've tried... delicious! I did miss the kajmak though... what's up with all the Bosnian restaurants in St. Louis serving sour cream instead? It's just not the same! Sigh... I feel cheated.

Oh, and my take on the restaurant? Jimmy Buffet meets Vermont ski lodge. Quaint, cozy yet hokey. Niiiiice.

You're hungover. Turkey leftovers are tired. Gyros sound like more the ticket! But mom can't find out you're skipping the remains of her laborious turkey dinner.

Okay by now, it's clear I'm talking about my cousin... definitely not me!

But I digress. A couple clicks on my Yelp app yielded what would turn out to be a deliciously messy, completely necessary experience with an overstuffed gyro. Sure, Soco Gyros & Deli doesn't look like much on the outside... but tell that to your mouth after putting away one of these stacked sandwiches!

Meat: Most excellent! Tzatziki: Luscious. Pita: Very good. Hot sauce (don't judge): Terrific. Presentation: Perfectly swaddled like a newborn baby (read: ain't no meat falling out of this pita!). Only menu item I can live without is our shared appetizer, the hummus, as it lacked that homemade taste and super creamy texture I love.

Just a little over $20 for a solid lunch of two gyros, two soft drinks and that ho-hum hummus. And mission accomplished: I got back to my cousin's couch and promptly fell asleep for three hours! That's one hell of a gyro-induced coma doing its job and erasing hangovers all over the StL.

I wanted to love it, I really did. But Berix fell a little flat for me in a few key areas.

My mom, brother and I came here for lunch with pita and cevapi specifically on the brain. You order at the counter and then take a table. The restaurant itself is really clean, spacious and has sort of a cozy ski-lodge feel. 

My mom placed an order for our cevapi, a cheese pita and also two pitas to take home. However, when the order came up all the pita was on the tray instead of being packaged to-go as she had asked. Not a biggie, but they also gave her spinach pita instead of cheese for some of the order. No language barrier, just unmindful customer service.

My cevapi themselves were really good, but there's more to cevapi then just the meat. The bread and kajmak also contribute to the total awesomeness. While the bread was perfect (and I mean perfect!), the cevapi were served with ajvar. I asked for some kajmak but received... sour cream! Lack of the ideal (and authentic) cevapi condiment? Somewhat of a letdown. 

The pita was so good my mom served it at Thanksgiving dinner instead of making her own. So we'll definitely be back for that. Berix also makes burek, sarma, gulas, raznici, kebabs and pljeskavica in addition to more Americanized sandwiches.

Trivia: wondering about the name origin? No, it's not Bosnian. It must be derived from the name of the intersection-- Reavis Barracks (Berix) and Lemay Ferry.

I'm loving Northwest Coffee even more now since they started serving eggs several days ago.

Plain eggs, eggs with cheese, eggs in a tortilla, eggs on a bagel, eggs on an English muffin... you get the picture.

They actually steam their eggs under one of their espresso machines! So, they come out extra light and fluffy, and the water expands them nicely. No butter or oils necessary! 

And, their eggs are locally-sourced from the River Hills Poultry Alliance. They're 'happy eggs', as they come from free-range chickens that are free of antibiotics and humanely raised. And yes, you CAN taste the difference.

They still make the meanest latte ever here, too! Try 'em.

Awhile back, I purchased a Sony mirrorless camera and slowly stopped using my Nikon DSLR. Though I actually prefer my Nikon, I found it and all its gear just too bulky when traveling. And I really only use my mirrorless and DSLR cameras when traveling, so the compact Sony camera won.

A few months later, I found out that Schiller's buys used camera equipment in good condition. As I had no real emotional attachment to my Nikon, I decided to visit Schiller's to see what I could get for it. Lo and behold, I was offered $430 for my gently-used camera, 3 lens, and a speedlight flash which I thought was more than fair. 10 minutes later, they cut me a check and I was on my way. 

If you're coming here to peruse camera gear, their selection is second to none! New, used, vintage SLR, DSLR, mirrorless, you name it. Their service is very comprehensive so the only negative may be that you may end up waiting awhile... and there's no clear queuing system. Otherwise, Schiller's is tops within their niche!

New Day Gluten Free is a true sanctuary for those of us who can't process wheat like the rest of you lucky folks. There's even a sign on the door stating no outside food can be brought in, to ensure the environment isn't contaminated!

Indeed, New Day is 100% wheat-free. Visiting their new location had topped my bucket list for the last couple of months, as they were moving their previous shop to a shiny, larger location in Clayton. And what a gorgeous space it is! Just going on 3 weeks new, we snatched the last open table on a busy Saturday.

Nothing can prepare you for the beauty that lies in the glass-encased baked good display case. Generously frosted cupcakes, gooey butter cookies, lemon bars, the cutest cakes and much more! I ordered a carrot cupcake and lemon bar to-go for my mom and me, and for lunch we opted for a turkey club and a California melt.

While both sandwiches were outstanding, I think my mom was a bit envious of the warm bun that hugged the overflowing toppings of my sandwich. Fresh turkey, provolone cheese, a liberal spread of guacamole, onions, lettuce and some mayo. But THAT BREAD! Wow. Just as good as bread made with conventional flour. This was my favorite type of sandwich in my gluten-eating days, so it was a dream to take in. 

After suppressing the temptation for a solid 8 hours, I finally gave in to the decadent carrot cupcake that had been staring me down all day. Holy cream cheese frosting! That was definitely the highlight for me and then some, as the cake portion was slightly dry. Still, it was one of the better gluten-free desserts I've had. Next time, I'll be trying the vanilla cupcake as that's my usual go-to treat.

Thanks for filling in a much-needed void in St. Louis, New Day! You've earned some new lifetime fans.

When the 'lover of sweets' file cabinet is opened, I'm not in there. In fact, when I feel a craving coming on for something outside the realm of savory, I'll turn to Yelp's unofficial guru of all things sweet, Johnny T. A recent conversation with a very indifferent me went something like this:

Me: I think I want something sweet, but I never know what to get. What do you usually go for when craving sweets? 

JT: Ice cream. Chocolate. Cupcakes. Cookies. Pancakes.

Me: Nah... keep going.

JT: Macaroons. Fruity drinks. Pralines.

Ding, ding, ding - PRALINES, people! I'll go on record to say that pralines are the most satisfying form of sugar I've ever put in my mouth, especially if they're from Southern Candymakers. You know you're in for an inimitable treat when you're greeted with that smell - a heady mix of childhood nostalgia that for me, was reminiscent of waffle cones being made at Six Flags (only exponentially better). A candy crafter was busy at work hand-scooping creamy dollops of praline onto a marble slab and cheerfully asked if I'd like a sample, even though I had already acknowledged I was purchasing a few. Oh good gracious, southern hospitality... teach the rest of us, please?

I walked out, practically skipping on a clear, sunny New Orleans day with my decadent collaborations of fresh cream, butter, sugar, and Louisiana pecans swinging in my right hand. The world and my heart stopped for a moment while I took that first bite and contemplated saving the other two pralines for later... but I couldn't. A handmade praline is a gift, and you shouldn't deny yourself the unequivocal, wholly-sating sugar high only a perfect praline can bring on.

It should be noted for tourists that Southern Candymakers' pralines are wrapped very simply (for those considering bringing them back as gifts)... think of the wrapping as expensive lingerie. Is it really necessary when you're about to be passionately consumed with what lies underneath the package? Exactly. Take it from a new-to-the-club praline junkie - these exquisite treasures simply should not be missed!

Love coffee mixed with a heaping side of socializing? Then Northwest Coffee Roasting Company is your spot, yo.

But first let's cover the important stuff-- the beans! I chose a Mocha nonfat latte as my inaugural drink at NCRC. No bitterness, just a smooth, rich caffeination ride. Mocha-choca-latte-ya-ya!

Grab a seat at one of the tables or at my pick, the coffee bar. The super friendly staff is fun to chat up... Emily the barista sensation is a sweetheart! Really, this coffeehouse is more Cheers than coffee depot. After today, I bet they even remember my unusual name. 

Free wi-fi should you feel like being productive.

Modesto just keeps moving, tweaking and re-inventing. Just because you've got a good thing going, you can't rest on your laurels. And these restaurateurs get it-- from menu redesigns to new tapas, evolution is the word @ 5257 Shaw Ave.

I met up with my longtime bestie from Buenos Aires for a night of girl talk, sangria and our favorite small plates. The restaurant was full and we didn't have reservations, but you can reserve a table in the bar area... 10-minute wait, score!

Can't-miss:
Mussels steamed in hard cider with chorizo and peppers
Lamb skewers with yogurt and herb salsa
Baked goat cheese in spicy tomato sauce
Hangar steak with port reduction
Bacon-wrapped dates stuffed with Cabrales cheese

Pass: Flatbread with caramelized onions, olives, garlic and Manchego cheese. Just a bit too sweet.

Service is always courteous and professional, and the sangria... oh the sangria! If you haven't tried sangria made the authentic way with brandy, well then just you wait. It's the champagne of buzzes... exquisite!

A jewel in Ybor City, La Creperia Cafe's specialty are crepes... both sweet and savory.  But if you don't like crepes, they have an extensive menu that includes panini, pastas, salad, wraps, and a myriad of beverages.  

The crepes are large and made fresh to order in the window at the front of the store.  I had the Turkey a la Brie, packed with roasted turkey, creamy Brie and tomatoes with a small side of lettuce, tomatoes and cucumber.  It was sooo yummy, but I couldn't finish it because it was so large!

I was tempted to order the "Latin Lovers," a sweet crepe with Nutella and bananas, but I figured I should have something more substantial than dessert for dinner.

I stayed here in August or September 2007 when I had to go to Tampa for some training.  

Due to the proximity of this hotel to the Nielsen Company location on Brooker Creek, this place should just rename itself "The Nielsen Dorm Facilities."

I dig the feel of this place--  old school new york subway station meets  fancy southern restaurant.

However, the meal didn't live up to the setting.  The oysters were outstanding, but the prepared dishes felt short (meh on the salad and the shrimp). Also, the service was painfully slow.

Ooka has been recommended to me by a few people at work as the best sushi in town (Willow Grove that is).
Upon arrival, I was greeted with very pleasant, smiling faces of the hostesses and many of "The Best" and "Top Pick" certificates from various review centers (yes, Zagat, too).
I have to say, the food was amazing and I really enjoyed it, but your restaurant experience is only as good as the wait staff.
To make a long story short, I never got my soup, even though I asked for it twice.
They brought the wrong food to my table at one point.
I had a constant feeling that I'm not welcome and need to leave pronto.
They were cleaning out the plates in front of us the moment I lifted the last piece to eat it (not quite literally, but it felt that way). By the way, I appreciate when the waiter/waitress cleans up quickly, but there's 'quickly' and 'too quickly.'
Lastly, I really wanted to try their amazing-looking desserts, but I was never given the chance to pick anything, asked if that's all I would like to have that evening and the waitress just showed the check in front me and left.
Shortly after that, I was gone too.

There are many other Ooka locations and I'm sure I'll have a better overall experience there, so I'm not completely DONE with them as a chain - the food was really good and presented beautifully.
Heck, I might even give this one another chance, just because I used to be a waiter too and know how some nights are just not meant for working :))

I went to Benihana at the Plymouth Meeting mall (right by AMC Theatres) on Christmas day. It was the only (besides the Chinese buffet) open restaurant, but they were not too packed. As soon as we sat down, the server was greeting us. From the moment we walked in, to the moment we walked out, the staff was smiling and giving us their full attention. The cook that prepared our meal was skilled and even tried to be funny (unsuccessfully :)), but overall, we had a great time. Between the three of us, we couldn't finish even the two main meals, after we had three appetizers.

I will go back again. Soon.

Yummy cold brew coffee & friendly staff. However prices are on the steep side and there is no a/c. On a moderately warm day of 70, I was starting to sweat in the couple minutes it took to get my drinks I felt awful for the staff who have to stay in that sweatshop for hours. Management needs to stop being so cheap and actually turn on the a/c!

Topa Topa is a cool bar located in an old converted car garage. The space is very spacious with tons of tables and plenty seating around the bar. Delicious beers on tap which you can purchase by the pint or growler. Staff is friendly and accommodating. Food is also available for order in the hallway to the right. Stop in for a refreshing brew!

The service was nice but the food can only be described as average and overpriced. I highly recommend sitting on the outdoor patio. We came with a large group so we got tucked into an unsightly back corner inside. The difference in decor and atmosphere is night and day. Decent place but nothing to write home about.

This is certainly not a bad place to stay but given the price range, the hotel leaves much to be desired. I came here for a work conference and I would not choose this particular hotel for pleasure given the option. 

Calling this a "beachfront hotel" is a bit misleading. It should be called - "Hilton wayyyy across the street from the beach." That said, there was a nice little path you can take from the hotel to the main street (which is across the street from the beach). 

First off, the grounds are confusing upon arrival. There are signs for the Lobby but finding your particular building and the elevator for your building may be a challenge. Not a great first impression. 

The premises themselves are a bit dated in the common areas- think older carpets and dank/muggy hallways. On the other hand, the room and the lobby areas look newly renovated. My "garden view" faced directly into the parking lot which is adjacent to the Amtrak line. If possible, request the garden view or the oceanfront view.

While the suites looked fairly nice, I did not feel like the A/C worked properly. The room would get hot and the air felt very dry. Opening the balcony allowed quite a bit of noise (think Amtrak right behind the hotel) so it was not the perfect solution either. 

I found the cleaning staff to be great yet the hospitality people varied in friendliness. As a pregnant woman, I was also a bit bummed that I was not allowed a courtesy 1 hour later check-out time to lay down during my lunch break. Usually, this is a common accommodation I have received at other major hotels. 

All in all, this was a fine stay but did not leave me wowed. I would recommend that the management improve the a/c and do something about the bathroom sinks which spray water everywhere and have scalding hot water.

My boyfriend's fam who live in the SB mountains brought us here for an early breakfast.  We were the first ones in the 2nd dining room so we got to snag the table next to the fireplace and had awesome attentive service from our super friendly and accommodating waitress. 

The prices are standard and the food is delicious. I enjoyed the Santa Barbara omelette and the house potatoes were good too. I thought the molasses toast/biscuit w gravy were just okay, toast came on regular sliced bread with a little sweetness, not the fat french slabs I had envisioned...oh well, no biggie b/c it was still a huge meal without the bread. 

I recommend taking advantage of their early opening time and getting quality service for an early breakfast :)

We went on the bike/wine tour through the San Ynez Valley and it was really wonderful.  The trip was organized very well, the wineries we stopped at were fantastic, and the bike ride was pretty easy and relaxing and lots of fun.  The scenery is really wonderful and I can't think of a better way to see the valley then on a bike.  I highly recommend this trip! Only thing I would change is adding one more bike riding segment!

We had one of the most amazing dishes I've ever had EVER at Herbsaint: the Rabbit Fricassee. It basically tastes like smoky rabbit bacon awesomeness. If someone had put 5 pounds of it on the table in front of me, I would have eaten all of it. Then I probably would have died, but I would have been the happiest man alive.

But there were other things too.
Like the Duck Leg Confit, which was possibly the best duck dish I've ever had. Duck is usually WAY too fatty for me, and this wasn't at all, while also being juicy and delicious.
I also had the fish of the day (a gulf redfish), which was perfectly cooked.

We were also very amused by the wine list, which was remarkably California-focused, but also quite reasonably priced.

Service was excellent, and the restaurant is comfortably nice - guests ranged from a few in nice jeans to a few in suits.

I will absolutely go back for that rabbit though. Damn.

5 stars for the food, the environment, and the thoughtful service.

It's a quaint country farmhouse converted to a wonderful, romantic restaurant, with tables spread throughout its many rooms, most of which have only a few tables providing an intimate, classic dining experience.

The food is uniformly fantastic, from the classic Caesar salad prepared tableside, to the big, rich Maryland crab cakes wholly comprised of fresh crab meat and plated across a pair of spicy and pesto sauces.  Lobster crepes (stuffed with equally massive amounts of lobster), truly rich lobster bisque, moist tender rack of lamb, and obscenely intense veal tenderloin with exotic mushroom sauce (a special) were equally brilliant examples.
My only observation and minor nit about the food was that the meat was not precisely cooked - all the smaller medium-rare items were solidly medium, while the larger filet mignon, ordered medium, came out medium-rare.  But all were delectable, and very tender.

Desserts were equally brilliant, from the Belgian dark chocolate mousse to the Austrian cheese strudel.

The wine list is reasonably large and well selected, especially considering the location, though the markup is enormous.  Unfortunately, due to the exorbitant licensing fees charged by Pennsylvania, this is more or less unavoidable, and with a careful search (and sufficient knowledge) reasonable value items can be found.

Service was friendly, helpful, and knowledgeable (though the average wine knowledge of the servers isn't large).

If you're looking for a fantastic meal in an out-of-the-way, rusticly romantic environment, look no further.

They also have a B&B with quite reasonably priced rooms on site.

I was struggling with what was going to be review #1500. Would I go try a new place? Would I seek out something unique and fun to celebrate? I contemplated it. But I decided I'd rather review Wat Mongkolratanaram, a Buddhist temple in Tampa that offers a lovely Thai market on Sunday mornings. It's not something you come across too often.

I had been looking for cool things to do in Tampa, which are hard to come by, as I left the city somewhat indifferent about it. Luckily, before I left, I had found out about this place on the Tampa talk threads. From what I can tell, you need a car to get here.

I agree with much of what has been said: come here early (parking is rough and food runs out), bring plenty of cash, and plan to grab some small items to eat while you stand in line for the noodle soup. I missed out on the noodle soup because of poor planning. Do not let this happen to you. Also, come with people that like to eat and understand waiting in line for food.

Food wise, we tried various spring rolls and dumplings, beef satay, pumpkin curry, and chicken basil. Everything was great, and I'm fairly obsessed with the spring rolls. I also tried the papaya salad, and that was the only thing I did not really care for, and normally, I love it.

The grounds are idyllic, and the temple is gorgeous. There's really no other way to describe it. Ideally, when I return, I'll return alone, and be able to stay for services, which all are welcome to join. 

As a visitor to the area, I definitely recommend finding a way to get here. It was a highlight of my trip.

I've been having a hard time finding a good brunch spot, until I found Jones.  Unfortunately for me, Jones is a 3 hour drive.   So I will not be frequenting it - but one can dream.

We sat upstairs, which I recommend - a little quieter & you can watch everyone below you.  We were there around 11:30 on a rainy Saturday, and were sat immediately.  Service was fine, and fast.  Decor is super cute.

I had the French toast with tater tots.  Tater tots, you ask?  Yes, because where I'm from, they are not quite ubiquitous.  My Philly friend (aka tour guide) also had the French toast, and my husband had the avocado sandwich with fries.   The French toast was thick and tasty, and probably the biggest piece of French toast I've ever seen.   I enjoyed the tater tots.  My husband liked his sandwich and fries, but the fries went cold fast.  

Perhaps a second location in DC or Boston is needed?

I don't always get drunk and go to clubs, but when I do, I like to make sure I'm on vacation in a different city and pay a cover.

I remember mostly EDM with some hip-hop, a lot of dancing, and it being super crowded. Floor was sticky. Definitely a dressier crowd. I don't miss my club days.

I had fun, but keep in mind, I was feeling the effects of alcohol. I'd probably not choose to go here sober, however, I didn't see many other dancing options in the immediate vicinity.

My iced almond milk caramel latte was fine, as was my friend's cortado and bagel. Four stars for the overall atmosphere, decor, and service, but three for the coffee. I've had better, and I've had worse. I prefer a strong coffee/espresso flavor, and my latte was missing that. It was more milky than anything, so the overall balance was off. Pastries (not bagels) looked tasty, and if I did happen to stop in again, I'd grab one.

Muriel's is a fine dining gem. I had been wanting to visit and finally, on my last night in New Orleans, I did. I enjoyed the fantastic service and delicious food.

I hadn't yet had a Hurricane and figured this would be the perfect place to get one. I definitely enjoyed it. The bread is addictively good and I couldn't stop eating it. I ordered my new standard--greens and redfish courtbouillon. I love redfish. Both the items were great. I loved the greens and the popcorn rice paired well with the redfish and sauce. I was too full for dessert, but I definitely want to return and will definitely be ordering dessert.

If you are looking for fine dining and excellent NOLA cuisine in the French Quarter, Muriel's is your spot.

This shop is fantastic. It's very welcoming and not gimmicky. I felt like the staff was really knowledgeable and helpful. You could tell they love talking about and teach about voodoo. My interaction was great--I told the super nice gentleman what I was going through and he recommended the perfect item. My Oya doll and I haven't been separated since. I really appreciate that he took the time to explain her protections and offer other suggestions as well. I'm looking forward to returning here on my next visit.

Our iced caramel soy lattes were OK. Something was missing--perhaps a stronger coffee flavor? Their hot lattes may be better, as some places are better at hot lattes than cold ones.

However, I did love the fun, eclectic vibe, and the food we saw looked delicious. I'd come back to try some noshes, keeping in mind that the line gets long and parking will take a few circles around the block.

We all really enjoyed Pho Street. We didn't plan our visit, but were happy to have happened about this place. It's casual with plenty of seating and you can order at a kiosk, which is much appreciated.

I did a quick scan of the reviews to know not to order the pho. I ordered the grilled pork vermicelli bowl (bun thit nuong with cha gio), my sister had the Vietnamese hoagie (banh mi thit nuong), and my brother-in-law ordered the broken rice (com tam) with a cha gio side. Everything was excellent. The pork was super flavorful and there were tons of fresh vegetables and herbs in my bun. My sister said the bread on her banh mi was great. And my BIL loved his perfectly cooked and delicious com tam. We all appreciated the crispness of the cha gio. Even my baby niece enjoyed the vegetables we gave her. I love that they have a house-made fish sauce, which add depth to everything.

I'd stop here again if craving Vietnamese in Center City.

This bustling station is beautiful. It probably works well if you know your way around, but as a visitor, it's frustrating, due to lack of available information. Directional signs are not clear. The website is basic, at best (given that it is run by Amtrak, that is no surprise), so finding information prior to visiting is a chore. A quick peruse of the food court options also proved to be basic and most close early. No place to grab a great coffee in the morning. Bathrooms are fine and at least there's an ATM and a convenience store, but this place could be better.

I could've skipped this and would've been OK in life. Anyone who tells you need to do a cemetery tour in New Orleans is lying, unless they are are really boring or really into history. The tour was good, but I was bored. You can walk around a free cemetery and see some graves--no need to pay. You can see a bit of this particular cemetery from outside the walls (this one you have to pay for and can only get in with an official tour) and that's all you really need in life. Save your money and your time for the important things, like drinking.

Hipster heaven, but my barista was surprisingly friendly.  Very good lattes, though I definitely needed sugar for mine.  Cool atmosphere, and the pastries looked amazing.   Definitely better than going to a Starbucks.

I was expecting greasy, lackluster bar food here and was very pleasantly surprised to enjoy delicious, creative, gourmet food instead! My favorite dish was the smoked trout wontons, but really everything was pretty amazing. Loved the chocolate lava cake. I'll definitely make a point to come back here the next time I take the train to Philly.

Beautiful place for a wedding. Parking right outside (first 75 minutes free) or park across the street in the parking structure (first 75 minutes free and $1.50 for every hour after).
There are many floors and hidden gems in this beautiful space. I attended a wedding in the Mural Room and it was stunning.  The judge who married my friends was stellar and even came around to say hello to the rows of attendees before the start.  They have a clock tower here and the history behind it is fascinating. You can also go to the very top and see a beautiful 360 view of Santa Barbara. Truly a great space for guests to entertain themselves and enjoy Santa Barbara. This is preservation and history at its finest.
Amazing food and gluten friendly too. Go there with friends so that you can pig out on all the yummy appetizers. This is the first time that I had southern food and I am highly impressed by it.

Decent quality. The Siu Mai does not look nor tastes like Siu Mai. The salad was drenched in dressing. The miso soup have a hint of bitter tasted but then I have very sensitive taste buds. I ordered the Chirachi bowl which lets me taste the quality of the fishes. Half of them tasted fresh. The other half was okay. So overall assessment... Eh... It's okay. Disclaimer: I'm use to the standards in NYC, and Los Angeles.

This market was small and had limited items. It was ok for some dry or canned items. Otherwise, I didn't find anything impressive. 

They have your snacks such as shrimp chips, and pocky, and mochi.

They also carried a variety of dry noodles and ramen. Canned vegetables available at most Asian markets. 

There were some prepackaged bags of vegetables in the fridge but I'm not sure how often their shipments come in. 

They also carried a few different cans of Thai curry and prepackaged teas.

We love this park! Discovered it when I met a moms group here and there is so much to it. They have areas where you can plan soccer or basketball or so many other sports. 

There are roads where you can basically go for a walk and circle the entire park. There's a section where there are benches and it's covered so there is plenty of shade and restrooms! It gets REALLY windy though so be warned.  The kids playground has a variety of things to play with for the younger and older kids. The downfall is that it is not covered.  The bigger issue I have are the large ant piles (most likely fire ants) which I am deathly allergic to. What if one of the kids walk through it by accident? One of my bigger fears.....

Do not allow yourself to leave St. Louis before hitting up a restaurant and having their fried ravioli with marinara sauce. This casual restaurant reminded me of a typical American eatery with a few outdoor seating on a nice day. The inside of the restaurant was rather spacious and dull. Don't forget to try the Creole Pasta with Sausages. The portions were pretty large but it was all worth the extra inches on the waistline!

This Target was far off in the distance in this strip mall but it needed the space because of the size of the store! 

Service was fairly friendly and most of the time the folks were more by the cashiers area. The aisles were clean for the most part and items on sale were displayed. 

My favorite part is the $1 (or not $1 section) and of course who doesn't enjoy their Starbucks while browsing through the Target aisles.

I thought it would be a good idea to come by here for dinner the other night with the family. It was so busy and the wait was rather frustrating.
