Yeah a bit pricey for a Vietnamese joint but I'd rather spend 10 bucks on a meal here then spend $7 at a drive thru.  Much better for you and go ahead and titilate your senses.  You can alwasy douse your pho with Siracha or Hoisin Sauce.

The windy road seemed awkwardly familiar and although I hadn't driven down this particular path in almost a decade but I was ready...The young man taking my order before the first window was adorable, "The three please with a Dr. Pepper."  

I had been craving InNOut ever since we left Monterey, my sister had returned home for a family emergency (our first and hopefully last) and she had to get to her Global Environmental Politics Final by 4pm.  I got her to UCSB and dropped her off by Campbell Hall by 2:15pm.  There are several of these fine burger joints on the route down the 101 but we kept missing each and every single one so you can see how I was hungry to floor it to this particular location off Turnpike.

The ladies at each window were beautiful and customer service was impeccable.  My "car ready" meal and I (with onions nothing animal style, that's a bit much for me esp. since my sister was having major gas issues on the drive down and she said if I had ordered animal style and she had to smell it that she might poop in her pants and the thought of that well you can see how I wouldn't want to order anything, fries included animal style.)  I drove a few exits south and parked in a parking lot.  I had devoured my little heavenly balance burger (crunchy fresh cool onions and lettuce, warm beef patty, juicy tomato and tight slightly toasted bun and the sauce is killer, next time I will ask for extra sauce.  That alongside a few fries while sucking down a packet of ketchup and a few sips of nice cold Dr. Pepper.  I was happy but felt slightly bad that my little sister was taking a final and I was in pure bliss.

We stopped in for a quick lunch and I was craving Fetuccini Alfredo.  I ordered the closest thing to it on the menu and it was the Cajun Pasta.  It was actaully pretty good.  However, we foudn hair in our food.  Our group expereinced hairy food at every restaurant we stopped in.  No joke.  I don't think hair nets are necessary in TN.  They should be.  

A very casualy bar/restaurant that you can get rowdy in if you want to.

When I was getting my nails did in walking distance at Famous Nails yesterday the ladies that were working got a snack at Jack's... totally brought back memories from when I used to have the munchies and was at FT (Fuck Towers now Santa Catalina Dorms) or when I was filling up my gas next door at Chevron and skipped over for a Spicy Chicken Sando (those are the best!).

Hot, quick and greasy... what more could one ask for (question mark).

One of the best places to go if you are out of the dorms and fending for yourself out in IV or if you are too cool and mature and move out near State St. or the city college.  

Cheap eats and affordable booze, it doesn't get much better than this.  Besides the one closer to campus on Calle Real, this was my go to market until I graduate in 2002.

As Sam stated when we first sat down at one of the casual picnic style tables in the middle of the restaurant- we are a group of, " dietary restriction (shrimp as he pointed to himself), dietary restriction (gluten as he pointed at me), dietary restriction (gluten as he pointed to my partner), restaurant owner/chef (as he pointed to my Dad - it was our Father Daughter Ski Weekend), and I forget what he said about my sister but you get the point. Not an easy party to deal with especially at an Asian restaurant (where shrimp can be found in some fish sauces and gluten hidden in many others). 

Our server's customer service skills were on point and she went above and beyond to accommodate us without making a fuss. We were beyond grateful.

Pho bowls here are double the size of any pho restaurant i've ever been to before in my life. I ordered the oxtail pho because it was seasonal as did our father. We both though the oxtail could have cooked slightly longer as it would have made the near fall off the tailbone but other then that the broth was super rich, had solid depth, and full of flavor.

The shrimp summer rolls were enjoyed by all minus Sam (shellfish allergy) and they made one of the specials GF for our table. If you see it on the specials board, I would highly recommend trying it out... the sautéed eggplant served in a hot clay pot with the optional minced pork meat was divine! With a side of rice this would feed 2 to 3 people. I hope they have it next time we head up to Reno to ski Mt. Rose

Nothing better than a bowl of hot noodle soup and some specialty comfort food eats after skiing a perfect 
bluebird but cold ski day, best snow, and even better company!

The views are gorgeous and the outside seating is perfect on a warm day but the food is below par.  My friend and I both tried the Cheese Tortellini with a Marinara and Bolognese Sauce Combo.  I just expected it to taste a little better considering it is served on paper plates and puts you back eleven bucks.  I'd rather hit up the Hot Dog Haus located somewhere on the lower half of the mountain.  They serve Elk Chili and their hot dogs are off the hook... not to mention super long and delicious for only $5.50.  The hot dogs at Two Elk starts at $8.

My sisters and I love enjoying a pitcher of Sangria here... we were in the area on Monday for lunch and we didn't quite make it to Cafe Buenos Aires for our sangria but I'm glad that we stopped by Andersen's Bakery instead as this place is now closed.  The number is out of order and I just read in another post that they were closing.  The links on their website are down too so I guess they are gone.  So sad.  I'm glad my sisters don't know as they would be very bummed about this.
Stop in here to and from the mountains for a tune up or to check out what stuff they have on sale.  I got some tees for $4.99 can't beat that.  (Perfect for little gifts.)  Always friendly service.

Wow really?  More like Not So Good... I don't get how once can spend so much on not so lovely quality things... I do but at F21 prices... the earrings I saw here were $14.99, $12.99 and some on sale for $8.99 or $6.99 but the quality is the same as F21 and their prices start at $2.99... I just don't see how people can love this place... yes it is eye-catching and a lot of "pretty" and sparkly things but to me they are at rip-off prices.  I saw feather hair clip extensions that went up to $35 or more and they weren't even nice pheasant feather or anything... I saw a one feather clip that had one feather on it that was $8.99 and I got a bag of 200 (of the same feather) for $4.99 at Beverly's Fabrics last week... maybe part of the clip was missing?  When I went to touch it the feather wasn't even fastened correctly on the clip and the feather pretty much flew away... I was in shock.  

1 stars because it is a smart idea to pack a place full of "cheap" jewelry but it's also uber cheap quality and 1 star for the entrepreneur who is banking on the profit.

Oh Man.  Where do I begin?  My sisters and I hit this place up and it was better than I remembered from my visit before (but it had been at least 6 years).  

Great atmosphere and nice mixed crowd.  The order taker is an adorably cute gentleman and if you don't know what you want ask him to recommend something.l  We ordered about 6 items to share and I asked him to pick the last one and his was the highlight of our little lunch fiesta.

Here is what we ordered (and not in order):

Tecate with Lime

Horchata - Grande

Pechuga Suiza - Chicken/Cheese served between 2 corn tortillas

Carne Asada Tacos (a bit dry, but some salsa on it and make it wet)

Carnitas Tacos  (a bit dry as well)

Green Chile and Cheese served between 2 sheets of corn tortillas (my sister saw them charring the chiles on the grill and wanted to try it, super sweet but I wish we got them without the cheese)

Side of Today's Special - Arroz/Rice

Side of Guacamole

Today's Special - Tacos Deshrebada ( shredded beef served with a creamy avocado sauce, um yes please)

The Recommendation - Chilaquiles ( hot chips drenched in a spicy tomato broth mixture then topped with cheese and grilled green onions - just gorgeous)

After he placed the Chilaquiles for us then other people started to order and one lady asked if I special ordered them since she didn't see them on the menu.  Minutes later they placed Chilaquiles on the Today's Special Board. 

Um you could say we left full.  Salsa bar is a nice touch and the covered patio seating is awesome.  This place is always packed especially during lunch and it's funny to watch the locals practice their Spanish with the man in charge.

Talk about a convenience store. This is more like a smoker's post-toke dream. 

If you're looking for smoking paraphernalia, this store comes stocked with pipes, hookahs, grinders, screens, papers, loose tobacco, flavored cigars, all sorts of snacks, and even "Irish" food. Not sure what really constitutes as Irish food since all I really found we items to satisfy the most serious munchy craving. 

You'll also be pleased to know they take credit cards with a reasonable $5 minimum. I'm pretty sure this store knows its niche.

When I was searching for some 3.5-4 star level hotels in downtown St. Pete, I was surprised to find the Courtyard as my best option. In most other cities, it isn't too hard to find an under-$200 locale but to be accessible to downtown, I sacrificed a moderate upscale experience with this middle-of-the-road option.

If you're driving, you'll find there's only 2 hour street parking outside. Meaning: valet will park your car for $12 overnight. I found the hotel lobby to feel a quite dated and certainly teetering quickly towards a no frills experience. Up the elevator to floor 7 revealed a slight improvement in the room. Flatscreen TV, partial view of the water beyond, a king size bed and a large bathroom. While I still couldn't shake the feeling of being in a creaky, old hotel, I slept with the TV on to dissuade phantom visitors. 

Should you rise early, the modest gym on the lobby level has what you need and the small indoor pool adjacent to it adds a little perk. Breakfast doesn't come free, but it comes relatively cheap. Grab a free apple on your way out and opt for the free shuttle to take you around downtown!

There's no man who could ever endure the pain associated with a Brazilian wax. If there were such a man, or woman for that matter, looking to experience the most painless and satisfying procedure, (s)he better look to Kim at bluemercury. 

She wielded that wax with the utmost precision and grace. Unlike, other hair removal spots that use duct tape to strip away the unwanted comrades (*ahem International Salon), Kim applied the gentleness of a lamb and stripped away with the force of a lion. 

She was so great that I even got a facial afterward. In our dimly lit room, she massaged the chunks of cheek on my face and even gave me a shoulder and neck rub. The only awkward part was when I put the robe on as a cape, to which she exclaimed, "it's not meant to be worn like Batman, Monica." I may never feel totally comfortable naked before a stranger's eyes, but Kim put me right at ease and got the job done quickly and painlessly!

The food was ok, the service was abominable, but thankfully, they're open late. My mom, brother and I arrived at 10pm on a Saturday night to a near empty restaurant and it took our server a solid 15 minutes to show face.

Once it was all said and done the food was just ok. Sushi was toothsome, but my brother's chicken teriyaki (I don't endorse this order either) was dry and bland. Soy Vay could've done a better job as a sauce.

Why Haru wins: smart, casual sushi joint in Old City with a full cocktail menu and a decent wine line.

Without wanting to drive well out of the city, Sammy's proved to be the nearby Chinatown option to cure our afternoon Korean craving. 

We were one of very few occupied tables, but that didn't bother us -- the ambiance however was lacking (but no surprise there). 

We started with the complimentary banchan and I found the kimchi fresh and fermented, just the way I like it :) The pot of barley tea warmed us up on the cold and rainy afternoon, but it didn't help that heating/insulation seemed to be non-existent. 

The food is what really impressed though, my dish in particular. I'm a fan of dolost bibimbap and galbi, but I'm always torn on what to order. Here, there was no need to choose; my galbi came served atop my piping hot bowl of bibimbap! It was magnificent. Similarly, my date's bean paste soup was a winner. 

Come for the galbi bibimbap!

After trying just about every vet there is in the city, I've -finally- found the one. Tucked away in the heart of South Philly is a state-of-the-art, environmentally conscious vet hospital. 

I called this morning looking for a quick appointment and to my surprise, they were able to see me just an hour later at 10am. The facilities are really impressive. The room was spotless and felt less like a sterile vet's office and more like a cozy little holding pad. 

Dr. Majeska saw Giles (my pup) within 15 minutes of us getting there and get this, she sat on the floor with him. She gave him a very complete exam and talked me through every step of the way. There was never a feeling of being rushed out so she could get to another patient and her placid, conversational demeanor instantly put us at ease. 

Just as much as Dr. Majeska cares for pets, she's clearly got a thing for the environment. This brand new facility boasts a green roof, environmentally sound architecture, reused plastic bags, and paperless billing, to name a few features. 

After diagnosing the pup and suggesting a system of attack (he's got a growth on his paw and his ears are chronically itchy), we proceeded on to the medication I should start giving him. I agreed with all her suggestions, which sounded totally logical, and upon paying for all the antibiotics, pills, ear cleaner, ear medicine, and doctor's exam, the total came out to $150. Seriously, that's nothing compared to what I had calculated in my head. 

The staff was beyond cordial and Giles and I couldn't have been more happy. So I think: amazing service, amazing facilities, thorough exam, AND affordability - I wish she could be my doctor.

Great local roaster boasting a cozy coffeehouse vibe reminiscent of Seattle in the 90s. There's no formal register and the one or two employees running the show seemingly hang out in the open area where you get your fresh cup of pour over style coffee.

Great spot to work away the afternoon.

I could basically copy/paste Jason F's review into the box I'm currently typing in. I too went to Bitar's in search of that perfect falafel sandwich. What did I find? Bland falafel balls overly drenched in hummus and tahini. Talk about a messy sandwich! I actually had to change my pants from all dripping that went down. 

I still look to Maoz as my favorite falafel sandwich. Perheps Bitar's can satisfy on the meat end of things? What say you Philadelphia?
Back again to Honey's where not a thing has changed and thank god. Huevos rancheros still better than any other version I've come across in the great U.S. and enough flannel to screw a lightbulb.

Being in the business of event planning, you deal with all types, but ultimately it's the efficient nice folks who get my company's hard earned dollars. I've worked with Mike and his team twice now and both experiences have been filled with quick, efficient, and personable service.

For an upcoming event, Mike came out to the site, measured all the rooms and is in the process of entering the info into a program that creates a basic blueprint of the venue. He's figuring out where all the tables are to be situated, he's helped me visualize where the vendors should go, and even offered to deliver and pick up the tables, chairs, linens, and other rental stuff during non-business hours. 

Being a one-woman operation, it's really wonderful to have someone like Mike on my side. He's taken a lot of stress off my shoulders and I gave him a muffin for that.

A particular morning found me a dejected, poor, unfortunate soul with no promise of fortune and no care in the world. So I wrangled up my favorite Bay Area heathens, Dusty Muffins and Winnie Bago. "We need a change," I urged. "We need to kick these small town blues and dive deep into the heart of something sinful, degenerate, and downright depraved."

With a nod and a sock, Dusty mounted his hog and tossed us eagle monogrammed leather jackets. "Lasso up your gumption, Sharon and Winnie, we're hightailing it to the biggest little city in the world." 

And so we descended upon the Peppermill. Italian busts, Julius Caesar, a bronze fountain in the swimming pool, poolside pina coladas, flatscreens in the bathroom, and more bikers than you could fit in a sombrero. We were slingin' 5 dollar chips with reckless abandon, chumming up to the dealers, and striking gold. Our money won was twice as sweet as money earned.
 
When you're in Reno, there's just no reason to leave the Peppermill. It's got more class than Venice. Just like taking an Italian voyage to the Bahamas. That or straight to hell.

Last night might have been my favorite dining experience to date. My 3 friends and I took over a downstairs booth and indulged in far too many dishes. Everything was absolutely perfect - from our server to our food to the cocktails. The dishes came out in excellent timing and with all of the items we tried, not one fell short of amazing.

What we ordered:
Cazuela de Chorizo y Papas - chorizo and potatoes with kale in casserole form. So hearty and delicious!

Tostadas de Tinga - shredded chicken served cold atop a crispy tortilla. These were heavenly.

Ensalada - something light and fresh to cleanse the palate. I loved the jicama!

Atun ceviche - buttery chunks of yellowfin tuna ceviche. Yum.

Platija - maybe the favorite. Fluke ceviche served over those same crispy tortillas. The mild fish was so simply prepared but oh so good.

Carnitas de Pollo - we were really full by this point, but I loved that they embraced the crema for these baby tacos. 

Carrillada de Cerdo - pork cheeks

All in all, you should absolutely go to Xochtil.

I ordered this expecting nothing more than wet socks served over dough. Meaning, just something to fill my stomach. Much to my surprise, what came delivered to my door is now amongst my favorite pizza in this city. What? Really? Yes! Favorite pizza in this city.

Were it not for the fact that they forgot to add chicken to the "Chicken Garden Salad" I'd have awarded them 5 stars. Nothing really notable about the salad except for the fact that it's not as fattening as the pizza. 

Order this tomato pie and you won't be sorry. Unless you're a sorry kind of person...in which case I can't help you and neither can pizza.

Last night, the cozy yet bustling ambiance of Xochitl really shone through for me. Maybe it was all the new people I met, or all the faces I hadn't seen in a while, or exchanging a game of footsie with my friend - whatever it was, Xochitl really came alive.

The experience began by sitting at the bar (often a wise decision) under the care of Eric. He's a pro and just before you've cleared your last sip, he's at the ready with a new drink in hand or a quick recommendation. Eric is fast and efficient without being unnecessarily chummy but don't let it fool you, you'll be exchanging high fives after your 3rd or 8th drink. He also happens to be one of the most respected bartenders in Philly. 

New chef Lucio Palazzo has maintained many of the old beloved dishes while adding some excellent new choices to create an accessibly smart menu. 

Some things you should check out:
-La Chilindrina (blanco tequila, blood orange, lime, canela, chile)
-Chespirito (poblano-infused blanco tequila, green chartreuse, St. Germain)
-Cazuela de chorizo y papas (caserole of chorizo, potatoes, and kale)
-Queso fundido

Regretfully, I did more drinking than I did eating, but the little I did have definitely piqued my interest for some more. Perfect spot for a date or a late night drink. Actually, it's just awesome all around.

You can tell by the austere, wooden interior. You can tell by the unpedestrian beer options. By the barista with a hidden smile (only to be shown for those "in" folks). And last but not least, you can tell by the references to indie music, bike culture and flagrant love of cool bluegrass. If you were to equate a bar's clientele to music, let's just say you won't find a Creed fan in this room. The Independent is where the cool kids fetch pints and later down them with a dose of sick tunes.

There's a food menu too should you be so inclined and wine's not lost on them either, there's a decent selection of adult grape juice for winey wanderers.

If you like babies, this is the best place to baby watch. It's a true melting pot with tikes of every ethnicity! If kids, adults, waiting, and bureaucracy  doesn't suit your interests though, you should probably go around 9:30am Tues-Thurs. I was in and out of there within 15 minutes.

Large, clean Chinatown haunt with food that everyone can enjoy. From picky eaters to adventurous ones; vegetarians to carnivores, Vietnam satisfies every palate. Meateaters shouldn't miss the BBQ platter (which is more than enough to feed 3) and then wash that down with a steaming bowl of pho. 

You've also gotta love their flaming punchbowls filled with liquor to the brim. My vote goes to this Vietnam over the across the street neighbor...especially if you're on a date.

Despite finding the most hideous 80s prom dress ever (this was a success, actually), I simply couldn't get down with the curtained dressing rooms. Sure, they're nicer drapes than what you'd find in grandma's attic, but (un)dressing in them caused me to hit the peaks of anxiety - and I'm not an anxious person.

Public nudity aside, the prices are reasonable, the selection's name-brandy, and the merchandise is well-organized. Now if only I wanted to try more things on.

After a night on Frenchmen St., hanging out at the Spotted Cat, we decided to call it a night and head back to the hotel. As we ventured out onto the street, we heard music. Granted, on Frenchmen St. at that time of night, it's not abnormal to hear the sound of jazz music coming from every direction...but this was different. As we approached Maison, the sounds of The Jackson 5 poured out of trombones and saxophones, and onto the busy street. The open doors and people dancing inside the large windows beckoned us to enter. When we went inside, we had one of the best experiences during our trip to NOLA. 

That night happened to be a "open mic" night. A night where locals brought their own instruments, jumped up on the stage, and joined the group, ad libbing and free styling r&b, jazz, and any other genre that was requested. You could tell that these were regulars, some of the musicians on stage would call others in the crowd, asking "Where's your trombone?", and telling people that they need to "Hurry up and get up on the stage!" The jam session quickly turned into a trombone vs. trumpet battle. Both sides taking turns trying to top each other....blaring notes, clapping hands, and shouting filled my eardrums as the audience watched. 

This is a part of NOLA that I always heard about, and was so happy that I got to see. I heard that the food was good as well. I didn't try it, but next time I definitely will. Great spot!

Greatness! 

This was the best meal that I devoured during my NOLA visit! 

We came across this place totally by accident. It was a rainy Sunday, and we were taking a walk down Frenchmen Street. It was lunch time, we were hungry, and The Praline Connection happened to be right in front of us! We hadn't heard of it before, but we took a chance and entered. Not only did it turn out to be a shelter from the rain, but a haven for gorging and overeating. 

The wait staff was excellent, very helpful and friendly. The establishment is separated into two parts, the candy store where they sell pralines, and the restaurant. The walls were decorated with antiques and paintings, it had a good vibe. There weren't too many people inside at the time, so I was kind of wary...but that all changed once the food came out. 

I had the seafood platter...shrimp (great), oysters (great), catfish (great), deviled crab (great), half of my friends bread pudding (OMG sooooo awesome!). The seafood was seasoned perfectly and the bread pudding had a praline sauce on it that consisted of pralines and bourbon I think. She had The Taste of Soul platter that consisted of ribs, chicken, catfish, etc... When I think of the amount of food that we both ate that day, I almost get sick. The words gluttony and greed come to mind. So, my lesson for you, the reader, in this review, is please try to not overeat during your visit here. It not hard to do!

FINALLY got around to trying this gem of a hole-in-the-wall!  After living in Santa Barbara for three years, we thought it was about time to try the coveted "Julia Child's favorite Mexican restaurant."  We went for the #2 (steak tacos), #16 (the special with marinated pork, cheese, and grilled peppers), and #18? (guacamole and two tortillas).  We loaded up on the fresh salsas and eagerly awaited our order.  There was plenty of seating (specifically, lawn furniture) in the semi-covered patio.  We were there at around 4:00, so it wasn't too busy.

When we got our food, we couldn't wait to dig in.  The #16 is definitely not overrated.  SO tasty.  LOVED the peppers.  Would definitely order it again.  The homemade tortillas and the guacamole were certainly tasty.  I loved that we could literally watch our tortillas being made from scratch as we waited in line.  The steak was pretty good in the steak tacos, but we'd probably try something different next time.  The salsas made everything taste better.  And we got a generous-sized cup of water, which is a lot better than those mini cups that most places give you, to make you feel bad for not buying a beverage.

The whole meal for me and my boyfriend was $13 - quite the deal!   And the cashier was friendly, and they bussed the tables in a timely manner.  This place is definitely worth trying.

One of the best places to visit in Santa Barbara.  Great for all ages, and anybody that appreciates nature, animals, or the beauty of butterflies!  Yes, that sounded corny... but you will not regret it!  You can easily walk to the beach and have a picnic before or after.  Sometimes there are park rangers there with binoculars and information to share, but you can bring binoculars just in case.  Cameras and pictures do not capture the beauty of this place, so definitely go and see it for yourself.  I believe the best time of year to go is late January/February?  I've gone every year at this time since I moved to Santa Barbara four years ago, and I'm amazed every time!

I really like the layout of this Starbucks.  There is a variety of seating choices (long wooden benched tables, small armchairs, and standard tables, with outdoor seating as well), with plenty of electric sockets for laptop use.  And being that this Starbucks isn't the biggest, I think they use the space nicely.  My drinks have always been made just fine here, and the baristas are friendly.  Parking is pretty easy, so what more could you ask for?  A great location to stop at after a morning workout at Spectrum!

I've been here once for a dinner, a couple times for happy hour, and one attempted happy hour.

I probably wouldn't recommend this place for dinner.  The prices are just too high.  I did have a fabulous Cioppino (I wish there was more broth though, that's the best part!) and the waiter was super attentive.  We had ordered the red clam chowder, but he accidentally poured the white, so he brought both over for us to try.  Very nice!  I'd recommend it for lunch, because it looks like they have similar offerings, but for much cheaper.

The first time I tried to come for happy hour, it was towards the middle of their happy hour on a Friday, so it was impossible to find space.  Other times, I've been poured a good glass of wine, but that's all I've really tried.  I'd like to try their happy hour appetizers, but I have to plan to get there right at the beginning of their happy hour... and that requires too much thinking and planning for a happy hour!

Very much a touristy thing to do, but that doesn't make it any less awesome.  The Deep Sea Tasting Room is on the harbor, which is a good place to have a SB experience.  The wine, albeit, is not amazing.  The prices are average, but I have not been impressed by the flights.  I'd recommend getting a glass of your fave, in order to avoid tasting some not-so-good wines.  However, the staff here is super friendly and you can't beat the view!  I wish they had more/better furniture in the outdoor patio.  But, really I am just nitpicking - go to Deep Sea Tasting Room if you enjoy sipping wine with an ocean view.  And who doesn't?

If you could go to one tasting place in Santa Barbara, I'd recommend this one!  Although I love Kalyra wines, I think this place is fun because they have so much of a variety, with wine and beer flights.  They have a traditional beer tastings, as well as fruit beers.  You can apply the flight price to your wine/beer purchase, which is always a plus.  

The flights are pretty affordable (normal for the area), with a range of options for different prices (i.e., chardonnay/white tastings are cheaper than some cab/red tastings).  

This is the best place to take a group, even if they are newbies to the wine/beer tasting world.  The location is great - take a walk along the coast after you taste!

The only reason I give this place four stars instead of five, is because the staff weren't the friendliest.  Not rude, but not nice and welcoming either.  But I've only been here once, so maybe next time my experience with the staff would be different.

Yes, we are health freaks, but really... they have probably the best burgers and fries I've had.  I rarely eat red meat... let alone with a side of deep-fried potatoes... but I will stretch to make excuses to eat here ("I was in Vegas all weekend and still need to soak up the alcohol.... I went to the gym everyday this week, my body probably needs protein...").  Hey, I didn't say they were good excuses.

I tried the turkey burger once, which is usually my go to if I'm craving a burger... but I say, splurge for the classic cheeseburger and fries.  This is a once-a-year treat, but so worth the wait!

Love the concept of this place, love the food even more.

The bf and I shared a Backyard Bowl for a Saturday afternoon snack.  The fruit was fresh, the bee pollen was sweet, the goji berries were chewy, the granola was crunchy, and the blended smoothie part was refreshing.  Just a perfect, perfect combination of fresh, (mostly) organic and local foods.  It is a little pricey, but you get what you pay for... and it's definitely worth it!  I want to go back and try the other bowls... but you have to be careful with calories on these.  Although it sounds and tastes healthy, I think it's better to share a bowl unless it's your lunch (forgive me, I'm on a calorie-counting kick right now).

I also really like this location.  A walk from the major shops downtown, and there is an open-walled outdoor area to eat and enjoy the Santa Barbara breeze.

I love this farmer's market!  It's tucked away in a street a couple blocks from downtown.  There's always a musician or two lightening the mood, as well as the balloon animal maker.  

My favorites:

*Autumn - grape stand, especially the lychee grapes and big, crunchy grapes
*Winter - persimmons, sugar snap peas, carrots
*Spring/Summer - all stone fruits!  
*Year-round - bread

Yes, prices are pretty high relative to other places in California, but normal for Santa Barbara.

Almost as visually pleasing and relaxing as the beach.  The architecture is just beautiful, parking is easy, and the view is breathtaking.  I'd like to take advantage of the thick patches of grass for some reading pleasure or a picnic.  And I'm going to bring any guest that comes to Santa Barbara to the clock tower view.  Ahhh, bliss.

Perfect place for a quintessential Santa Barbara meal!  The location of this restaurant is right on the pier.  I wish the view was a bit better out the windows.  I would have sat outside but it was pretty cold that day.  We went around 2pm, so the wait was only about 10-15 minutes.  And we were able to watch the chef butcher and steam some massive crabs while we waited, quite entertaining!

We went with the coveted clam chowder and the cioppino in a bread bowl, along with some beers.  The ideal Santa Barbara meal!  Service was great, and food was quality.  A great place to bring a (small) group of visitors who want the Santa Barbara seafood experience, without the super high price tags.

Thanks Cat Cora for the recommendation.  Casey and I have ventured up the mountains of Santa Barbara to satisfy our tri-tip craving two or three times now, ever since hearing about this place.  On the weekends (and I think just Sundays during non-summer months), they do their famous tri-tip sandwiches that you order in the bar (pay attention, because it's not obvious to figure out), and then you take your sandwich ticked up to the grill.  They give you a hefty portion of tri-tip laid on an oh-so melt-in-your-mouth roll.  There's a couple sauces and au jus to choose from.  And then you eat.  Perfection.  There are plenty of places to sit outside, accompanied by several biker dudes/chicks.  Great place to go if you're visiting SB or if you live in SB and have visitors (carnivores).
Umm, cashiers are NOT nice, I retract!  Zero stars for you, Kmart.

Went today for the opening and was very pleased!  They advertised a noon opening, hyping it up by passing out flyers downtown last weekend.  They said there would be freebies for the first 250 customers.  I didn't really want to wait in a long line for a clothing store that I could find on weekend trips to LA, but when I was downtown today and the line to get in the store wasn't long, I decided to give it a shot.  They were giving everybody $10 off coupons for $50 purchases.

I expected the worse as I entered the store... I thought it'd be a mess.  But it was one of the best organized, cleanest, neatest H&M's I've visited... and there were SOO many people!  So that shows that this staff has it down from the beginning.  Very impressed.  The space is pretty big, and there are a lot of clean dressing rooms.  Yay for H&M finally coming to Santa Barbara!

Uhhh seriously?  I'm shocked at the high reviews.  I will flat out say from the get-go... we are Yogurtland fanatics, so all yogurt places are held up to the Yogurtland standard.

-The price: relatively expensive compared to Yogurtland (Yogurtland is 30 cents an ounce, this place is 38 cents an ounce).

-The yogurt: not firm at all, didn't have the right tart flavor... totally was melting at a faster rate than normal.

-The toppings: meh.  Nothing special.  The fruit was not particularly fresh, and the dry toppings were similar to most joints.

-The service: fine.  Nothing extraordinarily good or bad.

Two stars, because why go here when we could go to Yogurtland?  It's even worth the drive.  Won't be returning, not worth the money.

I thought about giving this place 3 stars... just because it's so expensive!  Almost $5 for a smoothie I think is kind of ridiculous.  I can make similar-tasting ones at home.  But I do admit that all of their smoothies are pretty delicious.  I feel like their trick is their orange juice.  Get smoothies with orange juice - they have a wonderfully tangy, sweet flavor.  The fruit is fresh, and the staff is usually pretty friendly.  When Casey and I bought a smoothie to share this weekend, they offered to put it in two cups, which was nice.  I would go here more if a) it wasn't so expensive, and b) smoothies weren't so high in calories.

We went here this past weekend, since I've been living in Santa Barbara now for about 2.5 years, and we still haven't visited this iconic landmark.  The self-guided tour is $5 each.  It'll take you about 20-30 minutes to go through the tour.  There is also a fountain/lawn/garden area in front that would be a great place to have a picnic.  The mission was really crowded on Saturday, maybe because of Easter weekend.  It's not that big.  Lots of free parking.  A must if you live in Santa Barbara, and a good place to go if you're visiting and enjoy history and landmarks.

The combination of the wonderful smoky smell that always comes from this place + the awesome low-budget commercials made us expect more (seriously, how can you not love those commercials?).

We got a combo plate to go to try at home.  The interior is very nice, plenty of seating, and service was super speedy.

We got home, and opened the styrofoam box, revealing 5 small pieces of tri-tip, two pieces of chicken, 4 corn tortillas, and small cups of rice and beans.  The tri-tip was overcooked.  These guys got nothing on Cold Spring Tavern.  The chicken was delicious - tender and flavorful.  The beans were a little "al dente" as Casey described, but I thought they were good.  And the rice was okay.

Overall, not very memorable.  We probably won't be returning (if we did, we'd just get the chicken).  So unlike the commercial which claims "it IS the best!".... not so much :-(  We wanted to like it more!

Our experience was lackluster to say the least. The waitress got the wrong orders and repeatedly ignore our request to change it. she kept asking, "do you want more coke?" when she passes by. 

looking at other table getting the food they ordered, and savoying each bite as they chow down those juicy meat, kept us wondering: "what if we got what we wanted to eat?"

yes, this is a rustic tavern, enough said.

A little bit painfully slow and seemingly disorganized and understaffed. Great variety, though. Nice addition to The Gulch, and part of the very vibrant craft beer scene in Nashville now. Small place and gets cramped. Parking is not plentiful. Better in warm weather when crowd can disperse.

Great spot, with ACTUAL coffee shop hours, unlike quite a few Nashville cafes. (You know who you are.)

Also -jam- packed with beautiful Belmont ladies.

Cool theme, nice vibe, great place!
Best followup in this space so far. Unlike their predecessors, they seem to "get it" in many ways. A great addition to the scene on 10th and for Cummins Station.

Meh? These guys have a great location and a lot of potential but I was totally not impressed today. I ordered the orange chicken which was very chewy and dry. It came on broccoli which was barely steamed and cold. All the tables were sticky, and my tray was served with a previously used paper menu sheet, which might've just been beat up because he was placed on a wet tray. I didn't feel like there were any health problems in the place but it definitely doesn't stand up very well when you have superior options, both independently owned and nationally owned.

Holy HELL, the disorganized dumbfuckery here... It would be one thing if they were even remotely busy, or if it were just something like a language barrier but in general they seem to have an overall flawed process and trouble paying attention to what's going on. Having soy sauce locked up like Ft. Knox and then shoving a fist full at me wastefully makes no sense and just shows off the poor planning and lack of thinking involved.
Tasty fare and a nice addition to the Nashville food landscape. Awkward location to drive to. Try to do a rideshare or walk up.
Nice spot, and very well-located for all types of visitors, from daytime office traffic to the many residents of the Gulch. Nice to see them come to Nashville.

Phenomenal spot. Feels like a secret hideaway, loaded with history, excellent reuse of an old space. Good cocktail menu. Variety of party size accommodations. It can be crowded at times and a little hipster-dominated, but always a nice time.

Incredibly sexy spot for a date. If she's not impressed by this place, you call her a ride and lose her number. The mood and vibe are an ideal precursor for that "go back to my place" or "let's get a room" stage of the evening.

Good sound system and usually a good DJ working. It can get loud and the staff can be a little overrun, but a little confidence and good tipping goes a long way.

There are a few knowledgeable Nashville go-to locations for all manner of booze, and one of the best is Midtown. Large selection and good staff. Plenty of options for helpful attention to custom orders and such as well. Reasonable pricing and convenient location, with decent parking.

Retail haircuts are what they are, but if you ask for Tony here, you'll get someone who is leaps and bounds beyond the workplace he's operating in. Convenient location, fair prices, but beware some of the old, crusty employees who transferred in from Belle Meade when the two locations combined. One of the gals' bat-wing-flab will waft her ashtray-scent at you the whole time and you don't want that.

This is one of our staple neighborhood bars. The entire ML Rose "chain" is great on food and beer options, and the staff is great at almost any location, but this one (and Capitol View) tend to have the best crew. They have decent parking and they're convenient to a drive up or walking in. Their recent remodel really opened the place up nicely, expanding their outdoor gardens as well.

However, they added a really stupid mini-golf element and have lifted the ban on kids they used to have after 5pm. This was an unwelcome and inexplicable kowtow to the young families gentrifying the neighborhoods around them and the golf flag spikes are an insane liability to add to the drinking environment, to say nothing of golf clubs. Even so, this is a go-to for great food and drink from a genuine local spot.

Their name is a little dumb, and has a somewhat sloppy legal history, as they gave in way too easily to idle threats from a pool hall near their original location. They were "Melrose Craft Beer & Burgers" and when challenged, they backed down and chose the somewhat goofy "ML Rose" knockoff. Nonetheless, they are a key figure in the Nashville landscape of restaurants and bars and should become part of your regularity in places to hang.

Mike's is a staple and legend of the main drag in Nashville. They used to be on Broadway, but have expanded quite nicely over on 2nd. Great selection of ice cream and a must-stop for a visit downtown.

We had a very pleasant buying experience at this dealer on a beautiful and very busy Saturday. Pete Purky took all of the necessary time to help us with the final stages of a decision that we had been considering for weeks. Despite some of the normal trappings of a conglomerate corporate car dealer outlet, such as the attempt to nickel and dime you in the finance department, we came away with a positive impression of a dealer for which natives to the Nashville area carry decades of history and exposure to. The deal made was a bit more competitive than other area dealers and the correct vehicle options were in stock. Not having to test drive with the salesperson in the car was another big bonus to this experience, as the ride along is moldy and outdated and unnecessary in the modern age of tracking and technology. We were able to have an honest discussion between the two of us while we drove and truly check the car out in our own ways without a continued sales pitch from the backseat. Also, the final paperwork on the digital table was pretty rad.

Mike's is a staple and legend of the main drag in Nashville. They used to be on Broadway, but have expanded quite nicely over on 2nd. Great selection of ice cream and a must-stop for a visit downtown!

Recently, they bested the trendy "new Nashville" scene big time:

We decided not to invest time in a massive line at a half-empty Legendairy Milkshake Bar, so we opted to pop around the corner to the Nashvegas ice cream O.G. - Mikes. Violet worked her magic after I challenged her to show them up. It was delicious, and I've even named it for them: The Mug, the Myth, the LEGEND. (See what I did there?)
This location is a convenient alternative to the more crowded one a little further down, sans drive-thru.

Ok, I'm in St. Louis on a business trip, what to do for dinner? Hooters?  Nah, not really interested in wings and orange short-shorts.  How about some ribs?  I stumbled on Masterpiece and got pulled in by the smells, who can resist ribs?  Order at the counter and grab a table, within 10 minutes I'm greeted with a large slab of ribs over white bread along with a side of cheese bread and baked beans.  

Overall Masterpiece made some good ribs but not great.  A bit drier than I expected, I'm guessing they were sitting outside for a while.  Sides were ok but nothing to write home about, nothing particularly fresh.  I do enjoy my KC Masterpiece BBQ sauce at home but can't really say that you've got to try the place when visiting St. Louis.  There are probably better and more authentic rib joints in the city.  But I have to admit, the Gateway Arch on the walk back to the hotel was VERY cool....
Ehhh, it's just OK. Order Diner food and don't expect more.  St. Louis needs a nice diner. The staff need to pay attention as well.

This place only survives because it is in the airport, but otherwise it sucks. The food is better than the complete lack-luster un-attentive and verges on complete rude customer service. Better take it to go.

I wish Boston had a store like this. I love the selection and the quality swimsuits and underwear are unparalleled unless you shop online. AHH but you can, this place sports a huge online web store, but I still enjoy trying things on. I try to stop by every time I am in town.
Don't worry about going somewhere else for Vietnamese in St. Louis, this is the best.. That's it. the best!

I was back in the St. Louis area visiting family and a very good friend took me to this place.  Let me say. WOW- I was very impressed by this place, the place looks amazing. Friendly fast service and the Alsatian - Vermont Crème Fraiche, Smoked Bacon, Caramelized Onions & Dante Cheese wood oven pizza was really amazingly delectable. 

If and when I ever come back to BelleVegas--- I must dine here.

When I lived in St. Louis I loved this place, in fact I came here for another going away party with 12 or more people and we all had a wonderful time.

I no longer love this place. I came here a few weeks ago when I was in town for work and upon arrival the hostesses gruff attitude and hurried personality already rubbed me wrong.  The server a blond woman perhaps in her middle 30's early 40's simply was not as personable or enjoyable I was hoping she would be. She was inattentive and it seemed that waiting on us was a chore.

The food just didnt seem to be of high quality and lacked the flavor and creativity it once had. The Scallops were unbelievably small I guess I am use to large scallops I often see here on the East Coast. I will give them kudos to preparing them correctly. The Lobster was ok, and the shrimp was nothing exciting.
Disappointed in Modesto.
Nothing pleases a girl more than finding out that there's an Arby's directly beside her hotel.  And, that it's open killer late!!

If you're looking to scoot away from the touristy area of New Orleans, Morrow's is definitely a place to go.  When my friend and I arrived, we were told it would be 45 minutes for a table.  They don't take reservations.  Fortunately, we were able to snag two seats at the bar.  The service was friendly.  We were seated between two locals that struck up conversation and gave us recommendations on things to do and places to go.  

The food was good, albeit delivery was slow.  Real slow.  It took over 30 minutes to get a cup of gumbo, and over an hour to get our oysters.  The oysters were worth the wait.  So delicious (we got the charbroiled ones).  Drinks and prices were on point.  

Great dinner spot before venturing over to Frenchman for some local jazz.

Cool concept, but unfortunately it lacks any creative execution.  Lots of pancakes to choose from.  I don't really like pancakes though, so was stuck getting some bacon and eggs.  I'd say the food quality compared to that you'd get at IHOP or Waffle House.  My meal came with some pancakes on the side.  I got the banana bread ones.  They were decent, but far from amazing.  Actually, I could have made them at home.  

This place is overhyped and not really worth the wait.  Also, they don't offer anything but basic coffee and juice out of a carton to drink.  This is a typical diner, which happens to offer a million different combinations of pancakes.  I wouldn't go out of my way to return.

Craving noodles in Reno, and there was basically one option, Minato Noodles.

I got the Tonkotsu noodles, which was surprisingly brothy and delicious. Nothing was overseasoned, and takoyaki was also delicious.

My only gripe would be the toppings in the ramen. My egg was not soft-boiled nor marinaded. There was a singular bamboo piece. And the pork was pretty thin, as far as Chasu goes. 

Also, to add ANY additional topping it is 2 dollars. They need to differentiate some of the prices, as I really don't want to be paying 2 dollars for half a hard-boiled egg, or a couple pieces of bamboo. The only additional topping that it warranted being 2 dollars was the Chasu, which was also pushing it.

Still, great place for ramen, I wouldn't order any add-ons.

This was by far one of my favorite places on my recent trip to New Orleans.  Our sweet bartender at dba overheard that I was a vegetarian and suggested my friend and I try it out.  The atmosphere is quaint, cute, and comfortable. It helped that we stopped by on a local artists showcase night.  I'll tell you, I never expected the best country voice I've heard live to come out of a scruffy looking hipster!  Service was very slow as it seemed they were running with two bartenders and no servers, but luckily the atmosphere and being on vacation cured any impatience I had.  

As far as food goes, our ceviche was delicious.  We also ordered the butternut ravioli with brown butter... which was lacking.  I didn't expect the ravioli to be sitting in an entire inch bath of brown butter and would have much preferred a light brush of it.  Overall though, I really enjoyed the selection and the tapas style dishes because who doesn't like sharing?

Frenchman was definitely my favorite area of Nola and Three Muses is a running contender for number one on that block.

We stopped in here today for lunch, because my daughter wanted pizza. They have a kid's menu that's the expected stuff (pasta, mac and cheese, burger, etc) Her kid's cheese pizza was $7, and it was a really big pizza. It would have been to much for me as an adult, so a pretty good deal. I got a cup of French onion soup, my husband got the clam chowder special. Mine was really good, not to much cheese like some places. We also split the grilled cheese which had bacon on it and  came with fries. It came on thick Texas toast type bread, not flat bread like the menu says, but I liked it that way. All in all, a very solid decently priced lunch in Olde City. I'd definitely go again.

We went to Gennaro's last week for the first time, because I had been told they have a really great outdoor patio.  My husband, daughter and I brought a friend who was visiting from the West Coast.  The server was really nice. Her and the mosaic covered patio were probably the best part of Gennaro's.  

As someone noted in another review, they don't have high chairs here. It seems rather odd considering its an average quality pizza place. Luckily, our daughter is tall enough not to need one, but I wouldn't have been super excited if I had a younger child. Also, the front door has a sign saying something along the lines of "Well behaved children are welcome." Ok Gennaro's, you aren't that great. Your pizza is a few steps above Pizza Hut.  The POPE is a pub up the street that is very welcoming to kids. Le Virtu is a pretty high end restaurant up the street that is very welcoming to kids. I can't imagine childless people are showing up in droves at Gennaro's when there is Brigantessa almost directly across the street (which by the way also has high chairs.)

Also, they served out food with paper plates. Seriously. We ended up paying over $50 for pretty bland pizza, super dry foccacia bread, and their version of sangria. And we ate it off of paper plates!

So all in all, it was ok. I don't imagine we would go there again considering there is much better pizza available at much more child friendly places in the area.  But if you want to sit outside on a really pretty and shady patio and aren't worried about having the "best" pizza, it would probably serve your needs.

One of the best freshest Rock Crab I've ever had in my life. 

It was a late late late dinner. Did I mention how late we came in? We came 45 minutes before closing because we got to Santa Barbara late. The place is just 4 minutes car ride from where we stayed. 

When we came in, the place is almost packed and we proceeded to the corner booth.

So we ordered the Rock Crab and my wife ordered the Cioppino. What the hell is a Cioppino? For those of you who don't know a Cioppino, it's seafood chowder on steroid on a sourdough bread. And a side order of Onion Ring.

As we waited for our dinner, I noticed people still coming in until closing time.

When I ordered the crab, I was afraid not being able to finish them all. Well I was wrong... and full at the same time :)

Rock Crab came out fresh with a side of butter.

Cioppino was just a complete massive dish by itself

Gigantic Onion Rings to top our dinner off.

I was full, sleepy and felt guilty for staying almost an hour past their last call. As I paid our bill, I apologize for staying late. The waiter was all smile and said not to worry. 

As we got ready to leave, we realized that we were the last one in the restaurant and the last one in the entire pier...

Does Angry Chair have the most comfortable tap room in town where you want to sit for hours sampling the entire tap list? Nope. Are you guaranteed to find a wide variety of styles that will satisfy everyone in your party? Nope. Is parking plentiful and easy? Nope. Can you growler the more coveted varietals? Usually not.

So in spite of all this, what is the appeal? Simply put Angry Chair makes some of the best beers in the country. Whether you're looking for a mouth puckering sour or a dense pastry stout, Angry Chair can and does knock it out of the park. Producing some of the most flavorful and unique barrel-aged beers I've ever tried, Angry Chair sets the beer game bar high. Burkitshi, an Imperial Sweet stout with cacao, toasted coconut, and Japanese sea salt remains one of my penultimate favorites, rich and laden with flavor it reminds me of an Almond Joy. Another winner, Barrel Aged Popinski with Peanut Butter & Marshmallow tastes like a fluffernutter. A bottle we got lucky enough to enough to happen upon by pure happenstance, Bourbon Barrel Dave's Barleywine, had an excellent malt backbone and tasted like toffee.

The taproom itself is trendy and industrial, with cool metal bone seats that are more decorative than comfortable. Funky art scattered about, and of course the many references to "angry" chairs make for a laid back atmosphere. While by no means a spots bar, they do have a couple of televisions as well should you want to watch the game with a cold brew. Be warned though, the space itself isn't particularly large, so it may not be the best spot for a big group (although occasionally you can snag one of the coveted few more sizable tables).

While unfortunately I don't live close enough to synchronize my visits for every release, Angry Chair is my "must do" brewery every time I'm in Tampa, just in the hopes that I will strike the jackpot and pop in when they've just released something sinfully delicious. If it isn't already on your brewery bucket list make sure to put it near the top, Angry Chair produces the kind of stuff that both well seasoned beer geeks and novice drinkers will dream about.

A girl walks into a bar right as a band prepares to play, and goes to take a look at the drink menu. Vintage and seasonal cocktail options? Check. Interesting ingredients (like eucalyptus or Thai spice bitters)? Check. Then the music starts, upbeat and jazzy, and it feels fitting for the French Quarter. So she decides she should order a drink...

Quite some time later and I must admit, I was sold on 21st Amendment at La Louisiane. The drinks are solid, the atmosphere is lively without being raucous, and the music is exquisite. While it is a more intimate venue, seating routinely becomes available as the crowd ebbs and flows, making it a comfortable spot to hang out for a spell. 

Come with friends, come for a date, or come alone just to hang out at the bar, indulge in a cocktail, and enjoy the performance. 21st Amendment at La Louisiane offers a seductive scene with the winning ingredients to make a delightful night out in The Big Easy.

A small city unto itself, Gaylord Opryland is a sight to behold on par with some of the larger resorts in Las Vegas. A conference center and hotel, Gaylord Opryland offers ample walking paths, multiple restaurants, a river boat ride, a salon and spa, and now a water park as well. It is quite the labyrinth and is easy to get lost despite the signposts peppered throughout, although this often makes for the best exploration. While the hotel isn't located in the heart of downtown Nashville, it isn't a terribly far drive either.

Taking a stroll through the atriums is like being in a tropical oasis. There are multiple waterfalls, streams, and lush foliage. While I have no idea what any of it has to do with Nashville itself or its history, it is quite lovely. The strategically placed oversized guitars feel a bit out of place, and yet seem more authentic to the local flavor. Compared to Gaylord Palms in Orlando which actually has decor centered around Florida (Evergaldes, Key West, and Saint Augustine), I felt less of the connection to the city here. However, I can't deny that the hotel is still quite picturesque. Visit around Christmas, and the entire hotel is bedecked in holly and strings of twinkling lights as well.

Like any major hotel, Gaylord Opryland  comes with its pros and cons. The parking is high on my annoyance list, because although it is ample, it is pretty steep extra on top of the cost of your actual room. Whether you are a short term visitor, or a hotel guest, expect to pay around $32 a day. Also the restaurants are plentiful (think Italian, Mexican, sushi, and a grill), but none are particularly great. They do have Starbucks on premises if you are short on time, but walk or drive across the street to Nashville Coffees for a better selection and more interesting options.

If you are staying on business or at the hotel for a conference, the conference center is massive and quite convenient. There is more than enough space for an exhibition hall and smaller rooms for more intimate talks. WiFi is available throughout the area if you need to sneak away to get work done on your laptop. Speaking of the WiFi, you can also connect throughout the grounds or in the hotel rooms, and they have a direct wired connection if you need something faster, which makes a better choice if you need to connect to a VPN or are on a call.

The rooms themselves are comfortable, although certainly some sections are better than others. For example, a room in Magnolia may have you in a fairly basic look (your standard outdated hotel) and a view of a courtyard/pool, whereas in Delta the rooms seem to be a bit more modern, and if you're lucky you can get a view of one of the domed areas, which makes for great people watching.

Worth visiting at least once, even if you aren't a hotel guest! At the very least make a stunning venue to get some steps in...

Honey + water + yeast= mead

What seems simple enough, a historic combination standing the test of the centuries is still a popular beverage in modern times. However, Garagiste is not your average mazer, and the meads they produce are anything but ordinary. Well balanced Reboog Vitis is an elegant take on a peanut butter and jelly sandwich. Other varietals include adjuncts ranging from vanilla beans to maple syrup to raspberries. If that weren't enough to entice, then they add barrel aged versions that add additional complexity from Madeira to Cognac.

Many of the meads take on almost a wine like quality, balancing honey laced sweetness with a biting acidity. For those unfamiliar with meads, or those just wanting to try more of their masterful libations, I highly suggest grabbing a flight. The menu is ever changing, and often includes limited offerings that may not be available otherwise. Each mead is quite distinctive and may range from fairly dry to on par with a Sauternes. They do offer some snacks as well, which can provide balance to an otherwise saccharine tasting.

Truly one of the best meaderies to be found, Garagiste is undoubtedly worth a visit when in Tampa. Even those that think they may not enjoy sweeter drinks may find themselves a convert.

Okay, I'll admit it. I may enjoy an art project here or there but I have zero woodworking (or power tool) experience. Zero. Zilch. Nonexistent. I am also pretty klutzy in general, so the idea of making anything using sharp objects vaguely terrifies me. That being said, the Florida School of Woodwork in Tampa is outstanding. A valuable resource for fledgling newbies (like myself) and for those who are more advanced.

I signed up for the cutting board course with my mother. Apart from both leaving with all our fingers and toes present and accounted for, we learned a lot and had fun too. Our instructor walked us through the entire process, and allowed us to flex our creative muscles (within the scope of the intended project). We glued, sanded, cut, and other far more technical terms I cannot pretend to recall. Even better, we left with two beautiful and functional cutting boards (complete with my own pyrography pen design) and a lot of great memories.

Book in advance for an afternoon, or even a weekend workshop, their classes are outstanding. Very well organized, and safe too. It is also a delight to work alongside instructors who are not only knowledgeable but truly passionate about their craft.

So apparently, Meghan C and I are now social pariahs, since we have a baby.

We went to Ponzio's last weekend, because Meg's sister is OBSESSED with diners, and they don't have them in North Carolina.  We get there, and they stick us in what's obviously the 'families with loud children' area.  Since Paxton is only a month+ old, he's still in a carseat, and doesn't make much noise, but because of this, we needed a place to put him.  The tables are too small to fit four people, plus a carseat, and we couldn't slide him onto the bench seat.  The one table that had an extended bench was open, but wasn't cleaned, so they said we couldn't sit there.  Fine.  We perched him on a chair at the end of the booth.

Five minutes later, the host comes over and says that we need to move, as we're a 'fire hazard' then he proceeds to put us at a four-top table, with no additional room to put the baby.  Where did the baby end up?  In the aisle, in the same 'fire hazard' manner as before.  Whatever.  Let's freaking eat, I'm starving.

I ask the waiter for the lunch menu, as it was almost 11, and I don't like breakfast foods.  He says that most of the food won't be ready, as they hadn't prepped the vegetables.  Really?  It's nearly 11 AM!  You're a diner!  Anyway, he says he'll bring the lunch menu, then never returns.  When he does, the wife and I want Bloody Marys.  We order, they come out, and I ask for the lunch menu again.  He says he'll get it.  We wait longer.  He comes back and takes the order from Meg's sister and her fiancee, then asks me what I want.  I tell him that I want the lunch menu.  Now, he's got to go find one, which took another give minutes.  It's almost 11:30, at this point.  It finally comes, and I have three seconds to look over the menu before he bails on us again.  I order a chicken club sandwich.  It was terrible.  At least my bloody mary was good.

What I'm more annoyed about, and marking them down big time for, was the fact that they couldn't accommodate four adults with an infant, and we were hassled because we were a fire hazard.  All they had to do was clean off the booth with the extended bench, but no...that was too tough for them.

Johnson's is a nice spot to take the kids for any seasonal activity, but jeez, it's a racket, price-wise.  We took my son to do the Easter Egg hunt last week, and for a twenty minute hayride, as well as a three minute search for eggs, it was $16, for two adults and a child.  That didn't get you access to the animal farm area, or to the jungle gym, each of which has signs up that if you don't have a wristband, you'll be asked to leave.

The egg hunt itself was in a grove of trees, and they basically just took a couple hundred eggs of different colors, dumped them in the trees, by color, and told the kids to grab one of each color, then get their prize back.  Nice, but $16 nice?

The animal farm area looked nice from behind the fence, as did the jungle gym, but I'm not sure that they were worth paying the extra cash to get in, especially when there's a park with a huge jungle gym just a couple miles away.

It seems like there are a lot of very varied experiences and reviews of this place, but I thought it was solid, and as my first Nashville culinary experience, set a high bar.  We ordered the nachos, and I had their burger, which was advertised as being voted the best burger in Nashville.  It did not disappoint.  It was cooked rare, the way I asked, was well seasoned, and was just a damn good burger.  The nachos were pretty solid, albeit small.  I wish we'd have been there for some live music, but it was noon on a Friday, so it wasn't really prime time for bands with day jobs.

Prices weren't bad for drinks, service was prompt, and they have a nice beer selection.  I'll come back!

Had waxing done by Raine during a visit to New Orleans. She was professional, made me feel completely at ease, and did a great job. She also seemed very straightforward and down to earth, in a friendly way... like, if you didn't feel like making mindless small talk, you wouldn't need to, cause she's just doing her job, but if you wanna chat, she's also happy to do that. Basically, the type of esthetician you want!

I really liked the vibe of the place, too - super welcoming, NOT a bunch of over-manicured people staring down their noses at me as I rushed in with minimal makeup and with my hair still slightly wet. It also seemed like an efficient place, where you can get in and out and on with your life if you're just looking for a quick service (although I'm sure they could do pampering if that's what you're looking for, too. I was just there for the waxing).

Loved the live band on Saturday night! The trumpeter in particular was phenomenal at both trumpet and singing. As others have noted, this is around the corner from Bourbon Street and much classier than anything you'll find there.

Had fun dancing here late at night on a Wednesday. It wasn't very crowded, but my friend and I had fun since there were maybe 2 dozen other people there having fun. It's a dance bar in New Orleans and is exactly what you would expect in that category.

Very very impressed by my stay at Best Western. Although this was the most I have ever paid to stay at a Best Western, this is also the nicest Best Western that I have been too. The rooms had a very big layout, there was complimentary bottled water and fruit. I was on the bottom floor so my door faced the parking lot, and the sliding glass door faced the pool. The pool area was well maintained, the grass was healthy, and lots of beautiful plants. The only unusual thing about the hotel was the windows in the bathroom. The windows were high so people could not see in, but they were slated glass so you could hear everything outside. Although this is on the opposite side of downtown, I would stay here again if the price was right.

Amazing warm chocolate nut cookie when you check in, and they gave me another when we left. Super comfy bed, I wanted to go out and buy one for my house. I loved the Crabtree Evelyn bath products. Great location downtown, there was a subway stop directly outside the hotel. The only other strange thing was that our room was located by the ice machine, I have never heard such a loud machine. It sounded like a glass table was crashing outside our room every half hour. Overall great location/hotel/room but no free wifi, so minus 1 star!

Great location, very clean and updated. Free breakfast consisting of fruit and pastries from a local bakery to bring back to your room. There is no pool or outdoor community space. I found it very difficult to sleep on our king bed. We were given one pillow each, but they were extremely lumpy. For the size of the bed, it seems like we could have been provided with more than one pillow each. In addition, although I love shutters, there are some security/parking lights immediately outside of the room, so it never got completely dark, and light creeped in all night. I would recommend bringing an eye mask, so that you are not up all night. Also, when we got to our room we had a used toilet paper roll, which is fine, but we did not receive a back up new roll which it usually the standard when you have a used roll, and was annoying the next morning when there were only a few squares left.

I couldn't have been more excited to stumble upon this darling wonderland on our humid explorative trek around Nashville.

I felt like we were experiencing a sliver of San Francisco at Kellie's healthy delectable oasis. I especially appreciated all of the gluten free options on her menu. I don't have a gluten allergy, but i always find myself having an easier time digesting things, when things happen to be gluten free.

Our first meal here we had the  Mediterranean Vegetarian Sandwich (sans feta cheese) on fresh Gluten free bread - consisting of eggplant, roasted red pepper, sun dried tomato, and freshly made pesto, and the Spinach Salad (sans feta cheese) consisting of spinach, dried cranberries, sliced almonds & balsamic vinaigrette. Kellie even went out of her way to replace the feta cheese with some additional vegetables like tomatoes and cucumbers. Both were excellent, reasonably priced at $6.00-$7.00 and you could taste the love embedded in each. We washed down both with A Matter of Taste's cold refreshing fruit tea.

We were so impressed with our experience at A Matter of Taste that we decided to venture out here again the following day. We decided to try their regularly rotating lunch specials. We went with the Pumpkin Brittle and Watermelon adorned salad, as well as their Fish Tacos. The salad was outstanding. A Matter of Taste makes their own salad dressing and you could tell. The fish tacos were also very flavorful. 

A Matter of Taste's eating area is intimate, but if you take a look in the back you can see their sprawling immaculate kitchen where all of the magic happens.

If you're looking for quality and healthy food for reasonable prices - A Matter of Taste is outstanding. I recommend them wholeheartedly. My only regret is not sampling one of their gluten free desserts - ranging from moist looking cupcakes to large rockin' cookies.

Trust.

Bliss.

Absolute bliss.

Thanks to Katie B's gushing recommendation - we joined her, Farrah A, and Tomas R at Bacchanal for the most delightful afternoon - full of chilled rosé, stunning cheese plates, and beautiful music. 

Sitting in the comforts of the shade beneath elegant overhanging trees - while beaming faces - enjoyed the enclosed oasis of fantastic wine and wonderful company - I felt abundantly thankful.

Bacchanal is worth the Uber ride. It's non-pretentious, full of great vibes, and it's always graced by lulling live music.

I recommend coming on the earlier side- since I've heard it does get busier later on in the early evening. But definitely don't sleep on this New Orleans gem. You could easily spend all day here.

Trust.

Visiting from out of town and looking for a unique cafe for breakfast and to do some computer work, I happened upon this gem (with Yelp's help).  Warm, welcoming atmosphere and employees and great food.

I wish I had looked at these reviews before bringing my car to the Collision Repair center for service.  After leaving my car there for one week, I received it back with only half of the work done.  There evidently was a dispute over what the repair center and what my insurance company were supposed to do, and it does appear that my insurance company bears some responsibility.  My primary concern is that when I spoke directly with the person at reception about having the repairs done, she neglected to tell me that there was a problem and that she needed additional information. Instead she told me everything was all set. I think she was overwhelmed and just wanted to move on to the next waiting person.  A week later, after having been told the car was completely repaired, I went to pick it up to find only half the work done - and, had to find this out myself.  No one at the repair service told me that they only did one part of the repair.  Poor, expensive, assembly-line service is what you will get at this place.

Review Update:
As Shawn at Don Brown mentioned, after posting this review, I was immediately contacted by Pam in Customer Service.  Everything Shawn said is correct.  Pam handled things very professionally and discussed concrete ways they will implement to make the service experience more helpful and supportive of the customer.  I appreciated her call and realized that I had I requested to speak with her or someone in the Customer Service area, much of yesterday's frustration could have been alleviated.  Lesson learned.

So came here with a group after a long weekend looking for pho after partying, sadly it was not the pho we needed.  Compared to other pho spots the bowls were small, prices high, broth bland, tendon undercooked, no fish sauce, tea was an extra fee, the combo came with 1/2 a beef ball!!!! Add to this it took about 30 minutes to get all this to arrive at our table.

This place is legit!! The oyster pancake was just like the ones I had when I was staying in Taipei.  All the food was amazing! I highly advise anyone and everyone to come here.  Service was fast even with a packed house, the food came out quick and almost all at once.  For good fresh food in the down town area come here!!

The food was decent. I was starving after a long day of trail running so it's hard to tell. I know I didn't love it, but it was relatively inexpensive, the staff was nice, and the food came out quickly.

They also had a large screen television with soccer (er, football) playing.

I think the best part of this is likely the deck outside. It was packed when I got there. Inside, was pretty empty.

My wife and I spent the last month shopping for furniture at various stores across Indianapolis. Without a doubt, our best experience was with Urban Home. We found the perfect kitchen table (a pub table with 4 chairs and a bench) at a great price. More importantly, though, we loved the service we received (as we continued to come back in). 

We found several pieces of furniture at other locations, and before we'd purchase anything, we returned to U.H. On two occasions, the manager was able to get us a better deal than we could elsewhere (and the two times he couldn't, he helped us figure out which piece was a better deal even though we weren't buying from him). 

We just can't say enough about the personal service, the good nature of the employees, and the positive vibe we had in the store. (The store is set up so that it's easy to chat with other customers without it feeling weird.)

Our advice: Before you buy anything, make sure you stop by Urban Home.

This was the first stop on my South and Southwest camping trip. I specifically chose the KOA because I knew I could mess things up and they would be helpful.

Indeed they were. (Even as I set up my tent in the torrential rains that hit.) The facilities were first rate: clean showers, bathrooms, and a great little kitchen and washing machine area for those funky clothes days.

It's KOA: so you know there were about a billionty things for kids to do. The best part: directly across from Opryland. If you don't get why that's the best part...put down the computer, back away, and then run.

It's a bit out of the way for my trail running -- about 20 miles -- but definitely worth the stay.

The only annoyance: the campground lights sit along the tent grounds, which means there is a stream of light that you need to block out with the rainfly, even when it's not raining.

I can't say enough about Bob. Our kitchen sink clogged on Friday afternoon, and he came over to snake our drain. After removing the sludge from our pipe, we realized our basement drain was clogged as well. We called him on Saturday morning, and he came over to fix that as well. With no hassle and without breaking the bank, we had a fully functioning house again. I can't say enough about Bob and his assistants. Wonderful people, and wonderful work.

I love this hotel.  I was there there last weekend, and last month... at their restaurant to scope the whole place out for an upcoming event/intimate meeting. I usually do Hotel Monteleone  but Aces popped out to me because of their hipster feel (which is exactly what I've been looking for!).  Room was cool and was barely able to strum some chords on an acoustic guitar but reminiscent of my earlier years. Loved the menu at their restaurant and... absolutely loved "Church".   His service, quick wit and charm made my colleagues and I's evening at the bar. And while our servers have always been great at Aces, Church was the one who made us feel at home and welcomed. He was a quick friend to us. Not pretentious. I went up to the bar, asked for something unusual and he went out of his way more than expected. We wound up staying longer because of him. Talk about CX when we are writing about a white paper on customer experience. I would definitely use Aces for an upcoming event as long as Church was there making sure things happen. He is a gem and so is Aces. Thank you

Super disappointed. Came back to possibly host a banker event at Ace and found out that they had let their best person, " Church" go. This Gen Z manager was so full of their ego they totally missed what good customer service is all about. Not listening to my needs. Expecting me to bed over backwards. Whatever. If anyone knows where "Church" went or where I can find exceptional service, please DM me. It never ceases to amaze me how much egos get in the way. I am so disappointed in Ace's poor decisions as management has no clue. 

Can I give them less than one star?

Love Flanagans!

Some of the beat bar food. Great crowd.  Fun to have the ghost tours for those of us outsiders.  And....the couple of times I've been there I've had a serious crush on the bartender, Church.
