Not a place to miss if you're living in or visiting NOLA.

Philadelphia is gritty, from the surroundings to the people. Phillies are dedicated fans and it defiantly showed. They came out hours before the game and sat in the rain til it started. We watched the Phillies vs the Washington Nationals on Monday, May 21st. It was funny routing for the Nationals the day before. We arrived over two hours early and they had already opened up a limited section of the park. We got a drink at Harry The K's the restaurant in left field named after Hall of Fame broadcaster Harry Kalas. You can sit and watch the full game there as long as you keep buying. We watched the Phillies batting practice and walked around the park as it opened. We had seats on the very top level (4 levels!) and it was high up there, still a great seat...but almost a touch of vertigo. The whole stadium felt huge. Capacity 43,651, but it felt like 50+

The video board in left field was so clear and massive, apparently it's the largest HD screen in the National League.  It also wouldn't be Philly without a replica Liberty Bell.  It "rings" and lights up after Philly home runs and wins. Unfortunately, we didn't see either. The Nats won. Another Philadelphia quirk is that their bullpens are in the outfield amongst the fans. When they first opened in 2004 the Phillies bullpen was closest to the fans and after Philly fans booed their own pitchers (these are the same fans that booed Santa Claus) they switched to have the visitors section closer for heckling.

The mascot always needs mentioning. Its rates high on my husbands list. The Phillie  Phanatic....a green beakish creature. The Phanatic has been named the best mascot before and he did not disappoint. He was absolutely hilarious. He came out with a full rain suit on when it began to sprinkle. He mimicked and danced with middle school cheerleaders. There are also videos of him traveling to the Galapagos Islands...his birthplace.

All in all, the stadium might not have a beautiful backdrop of the city, but it was still a beautiful park.  Its very open and you can see the game the entire time you walk around the park.  There were so many options for food (love the cheesesteakes!) and the craft beer was endless. You had to search for any macro beers if you wanted. We were highly impressed with the Philly beer scene.  Philly really was a passionate town about its sports, beer and food.

Quick and super friendly. Emily was super helpful with our order. The burgers were cooked just right and our order of fries and onion rings were just the right amount of crisp. Overall, this was a great experience.
Total jerks - completely rude to our large group and openly mocked us to our faces. We left immediately. I've never been so insulted - do not go here.

So apparently I visited Posh on the wrong day because there were not $9 suede boots like the ones Caitlin D snagged...lucky gal.  I didn't happen to snag any shoes, but that's  probably because I didn't save any room in my suitcase for yet another pair of shoes...even shoes as cool and funky as the ones at Posh.  If I ever do make it back to Nashville I'll be sure to save some room in the suitcase for a stop at Posh!

It's your typical country bar, but considering I never go to country bars in Chicago I thought it was great! My friend had her rehearsal dinner here and it was a blast. A low key atmosphere, BBQ food that didn't do much for me (but my fiance and others seemed happy), and most importantly fabulous service (I had a drink in my hand at all times).

I wasn't feeling well... and if I had my choice it would have been a matzo ball soup type of night. Or I may have just skipped dinner and gone straight to bed, but felt like I needed to eat something while pregnant. 

My colleague and I opted for dinner at Wildflower Grill, conveniently located within the Matrix Hotel we were staying at. We made our way downstairs and were seated immediately (no reservations necessary on a Tues night).  

By no fault of Wildflower Grill, but thanks to my stuffed up nose, there wasn't much on the menu that sounded appealing, but I finally settled on a caesar salad. And of course I couldn't pass up on ordering the bread appetizer that so many yelpers raved about.  Both hit the spot, especially the very warm bread that practically melted in my mouth.

I'm sure there's even better food on the menu that my bread and salad, but I"ll have to wait until my next trip to Edmonton when hopefully I'm feeling 100%.

Thank you Comcast Wall for keeping us entertained for 3 hrs while working the check-in table at the fabulous Yelp Spring Feastival. Fortunately, the Philadelphia yelpers are one cool bunch so getting bored wasn't a problem, but when have to sit at a table for 3 hrs staring at a wall of a building it's pretty awesome if there's a show occurring right on that wall.

This is one cool wall! You'd think I'd be sick of watching it after 3 hrs, but not so much the case (maybe just a bit dizzy).  I do still question the tourists I watched stare at the wall for several hrs at a time. Yes, it was a rainy day in Philly, but surely there's cooler stuff to do than spend a day staring at a wall even as awesome as this one.

Traveling with a bad cold is not fun...I was totally that person full of germs that I typically avoid on planes. Fortunately once I arrived in Edmonton (after passing my germs to everyone on the plane) the Matrix Hotel provided me with a clean spacious room and a comfortable bed so I could get a little bit of rest during my short trip.

Overall, I liked this hotel and wouldn't definitely stay here again. My colleague and I were in town to do interviews and they have a nice lounge upstairs that was the perfect spot for them (and it helped that it was empty too). 

It's also centrally located near lots of restaurants, shops and more...so there's no need to rent a car in what I believe is typically a driving city.

The restaurant downstairs was also solid if you happen to visit during one of Edmonton's infamous cold winters.

3.50 stars.  

Gabby's wasn't open.  I knew that.  Neither was Rotier's.  But my handy Yelp app had assured me that Fido's was open.  Imagine the disappointment when I realized there was a very real possibility that no burgers would happen on this trip down to the Deep South.  Would I really have to wait two more weeks when I would find solace in East Texas?   

"We can try Burger up," I mentioned.  

"Why don't you just call them?" hissed the appropriately nicknamed Viper.  

True.  We didn't have to keep driving around aimlessly.  So I call Burger Up, and a very pleasant, sweet voice assures me they are indeed open.  

Viper: "What was her name?  She sounded hot."
  
Me: "Paige."

Viper: "Yeah, she's definitely hot.  Have you ever met an unattractive Paige?"

Me: "Good point.  At least we have that going for us."

Paige was indeed attractive, but this review isn't about a photogenic individual who happens to work at Burger Up.  It's about what ended up being a visit to our fourth choice for burgers in Nashville.  

Burger Up follows a national trend towards upscale burgers.  My particular order consisted of a medium rare patty served with aged cheddar, Benton's bacon (very good), and ketchup served on an artisan bun.  Basically, it was a gussied up bacon cheeseburger, but it was a rather tasty one.  My major complaint is that I wish the actual meat itself exhibited more flavor.  Having said that, the burger was cooked properly and the flavors worked well together.  I ordered some wilted spinach on the side (mediocre) and truffle fries.  Let's talk about those truffle fries for a bit.  I know more people are apparently into the sweet potato fries here, but I think they are missing the boat.  Burger Up's truffle tries have pleasant aroma, taste great, and are the perfect texture for soaking up oil.  If you are on a diet, it is true you should skip these delightful fries.  But if that were the case, why are you at a burger joint in the first place?  Seriously, if you get nothing else out of my review, please do yourself a favor and order the truffle fries.  

Burger Up also boast an interesting beer menu with semi-obscure breweries from the Deep South included in the list.  I tried a pecan-infused amber from Mississippi - not bad.  I could imagine Burger Up could be a decent place to drink for a bit after eating.  

If I attended Vanderbilt, I would probably go here on a moderately frequent basis.  If you want a change from the dive bar hamburger, Burger Up is a decent change of pace.

3.50 stars.  I was told to go here for the shrimp and grillades (grits) and fried chicken, but I ended up loving the gumbo more than anything.  Located in Mid-City, Li'l Dizzy's is a cozy diner serving up an all you can eat breakfast/lunch consisting of fried chicken, trout, shrimp creole, rice & beans, grits, gumbo, omelettes made to order, fruit, and maybe a few other items as well.  It was all pretty standard until I reached the gumbo.  

Li'l Dizzy's gumbo is heavenly.  They don't hold back on either the sausage or the seafood as you have generous cuts of andouille sausage and crab legs in the wonderfully thick dark brown soup.  They got the flavor so perfect I felt no need to add any tabasco to my order.  I'd definitely come back here for the gumbo.  

Overall, you have plenty of options for breakfast/lunch in this city, and Li'l Dizzy's is a good one if you are in Mid-City.  It's a great option if you just want a cup of gumbo.

Everything here is top notch. Woodfired pizza at its best. Everything is sourced and sustainably produced. Everything on the menu is special somehow. Try the meatballs, salads, but get there before Jimmy or you won't get any meatballs. You can't go wrong here.

If you want great sushi, noodles, or Japanese fusion food. You have found the right place. The interior is very mod and cool, service is spectacular. The food is great with decent portion sizes. I had the udon bowl which was enough for a whole meal by its self, it was only $17. They have a great full bar with imaginative Asian inspired cocktails. I had a local IPA which was only $5. I could see if you get a bunch of small plates you could get in trouble but worth it. Great place for a special date night without breaking the bank. Will definitely go back.

I hate to do it, but the service was so egregious. I feel I must so maybe the owners whose hard earned money is going down the drain can step in before its too late.  I have had two bad experiences here. Whoever is managing this place doesn't know what they are doing. It's like the staff is not managed at all.
 
 Let me help you POW, if a customer is staring at you and it looks like they need something, just make eye contact and say "Just a minute, sorry we are very busy." This accomplishes two things, first lets the customer know you acknowledged their presence and the customer will wait longer knowing they will eventually get helped, and probably tip better. So the staff should take off the blinders and pay attention to the customers. Want to be even better, if the staff notices a customer looks like they need something and they are not your table go ahead and offer to get their server or relay something to them, again not hard. I would recommend some staff changes starting with that smart mouthed brown haired lady bartender before your business goes under. I would not hurt to have a manager there at your prime times.
 
  In closing the pizza, is not as good as when it was Wood Fired Pizza. The crust is sub-par and the pizza doesn't taste fresh, it's disappointing. The beer selection is not as good as the previous ownership. The service is definitely not as good a the previous iteration, which was a pretty low bar.

i have been going here since 1996, and it gets better every time I go. There is just too much to list, and everything is good. If you are in St Petersburg do yourself a favor and stop by.  My favorite sandwich is the Hot Italian. I also like to grocery shop for pastas, meats, cheeses, beers, wines, bread, coffee, and deserts.

This is their archive that holds many thousands of records. They have everything here from Edison cylinders, 78s,45s, and LPs. I can spend hours here. They bring in more vinyl every day. A lot of vinyl is sold over the internet and people come from all around the world to browse through the stacks. They will even let you listen to the record before you buy it. I have been going here since 96.
Great place for LP shopping even great for CDs. They have an archive about six blocks away.
I had a decent meal here. The prices were decent and the was great. Comfort soul food all the way. Definitely going back.
Great service, great subs, and award winning cubans. The Chicago beef(Italian Beef) is the best in the area.

Simply the best European style beer bar in Tampa. On of the best curated beer selections around, served in the proper glassware. Superb selection of limited release micro brews. What Berns is to wine the Independent is to beer.  Add the great Cafe that has a pear and gouda panini you have a complete evening. Outside seating, cool vibe, cant get enough on this place when in Tampa.

Lots of pretty people, great drinks, and a great beer selection. The do also sell food, imaginative small plates. A little pricey, but worth it. Always a great place to people watch for pretty ladies.

Bandit coffee is the next step in the evolution of the coffee scene in St Petersburg. The Slayer espresso machine, which is the perfect machine for single origin espressos. They are well equipped to deliver coffee in other forms, pour over,  cold brew, and good old American drip. Pushing five different single origin locally roasted coffees. They deliver without being pretentious or snotty. Minimalist, interior with lots of natural light from the glass wall at the front of the store. Trendy, hipster music and minimal to very little food. Great place to hang with friends for an after lunch coffee.

I like the food, the drinks and their wine and beer selections are great. I have been here three times and every time the service by the bartenders has been terrible. I have sat at the bar to watch bartenders walking by you like their wearing blinders. I was not there at a prime time maybe eight people sitting at the bar. The bartender seemed more interested in her conversation with her friend.  This is due to either poor training of the bartender or very poor attitude the bartender. Either one is unforgivable.  Let me help you, if a patron comes to the bar to get a drink and you're busy, acknowledge them so they know you saw them. Patrons will wait longer and be happier(tip better) if you at least acknowledge them. Even if you just make eye contact and tell them it will be just a minute. It's not hard. I wouldn't recommend this place, unless you enjoy being ignored or treated like a second-class citizen.

I like this place, great ambience, great food, and reasonable prices. They make everything in house but the tortillas for the nachos. The interior is done really well, almost like an artist owns the place. The staff was excellent as well the service top notch. 
 The only hang up I have with this place is really not the restaurant's fault. I went there for lunch and I pulled into the parking lot while talking on my cell phone on a business call(I know I shouldn't do that). While still on the phone I got out of the car and was greeted by someone wanting money. Since I didn't get off my phone and ignored him, he cursed at me so loudly the person on the phone asked where I was at. I made sure to sit inside where I could see my car out the glass block windows. I mentioned it to the staff. Then as I was leaving someone else came up looking for money. I just jumped in my car and drove off while receiving a glare because I didn't stick around to hear what I am sure was a great story of tragedy and need. This place is in a very rough side of town, which doesn't bother me. I would never let my girlfriend go here by herself, especially at night.

Authentic Mexican food on the cheap. Nestled in the back of a Mexican grocery store. Great daily specials Pazole soup, gorditas, tortas, and great tacos on home made tortillas.  Not great ambiance but the food and the prices make up for it.

Only someone who understands Cincinnati Chili will "get" this place. If not, they're know for a mild, uniquely spiced chili served on spaghetti with a mound of Cheddar cheese on top. It can be addictive so be careful. Start out with a regular way and work your way up.

The gold standard for ramen in St Pete. They also have Izakaya(think Japanese tapas) and yakitori(small skewers). Killer sake selection and a great mixed drink set up. Whether you just want a bowl of ramen or a full meal this is a great place.

Buddy Brew serves the best cup of coffee in Tampa. It's an artisanal micro roaster, and pure coffee house; it's all about the coffee, with simple food choices, some baked goods and poached eggs on toast. The seating is somewhat limited, however, and they have a wobbly table. They do have WiFi. Because they roast their own coffee, you have many choices of beans-- from their espresso roast to single origin roasts. A myriad of brewing methods include: dialed-in espresso, pour-overs, vacu-pots, aeropress, french press, iced and Chemex -- just  to name a few. Give the cortado a shot or try a single origin pour-over and find your bean. If you're looking for frapuccinos or caffeinated milkshakes, keep rolling down the street to Stardookies. However, if you are like me you'll drive past Stardookies and pay little more for a really good cup of coffee.

What a fun place. I love Reef Donkey pale ale so this is a good fit for me. Great fun food with a large menu, plenty of good craft beers including many guest taps in addition to their already award winning line up. They have the proper glassware for the beer they serve(this is my pet peeve). Very cool outside seating and bar area. In addition they have a real brick pizza oven. Great for groups as there is something for everyone, from chops to pizza and calzones. Worth the drive.
Great imaginative menu with out breaking the bank

Crazy good and proud of it. Imaginative entrees and a well planned menu. They even have a Pittsburg option for their grilled entrees.  Everything is a winner here from starters to the dessert. It's pricey, but they bring it. Service was great. A couple of quips. I don't like when I am the first to arrive for our reservation without my party and they ask me to wait at the bar and there are no seats at the bar, and I see plenty of open tables. They have a great beer selection, but I don't enjoy drinking a good beer out of a can shaped glass. The glass is a novelty the does nothing to enhance the beer. If you are going to serve good beer have the right glass.  Free valet parking on the 1st ave. south side of the building.

I have been going here for years. This place is the only place in Tampa to get Grill at your table Korean BBQ. The marinated short ribs are a must, you cook them at your table then make your own lettuce wraps with them. They bring you plenty of sides including soup and egg custard. There will hardly be any room at the table they bring you so many sides. My only issue with them is if two people go they bring both of you one bowl of soup and one custard to split. I don't mind this when going with my better half. The problem I have is when we go with another couple and they bring one soup and one custard for the whole table(I am told this is very Korean). This is kind of gross having people double dip their spoons into my soup. Call me soup possessive but I only want to share a bowl of soup with my spouse not my buddy Doug. I like Doug just not that way.  They are usually very accommodating and will bring a second set, but you will have to ask for it. Don't let this deter you from a great evening and the price is reasonable because its all inclusive. They will even bring you more sides, rice, and lettuce if you would like.

Home made tortillas, excellent choice of fillings, and home made salsas combine to make this a great little taco spot. Its in the back of  a small Mexican grocery store. The ventilation is poor so your clothes might smell like tacos when you get back to work, but its worth it.

Great food and excellent happy hour. 
Need to make a reservation but worth trying this restaurant for their seafood and Cajun food. 
I thought they had the best gumbo and jalapeño grits. 
The size was a perfect portion. I'm going back for their burger which looked great and almost everyone ordered it. 

Customer service was good . Couldn't really  tell who my server was but it seemed like everybody helped each other out in the restaurant so flagging down a random server didn't really matter they were happy to assist you.
Super yummy cupcakes! You must try the sweet potato cupcake! Do not sleep on it! I left with a box of different kinds to taste but that was my fav!!!

Always trying to live up to my "+1 extraordinaire" role, I was Mikey I.'s +1 to his official Uwishunu review of London Grill.  Dimly lit inside, the place tied together almost perfectly the feeling of neighborhood bar and nice restaurant. We both got the customer appreciation 'surf & turf' special ($19 for the meal); Mikey got filet, I got lobster. The special includes a starter salad, entree, and delicious chocolate mousse dessert, and they have $5 glasses of wine to pair with your meal.  All in all it was great food, EXCELLENT service, and a nice atmosphere.

Pistachio gelato ! Limoncello sorbet ! Oh, the varieties. All of which are delicious. 

The service is always fantastic, no matter what time of day we happen to drop by.

It's also always clean... Floors, windows, all.

Service is great here. Everybody who waited on us (which looked to be like everyone who worked there...) were very friendly and helpful. 

Ambiance was comfortable, and the decor is cute, trendy, contemporary. 

Food, is where I have a few complaints. The appetizers we ordered were fantastic. No issues there. Rose sangria was mediocre at best. But the Chili Rellenos I ordered ? It was an entire onion, sautéed with mushrooms, and drenched in what seemed to be canned marinara... What chili ? The stem that was at one end of the skillet ?? Or the slight hint of spice with an overwhelming taste of spaghetti sauce? It was all over the place, and I obviously missed their "concept" of that dish. I guess I liked their rice. My friend's Carne Asada tacos were really dry, that even her 6 year old complained about it. We liked their salsa...

I would come back for the appetizers. Thankfully, they were satisfying enough to not bomb the whole idea of this place as a dinner option. 

Sadface. I was hoping this place would've been a total hit, after seeing everyone's reviews.

I don't know why I've never written a review for this place? I must have just gotten lazy.

We've been coming here since day one. It's our no-fail-get-the-day-started place. There hasn't been a single visit that wasn't fan-tab-u-lous! Brunch is my favorite (I'll be honest, I never make it to "breakfast").

Whether you're coming for one, two, or ten (okay, maybe not too many because this location isn't that big), this place will meet expectations. I feel confident in stating that EVERYTHING on the menu is superb, because ... I've tried them all. From starters, to main dishes, sides, pastries, and DRINKS ! My favorites have to be... the grilled cheese, cast iron duck confit (the portions are sometimes a littleee meager, but it's delicious regardless), and french toast. Just pick something though. You'll be fine. 

The only pain is the wait time. Depending on the day, there's surely to be a wait.

Staff is always friendly and able. Decor is trendy and bright. And mimosas... Yes, get a mimosa. Thank me later.

My boyfriend & I stumbled upon this cart during a food truck round up. Were we glad we did ! It just so happens, he knows the owner of the cart as well, so we got to try the churros for free. (; 

Let me tell you, I'm picky when it comes to my churros. It's one of the main things I look forward to at theme parks! Fat kid tendencies, guilty as charged. So trust me, I would've just not written a review if I wasn't a fan.

These were AMAZING when they were fresh, and still FABulous when we ate the rest at home. The dough is made fresh daily, so you don't have that freezer taste that just kills me. The batch we had were perfectly crispy and didn't taste oily. They had the perfect amount of sugar and cinnamon so that they were sweet, but wasn't layered thicker than the dough itself. The dough texture if what makes it or breaks it for me. These were crispy and flaky, but still soft and moist inside. I'm drooling as I'm describing it right now...

Terrible for diets and figure watchers, because you really can't just eat one... Sorry, I'm really not that sorry. I'd eat the whole bag if I didn't HAVE to share. ;) Take them home and treat yourself with a scoop or two (or four) of vanilla ice cream. You'll thank me later.

I believe he said they were usually located next to the Guero on Grant, but they do go to the food truck round ups too. Go go go !

I suggested this place to my mother based on it's yelp reviews. Boy, was THAT a mistake !

It's not as clean as everyone claims it to be, and it's pretty run-down looking compared to other shops in the area.

My mom said that the tech kept raving about how she's been doing nails for like 9 years.... Well, lady, I'm surprised you still have a job. 

All she went in for was a fill. Simple, quick, nothing dramatic. Well, it took about 50 minutes all together, which is ridiculous. Also, the end result looked as if it was the person's FIRST TIME doing fills. Unevenness, gaps, just a horrid job. To top it off, they're a total rip off. My mom didn't have anymore time to waste to stick around and complain. But, we'll definitely never be back OR recommend them to anyone. 

We used to do nails. I'm not criticizing because I think I'm better. I'm knocking you off your pedestal because you plain & simply suck. 

Stop boasting & start practicing.

Great location!  We asked for a quiet room and actually got one!  The room was really clean.  The bed was a little lumpy but after we drank a few hurricanes we didn't notice.  Overall we were very happy with our stay

St. Francis has the last chance mass for St. Louis.  Paired with SLU, their Sunday 10PM mass is packed with tons of college students atoning for the weekend.  The church itself is beautiful.  The priests are fairly orthodox too, despite their more liberal Jesuit background.  The downside is that its really loud before mass.  And despite being packed and having a beautiful choir, the participation during mass is something to be desired.  And they sing "Go make a difference" at the end of every mass.  Worst song ever... hippies...Blech...

If you are going to drop over $200 on a fun night out, you might as well treat yourself to an amazing experience.  Prime 108 is an incredible restaurant.  If it weren't for the influence of country music, I would've thought that I was in some posh LA restaurant.  

The Filet was perfect, the lobster and cheese mac was just like I had it in Boston and the Popcorn chicken was about as far from the KFC version as LA is from Nashville.

Prime 108 is pricey, but incredible.

I am not a touchy-feely-aura-voodoo-new age type person despite being from California or having Louisiana lineage.  However, this place had a bad vibe.  


The hostess was nice. She sat me, my friend and her dog on the patio. About 5 minutes later she apologizes for the waiter not having approached us yet and stated she would remind him.  Another 10 minutes passed and our waiter charged the table chastising us for having sat ourselves.  I explained that the hostess had sat us.  At that point we should have left.  We still didn't have menus, nor did the table next to us who had been there before we arrived.

The band was fine.  The decor was nifty. The patio was lovely, even at night.

Our server's attitude did not improve, nor did the frequency of his visits to any of the tables.  Parts of our order were missing or incorrect or far from tasty.  My pal had a Mojito assuming it would be fabulous given the name of the establishment.  In fact, that was the only thing that was NOT tasty.  The rest of the meal was tasty enough for her to return the next evening.  She informed me that despite a different wait she had bad vibes and a not so nifty experience but I'll let her review it.

I do not see myself returning here on my next visit.

To quote a wise lolcat, "do not want."

Beautiful restaurant. Small. It was cold OUTSIDE & they kept the a/c on INSIDE? I asked three times to turn off a/c & they said they could not b/c it's from the hotel???Whatever....
The prices are high 
Quality is good
Gumbo was the best I've had so far in NoLa with mussels, Okra & shrimp ....
The shrimp & grits for $24 had 6 shrimp hmmmmm??? It was good but not really better then the S&G I had for 1/2 the price. I was here as 3pm hit and the oysters dropped from $16 dozen down to $6. They were local but not as consistent as ice had elsewhere. Price was AWESOME but I'd rather pay literally a few dollars more for more consistent oysters. 
I really wanted to like the place, but....
The cold bothered us
The waiter never refilled my water even after asking
And he didn't clean my table of Galen food until asked...
Poor service (Alex)
:-((

Pralines!!!!! Sweet!!!!!
no bargains
just very sweeeet food
See fresh pralines being made.
They close early

The best part about this place is the fans.  Union fans live up to the reputation of Philadelphia fans: an intense, energetic bunch.  The Sons of Ben have come up with quite a collection of songs in such a short team life.  Sit anywhere near the supporters section (or on the complete opposite side of the pitch) and you'll learn them in no time.  

The stadium itself is located somewhere you couldn't otherwise pay me to go to.  Easiest way to make money off of parking: put your stadium somewhere scary.  Driving to the lots is why I knocked off a star.  There is a lack of signage from the highway itself into the specific lots.  I wasn't sure if I was driving to be raped and dismembered or to park for a soccer match.  The lots themselves are well organized and illuminated, and once within sight of the stadium I didn't feel as though I was going to be violated.  

Signage within and around the stadium itself was easy.  We found the proper gate and got into our seats without any difficulty.  The stadium is comfortable, modern, and cozy.  The sight lines are great all around.  Also all around: concessions and rest rooms!  It was very well-designed, and well worth a trip to cheer on the U!

Doop.

I will never use another florist in Philadelphia. 

I live out-of-town now, so I am unable to pick out flowers in person when I send them back home now.  Thank you, Yelp, for sending me to Pure this year!!  For the same price I spent on an internet florist last year, I got something totally unique, completely incredible, and worthy of my mom!  

My mother received her birthday flowers today, and I was blown away via iPhone photo. I can only imagine just how gorgeous they are in person!  I had asked the designer on the phone to send something bright, oranges and yellows, that exudes happiness and makes you want to do a little dance when you see them.  To be perfectly honest, that is EXACTLY what I did when I received the photo of them.  I'm an only child, so my mom is pretty stoked on anything I do, but hearing the overwhelming happiness in her voice on the phone when she talked about the flowers was next level.  They are absolutely perfect.  I wish I could go hug whomever made them.  THANK YOU!

Seriously, using another floral designer would be a huge mistake/future regret, dear Philadelphia person searching for a florist reading this review.

Favorite happy hour spot in SB.

Brings out all the best people for all your favorite games.

And no, not a typo, they have ping pong AND beer pong.  The bartenders are great and every one there is having a really good time.

It may help that the pitchers of beer are such a great deal.

Great pub. packed on a Friday but not so much you couldn't order a drink quickly. Great specials, solid mixed drinks, and a shocking palatable "AMF". Definitely a good place to bring a small group of drunken revelers.

if you visiting Indy, you have a few options: the backyard BBQ and pool party, the downtown scene, or the college-bar-esque atmosphere that is Broad Ripple.*

Monkey's Tale is right in the middle, has great karaoke outside, a huge deck area, cheap drinks (on par for Indy but for those of us accustomed to LA, NYC, SF, and/or Miami, you wouldn't be surprised to hear that it had one friend HUGGING a waitress thinking she'd significantly discounted our tab)

The clientele are pretty solid, so much so that one turned out to be a bartender at a place nearby which resulted in a lock-in and lots of complimentary drinks.

Would I go back? Absolutely.

*note: many locals will slur "broad ripple" (two words) into one gelatinous multisyllabic blurb that almost sounds like the name of a terrible strip club, but it's two words and in fact a rather innocent sounding Midwestern-type name.

There is no party quiet like the Brass-a-holics at Blue Nile on a Saturday night.

Truly the brass band for the 21st century.  I was blown away, never stopped dancing, and even got their card from the manager.

This is a band you'd fly out for a wedding or birthday.

Blue Nile is solid and worth the cover. drinks are cheap, plenty of room to move, great crowd. I have many favorites in Frenchmen (dba, spotted cat, etc.) but Blue Nile is in the top two without a doubt.

if a place offers a "drink for free" option for anyone brave enough to walk in naked (and remain that way), you pretty much know what you are getting into.

but late night, this place, if you can get there, is a blast.

If you hate American coffee (especially Starbucks) but shy away from gut-scortching Italian espresso, this place is for you.  If I lived in Philly, this place alone would convert me back to being a coffee drinker.

it's kind of like getting hooked on Motrin 800's...  
giving them up because you just we're "feeling it" any more...
and then having someone walk in and hand you a Percocet 10/350.

(I hurt myself a lot.  that was the best analogy I could come up with)

Just calling it what it is, Tonic is like fishing a koi pond with a shrimping net. If you don't catch something, your net must have some serious holes in it. 

Great music. Lots of people. Lots of space outside (Perhaps a little cramped at times on the dance floor, but nothing to complain about at all) 

The service is quick (it helps to bring people who work next door and at surrounding bars and restaurants) and you won't go home disappointed.

Not to be missed.

Definitely get there early for batting practice, and for those Tony Luke cheese steaks (the line behind us hit over 60 people, and it was still 90 minutes til the Nat'l Anthem).  Mine is Whiz, Wit and a side of the Broccoli Rabe.

The Schmidter is disgustingly good (just don't ask what's actually IN this sandwich) and they have Blue Moon over there and a short line.

Definitely worth the money for the Diamond Club.  behind the plate, comfortable seats, great (and relatively cheep) bar inside, great food, and access to all the fun stuff like the Hall of Fame on the 2nd level.

if you're a baseball fan, or like history, definitely check it out (they have an original 1889 scorecard).

Jersey Shore meets Reno. 

Surprisingly fun and great dancing (the band was going off, great dancing, strong drinks).

Some interesting people watching too.

As for the food, skip it. tried a few apps friends ordered and no one was enjoying them (they actually screwed up fried calamari)
always a stop on my Reno pub and bar crawl.  always.

Started at the bar while they set up the table at the restaurant. 

Sure, we could have waited around, but we would have missed out on the live country music, dancing, stiff drinks and the smell of amazing homemade chili (behind the bar). 

I ordered the baby-back ribs per the recommendation of the waiter and I was very impressed. Also had a bit of the duck which was equally good. 

Great service and great appetizers (got the platter/sampler). Definitely bring your appetite though. they don't skimp on the portions. 

Looking forward to coming back soon.

No question this place has some incredible rolls and sashimi.  Definitely the place you go for the creative and unorthodox (not for the same-old-same-old sushi).  

there are 200 items on the menu and I've only had the pleasure of 10 of them.  but as I return, I will expand this review (for now, anything with habanero sauce is to die for and the baked green lip mussels are killer...but be careful, they come in groups  of five so I hope you know how to share "awesomeness").

god bless my girlfriend for introducing me to this place.  can't wait to go back for the oysters (which, fyi, can run out if you get there too late!)

I've apparently been missing out on an entire dimension of what it means to be an American.

"Thank you" to the 100th Anniversary of the Indy 500 for getting me up to speed (at around 230 mph).

Not only is this a blast to go to the night before (the Speedway gas station and liquor store across the street are by far the biggest party i could ever imagine at a gas station) but the event itself is ridiculous, regardless of where you sit.

Courtesy of some amazing friends, we watched 50 laps from the first row facing the pits (bag or Church's Chicken in one hand, Jeremiah Weed cans in the other), the last 30 from the first row the press box, Box 8, and got a first class tour of the infield (ps: the snake pit in turn 3 is unfortunately no longer what it once was) in between.

never have a seen such debauchery and fun WITHOUT people causing a problem. heck, even with ridiculous traffic, i never heard a car horn outside. Yeah, the Midwest is in a class all it's own.

as for getting there, DO NOT take the interstate. find a local who knows the back roads and you will get there in minutes as opposed to hours.

Will I be back? heck yeah. See you all next Memorial Day weekend.

the Kamehameha nachos are possibly the best nachos I've ever had.

dear lord.

can be a bit of wait with a group but WELL worth it.

i don't know anyone in our group who didn't walk away stuffed.

this is a HAPPY HOUR review only.

After a long day of baseball at the beach, we ordered every thing from the happy hour menu (or just about).  From the mahi mahi tacos to the ahi poke and about a dozen oyster shooters, everything was great.  No complaints. 

Not a place to go if you are looking for a happy hour "scene" (definitely an older crowd) which is why we picked this place for food, and not state street.

I still can't understand the appeal. 

The TV's are horribly placed so more than likely, you will be directly under your team's broadcast (or in a blind-spot). 

For as cute as the hostesses are (for the most part), the service is unsurprisingly poor. 

I'd tell you what we think of the host (dude), but I'm a good Christian. 

And the place smells horrible. So you have to sit outside. Except there is a wait and/or you have to order food and your whole party must be there, even if you have a party of three at a four person table and someone calls you last minute because they got off work early and wants to meet up.

I had to organize a party for a student organization end-of-conference celebration.  This is an annual event. I cannot thank Maison enough.  Justin and his team helped me put together an awesome party for 300 in the upstairs loft area, and worked with my budget. It included some appetizers, well drinks, and a DJ spinning some kickass tunes. Everyone who attended told me it was the best party they had been to of all the year's they've been to the conference, and I really did very little. It was all Maison! They were well fed, and their thirsts were quenched. Thanks for making me look good!  

This venue is fantastic--the upstairs loft area seems like it has all these secret spaces you can hide away in or be in the center of it all. Meanwhile, the downstairs bar area seemed quieter, but lively as well.

***No Problem***

Three months later and I still think of this store so fondly.... if only you were closer to me!  I happened to pop in on a hot day in June, just winding down from a conference.  This is an adorable little knitting boutique that has very knowledgeable, *unpretentious* staff working there.  I highlight "unpretentious" because I find most knitting boutique stores in Vancouver are not very friendly to new knitters.  

These ladies helped me right away.  I told them I was new, and that I wanted to knit a baby blanket, and they even had the book with the pattern I wanted to use.  I told them that I didn't want to use the expensive yarn suggested in the book, and that I wanted it to be soft, but washable.  This was absolutely no problem for the sales lady helping me. And she helped me with a smile on her face, not wincing that I didn't buy a higher quality peruvian alpaca wool yarn or something like it. She found me a nice, soft nylon acrylic blend that she said would be durable without getting to many pils after washing. I told her I wanted to use 2 colours and make a striped pattern--no problem! She even showed me (read: demonstrated) how I could do this the easiest way! 

I couldn't be more grateful that I stepped inside this store! I would love to go back to NOLA just for this store! Thank you, thank you, thank you Quarter Stitch!!

My fiance took me to R2L for my birthday. I cannot speak more highly of the ambiance of this restaurant! Even on a cloudy and rainy night, the view was to die for! Why aren't there more restaurants like this in the city?! All of the tables were spaced far apart from one another... unlike most places where they try to squeeze as many tables in as possible and you feel like you're sharing your dinner with the strangers next to you! The seats were comfy couches and perfectly placed around the room to face the windows overlooking the city.  

To start our meal we ordered a Caesar salad and the crab cake appetizer. The salad was VERY salty and the crab cake was only so-so (not a whole lot of crab). For our meals, he ordered the fillet and I got the stripped bass. The fillet was VERY good and perfectly prepared. My striped bass had a great flavor to it! It was pared with a scallop, some mixed veggies, and a square unknown fatty substance. I later looked over the menu description and realized that was the "fresh bacon"! It was a good 3 inches thick of fat! The rest of the items on the plate made up for the fat though! 

I don't have much to praise about our server.  He was strangely quiet and made it a bit of an akward encounter. 

All in all the atmosphere was amazing and we will definitely be back again... hopefully on a clear night!

Delicious, genuine Mediterranean food with a genuine sweetheart of an owner! i stopped in for lunch with my 18mo old daughter and Smiley was SO nice the second we walked in the door. He introduced himself and answered any and all questions I had about his menu. He even offered a sample of his tzatziki sauce. It was heavenly. I ordered a chicken gyro and a side salad. Both had amazing flavor... The chicken was seasoned perfectly. My daughter ended up eating more of the food than I thought she would. Who knew she loved Greek food so much? Smiley continually checked on us as we ate outside and was super friendly. He mentioned that he was a singer, i thought maybe we'd be treated to a serenade. Maybe next time! :) I have since heard that his hummus is to die for. Can't wait to try it!  We will certainly be back!

My fiance and I received a gift card to Maria's for Christmas and finally got around to trying it out. A lot of people in the neighborhood have spoke pretty highly of the restaurant. When we got there, we were seated right away but then no one even recognized we were there for a good 10-15 minutes. It was a Friday night so it was a bit busy... a simple "I'll be right with you" from our waitress (who walked past us plenty of times) would have been good though! Once the server greeted us she was very nice. Since we waited so long for a greeting, we had already decided on the menu and ordered right away. After waiting and waiting some more, I over heard another server giving the night's specials.... SEA BASS! An entree in which I love! We couldn't find our waitress (again) and the other server asked if anyone had taken our order, I told him yes but asked if it was too late to change tot he special. They obliged and happily made the change. Our calamari appetizer was so-so. We waited and waited yet again until our entree finally arrived. My fiance ordered crab cakes... a lot of filler, not much crab. My Sea bass was different than I expected... it was a very thin piece of fish and had a VERY salty taste. Not impressed. It IS an Italian restaurant so maybe we just went wrong with our selections... pasta might have been a better choice?? And while the server was friendly and courteous, she certainly didn't score points for timely service or frequent visits to our table. 

I don't think we will ever go back for a sit-down dinner again, I do think we'll be back to try their pizza... Carry-out!

We've used Melady Landscaping for many projects at our house. The crew is very efficient, respectful, and highly skilled. Their clean-up and landscape work leaves our property looking immaculate. We most recently had them build a stone walkway, patio, and outdoor stone fireplace complete with LED lighting. The final product exceeded our expectations and left us with a Pinterest-worthy outdoor space. We already can't wait for the next project to have Melady Lanscaping bring our vision to life.

Unaccustomed to free parking at a hotel, I was impressed that they offered it. Even more impressive is the lobby. It's funky, clean and modern, yet it's still somehow inviting and warm. The rooms are fairly standard with nice touches like pretty reliable wi-fi, robes, tea, and a mini fridge with complimentary water.

I do have a couple of questions. One, what's with the bathroom door? Perhaps it's is just the room I stayed in, but the last thing I want to do is to wake up staring at the toilet. Yes, closing the pocket door to the loo will take care of that, but come on, that didn't come up at all during the design phase? And two - perhaps I'm tech challenged (having never owned a satellite TV) but does the "high tech" remote need to be more frustrating than setting the time on a 1990 VCR? Heed my warning: if you channel surf to high or too low you might wind up on a "games" station - exit - nowhere! Or you'll be in music central - again with no exit in sight. I just want to watch Law and Order gosh darn it ;p

Next time I'm going to work my darnedest to get a room on a higher level. In a flat town, the last thing you want to be looking at is someone else's roof.

I went with my older parents and toddler on a rainy weekday during the lunch hour. I feel I was a bit unfairly a bit difficult, though I was frazzled. After we ordered, I noticed there seemed to be no available seats or high chairs. The counter person was really kind and accommodating, clearing off a table as soon as one was available a few minutes later, with high chair. The pizza was delicious. This is not "regular" pizza, but high-end organic (great ideals) specialty pizza. My dad was less than thrilled by this, but my mom and I enjoyed it. There were many choices, and it was difficult to decide. I did feel hungry after 2 slices, though, and was disappointed to see they only seemed to carry gluten-free cookies and treats. I just wanted a regular ol' cookie! I would recommend if you like fancy pizza. It did take me back to my CA days.

I met a literary friend for coffee here, to catch up. We haven't discussed books, etc. in a long time. It was a wintery afternoon, and after my long walk from the east side of South to the west, I was frickin' freezing and ready for something hot! On walking in, I couldn't find a seat, and people were crowded into every corner. It was a nice mix of conversationalists and people using computers and studying. You wouldn't get stared at for talking. Found a seat on the sofa by a nice guy who let me squeeze in, and soon after, we had a table. And soon after that, I had the most beautiful latte I've ever seen. It was really very pretty, and I wish I had a pic to share with you. Great afternoon!

How charming!

Old City fun. Nothing to do? Go browsing! There is so much quirky stuff here! I've even found they have a record section. I've been going to the Book Trader for a few years now. It was quite messy, until they filmed a movie there last year. Now, things seem much more organized and cleaned up. I love it! It's perfect for my lunch-time browsing. I use it as I would a library, but I keep the books I really love. I am so addicted that today they asked me if I wanted to browse (when I was turning in The Watchmen) and I said no. But I turned to my right and saw two books I have been wanting to read for a while, so walked out with two new ones! Addicted, I tell you! Plus, books are probably one of the cheapest forms of entertainment. Keep on tradin'!

MMMMM! this was my first impression, and I probably didn't have a typical visit to the restaurant. I had a chance to go last night for the first time. I was lucky - I know an insider. So, we didn't have to wait TOO long for a table. But I heard they don't normally take reservations and the wait is sometimes a bit long. We also had a chance to try a pretty good variety of dishes.

Drinks: I don't drink whiskey, but my boyfriend and his friend both loved a tasting of 3 and after-dinner one, too. I had two different cocktails: Ginger Rogers (and I'm not even a huge gin fan) and a De Rigueur. Both lovely and tasty! Yes, girly.

Apps: I don't do oysters, but the other couple with us enjoyed 2 of each. I had the pickled truffle lemon artichokes, and I was in heaven. Whipped ricotta to spread on your toast? Great idea! This is the best artichoke concoction I've ever tasted. Best. The pickled Herb Cherry Tomatoes were yummy, too, though I've had a lot of great cherry tomatoes lately. Popcorn shrimp were tasty, but the sauce was what really impressed me. As did the mustard and cheese sauce for the soft pretzels. The condiments topped the pretzels, for me. That cheese!

Dinner: Burger - medium, cheddar, bacon, awesome. 2 can split it. The bbq Pork looked wonderful, too, and when I looked at my friends' plates, they were clean. It was gone in, like, 1 1/2 minutes.

Dessert: We got to try all three desserts. The Irish Car Bomb was good, kind of like a wet cake, though. The Shortcake was good, with a mix of strawberry/rhubarb, though you couldn't taste much rhubarb in it. On the side of that was a buttermilk sorbet which really impressed me. The winner of best dessert, though, is the 'Nutter Shake. I've never had such a milkshake - so many flavors, thick, and with a bite-sized blondie on the side. Blondies melt me.

I would give it 5 stars, if it weren't so pricey.

The decor is outstanding, as all of Jose's places are. I love a great-looking old-timey-looking bar. Very classy. Wish I could go more, but this is no health food, and I'd have to save up. Looking forward to Jose's taco truck for better prices.

This is my favorite live music venue in NOLA - a must for visitors seeking lively jazz. 

They offer two full bars, a few water stations when you tire from dancing, bar seats, a kickin' a/c, wood floors that feel like they're about to cave any second from all the dancing, AWESOME live jazz and a great crowd. It's definitley not your beligerant French Quarter Street crowd. It's more of the 30- to 40-somethings. 

This area is poppin', and I rec making a night of it on Frenchman Street. You can dart right next door to Blue Nile (a reggae bar), The Spotted Cat Music Club, Yuki Izakaya and others... 

There's a cover, but cute girls take note: flirt and bargain with the door fella and you just might get in for free or a discount. I don't mind paying cover, especially when there's live music but they do pass around a giant tip bucket MANY times over and it gets annoying, especially when you pay the full cover price and are drinking like a fish.

Yum! Talk about a really lovely margarita. A peach margarita made from FRESH PEACHES FROM THE FARMERS MARKET. 

My colleague Julie P also had a finely crafted drink. Scotch, whiskey, I can't remember, but it had a zing of yumminess which was perfect after a hot day of attempted scooter touring.

Do give Burger Up a try. The name had me thinking it was some burger diner, but that's not the case. It's a modern/industrial cafe with uber fresh food and drinks.

Let's start with the good. Location, location, location. It's in the thick of things in the HB hood. They've got a great patio with prime people watching. There's also parking! Unfortch, perhaps that's all that this resto/bar is counting on. 

I wasn't in the mood to eat, but with the lovely weather and a welcoming patio, the day called for a margarita. They featured a pomegranate margarita, and at $8.50, I thought it would be a stellar, finely crafted, high-quality marg. NO. Even when I asked our server if it had any artificial flavoring or sweeteners, she said no. "Good," I thought. Well it came in a tiny, tiny glass - not even a margarita glass - and had no hint of lime, tequila or pomegranate. It looked and tasted like a vodka and watered down cranberry. For $8.50 - methinks not! 

Service was okay, but it took a turn for the worst in the end. My tab was fine, so I won't get into that, but l'd expect a better handling of the sitch from management. I too, have worked in a restaurant.

5-stars at the chance to once again cheer on the oilers. Being from Houston, I haven't done that since '96!

The most lovely, bodacious and sweet Jennie M - Community Manager for Yelp Edmonton - scooped me up from the airport and surprised me with tickets to my first NHL game ever. I've been to many Houston Aeros and peewee games, but this was an experience. My highlights?

1. Dem hockey dudes are HOT. Who ever thought a mouth of missing teeth would make a girl swoon?
2. Friendly fans. The Oilers were playing the Boston Bruins that night (2/18), and from what I hear about NHL games, the rink isn't the only place where you'll see people throwing a few punches. But Oilers fans are redic friendly. A packed stadium and no drunken buffoons, no fights, no curse words. Fans were civilized. 
3. No one stole my jacket when I left it in my seat! What? I was surprised when Jennie M left her jacket at her seat, and was worried. "This is Canada. People don't do stuff like that." So after the 2nd period, I tried it, and I'll be damned - my jacket was still there when we returned. Crazy. I know. 
4, Rumor has it that people are calling the team the "Spoilers," because they're going to spoil other NHL teams from making the playoffs. And they didn't disappoint. The game went into OT and later resulted in a shoot out where they beat the Bruins 4-3.

So it's the day of NYE and just about every restaurant in the French Quarter has a line of 20 people out the door. Lucky for us, we came across Desire at just the right hour because we were immediately seated - almost window-side - in a packed house. 

With 127 reviews and counting, let me break it down for you...

Start with oystas! The raw oysters were incredibly fresh, chilled, and served with plenty of lemon. And they their house-made cocktail sauce has strong bite - or should I say a giant smack? ...because that was spice-ay! 

We also got the barbecue oysters. They're fried, glazed in a wonderfully sweet and smokey barbecue sauce, sitting over individual shells and topped with crumbled bleu cheese. I didn't snap any pics, but you gotta check out this photo snapped by another yelper... http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/JvawJ9bSr22xn4R9oLvl_w?select=VL23qeOnZHumSnISqQ0uXw

You can't get wrong with the gumbo, with its rich, thick roux. Probably the best I've had in a while. I also ordered the crawfish ettoufee. it was good, but I had plate envy for my friend's shrimp and grits. 

The bloody mary I ordered was alright. Not the best. It was a tad too thick and had the consistency of ketchup. The flavor and spiciness were there, but I should have ordered another shot of Tito's and thrown in some more Worcestershire to thin it out. 

Service was great. I appreciate how it was so busy, and yet our server kept reminding us to "take our time" and "enjoy your food." Love the Big Easy mentality. 

I'll totes come back. But probably stick with a dozen or two oysters and a nice cold beer.

I can spend hours upon hours at this backyard wine bar. In fact, I did. 

Walk in to the front of house wine retail store to pick out your favorite bottle of red, wine, rose, champs or beer - along with any snacks - and pay. Then head on back to grab your wine glasses, buckets o' ice, water (you'll need to hydrate if you're gonna camp out for hours), and snag a table!

:: Live music is offered all day, every day. 
:: There is a menu of food - like a fantastic cheese plate and other light bites.
:: Above the wine retail shack is a second story bar with hard liquor.
:: Tip your musicians!  
:: Enjoy the laid-back backyard atmosphere, cool tunes, great vibe, fun people watching.

Cafeteria + Carbs ...I couldn't be happier. 

Growing up in Houston, we have Cleberne's Cafeteria. But folks in this small town have Gray Brothers Cafeteria -- and I might be a bit jelly. 

Apparently at GBC, it's all about the pies. And y proudly display them at the front of the cafeteria line. It's a reminder to always eat your dessert first. Or at least leave enough room for dessert. 

The entrees include everything from fried chicken, fish, roast beef, even chicken and noodles (which appears to be a fan favorite on Yelp). Sides -- so many sides. 

The cafeteria has been around for decades. It fills up for lunch and dinner. A good time to dine is between those hours. Arrive hungry and leave with pie!

I think Joi B said it perfectly: "I've found a hotel that has it all." It's true.

Friendly, affordable, trendy, easy check-in, comfortable rooms, great lighting in the restrooms for proper makeup application, cozy beds, amazing rain shower, the softest hotel towels, a complimentary wine hour in the lobby, espresso machines in the hallway, turn down service - yes, turndown services offering warm cookies, bottled water, tidying up of the rooms. They're pet-friendly, they have a giant steamer (upon request); I actually kept it in my room for the full five days. 

The entire staff was extremely accommodating - this entire staff deserves a hospitality reward: valet, house keeping, concierge, front desk

The only cons:
This hotel is a freakin' ice box. Not bad when it's 99 degrees outside, but hanging out in the lobby for wine hour, in the restaurant for lunch or the conference rooms (the absolute worst of it), you're gonna freeze your nalgas off. 

I rec, I rec, I rec. I'll be back on my next trip to Nashy - which I hope is soon!!!

When you walk in, this place has the best aroma of oregano, basil, tomato sauce and other delicious Italian flavors, herbs and spices just brewin' in the air. It's a little taste of what's to come. 

My friends and I couldn't decided, so we mixed and matched two of their pizzas, and they even let you do halfsies. My half was vegetarian, but I added spinach and garlic (it's pressed garlic, so it's super strong). My favorite part of the meal was the crust - it was buttery, soft yet crunchy. I always eat my pizza crust first - "backwards" as some may say - and Ponzo's pizza crust reminded me why I do that ... it's the best part!

We also shared an order of their pizza rolls - now those, I really enjoyed. They're more dough than anything, and if you're a carb freak like me, it's perfect. Especially since the pizza itself is too cheesy (I know, there really isn't such a thing, until you have way too much cheese on your 'za.) The pizza rolls are akin to a pizza kolache - just order it and enjoy. Also get a cannoli, and share that bad boy, because Ponzo's are huge. 

More things to note:
+ Everything is made fresh, so your order will take some time. 
+ The bar next door - Dog House Tavern - allows outside food, so oder from Ponzo's and they'll even bring it right over. 
+ ...Or, you can just sit outside Ponzo's shared patio and order a drink from the bar. 
+ They deliver. http://www.ponzos.com/delivery_area.html
+ There's parking. 

I look forward to trying their famous lasagna and other Italian eats!

We stayed at this location for 3 nights and very much enjoyed our stay. We found the location to be just right for us: close enough to get us into the french quarter in minutes while being just far away enough from all the craziness. All hotel employees we encountered were very helpful and friendly. Room was well appointed, and the bed was very comfortable. We didn't use the kitchen except to store leftovers in the fridge, but still enjoyed having the option. We booked an early morning tour one day and didn't have time to venture outside for breakfast beforehand. We found the breakfast provided downstairs to be adequate enough for our needs although I think they would benefit from adding more light/healthy options. We grabbed a glass of wine during the evening social one night also, which was great. Wifi was complimentary, and fairly speedy.This hotel is perfect for the economical traveler looking for comfortable accommodations, and I wouldn't hesitate to recommend it to anyone visiting the big easy.

I originally intended to book with Two Chicks because I didn't trust the notion of a free tour and thought the quality of the overall tour would suffer. Boy, was I wrong! I procrastinated regarding confirming my tour because I was waiting to see how we would be feeling after a long night on Bourbon Street. This decision meant that by the time I was ready to book, all the slots in the Two Chicks tour were filled. I confirmed the Garden District/Lafayette Cemetery tour with Free Tours by Foot and hoped for the best. We were greeted by Matthew, who proceeded to take us on the most informative and entertaining walk. Learning about the history of the famous above ground Lafayette Cemetery was so interesting! The mansions in the Garden District were jaw dropping. Getting out of the French Quarter and seeing this area is what really made me fall in love with NOLA. And, this was by far the most educational time we spent during our visit. Adding some history and education to our stay made the debauchery seem all the more justified! At the end of the tour, everyone paid what they felt the tour was worth. Please tip your tour guide appropriately: we saw a few people walk off without paying and some give an embarrassingly low amount. These guys are very knowledgeable and they work hard to give everyone the best tour they can. Highly recommend using this company!

Such a charming little brunch spot! I'd bookmarked this café weeks in advance because of their decadent benedicts. As I went to grab their address from my Yelp app, I noticed they had a feature that estimated the current wait time for a table and how many people were ahead of you that also gave you the option to electronically hold your place in line. Brilliant! By the time I walked into the café 15 minutes later, our table was ready! We ordered the seafood and oyster benedicts with hash browns and grits. The benedicts were perfect: runny yolks and just the right amount of acid in the hollandaise. I wasn't crazy about everything being served on biscuits, but hey, it's the south. This was only my second experience with grits and while I can now say with certainty that they are not my thing, the version they serve here was really nice. The café itself was the definition of adorable and the hosts and our waiter were extremely friendly. Looking forward to ordering the ridiculous pancakes that come with bourbon in the future!

It was really hard to settle on a place to grab a late breakfast with all the options that Reading Terminal had to offer. But, I'm happy we decided on Beck's! The ladies behind the counter were so kind and patient, and let my husband I sample the gator gumbo, etouffe and chowder before we decided on our orders.
My husband loved his oyster po boy and shrimp and corn chowder. I had the bayou breakfast: white rice topped with gator gumbo, a fried egg, cheese and cornbread. Phenomenal! Highly recommended!

Cajun Encounters was a great experience! It was so refreshing to get out of the French Quarter and see what else New Orleans had to offer. We scheduled the swamp tour with hotel pickup. Although we were instructed to be outside by 10:15 am and told they would be there between then and 10:45 am, we found that when we walked outside of our hotel, they were there and waiting by 10:10 am! Our bus driver was really lovely and gave us a little background information as we drove through various areas. In any case, we were the first hotel they stopped at and given the size of the bus, I was very concerned about how many stops we'd have to make. We moved on to the second hotel, and noticed other smaller Cajun Encounters busses there that were full. So we all headed right on over. So much more efficient than I'd thought!

Sadly, I don't remember our Captain's name, but it started with a B and his personality reminded me of a cross between Zach Galifinakis in The Hangover and Bubba from Forrest Gump. He was eccentric but entertaining in a good way that we enjoyed. At the very start of the tour, we were given the whole explanation that we were touring out of season and it would be highly unlikely to see an alligator. But, right at the very start we actually saw two young gators coming up for air! We saw blue heron, raccoons and of course we got to meet Deboe the wild hog. The ride itself was really fun as well! Anytime the captain was about to pick up speed he'd say "Let's run." and take off. 

Picked up some cool stuff in the gift shop. Would love to come back to take the tour again while in season.

I booked a room on Hotel Tonight for a last minute weekend getaway to Philadelphia. While I got a fairly good deal, this hotel is definitely on the pricey side for what is offered. You're paying, primarily, for location here. You're in the middle of everything and walking distance to a lot of historical sights and local points of interest. 

I requested an early check in, which I received. I also requested a king bedded room, which I did not receive. Accommodations are definitely on the small side. While the room is small, the bathrooms were oddly quite spacious. However, the room was very modern and comfortable overall and did offer a  nice enough view of the Philadelphia skyline. We checked out their pool and gym, which while small, we very nice facilities.

They charge $46.50 to valet park, with no option to self park. I found that amount to be excessive for Philadelphia, however at least it included in and out privileges. The lobby of the hotel was fairly lackluster, and I didn't get a very welcoming feel from the woman who checked me in. I also noted that the floors were dirty in a lot of common areas, and that attention to detail regarding housekeeping for my room could have been better.

Overall, I'd say that my experience was just OK but would stay again due to the hotel's location.

NOLA gondola is one of the best kept secrets in New Orleans! Everyone tells you to go to Café Dumonde, go on a swamp tour or hit up the French Quarter. But, very few people know that you can take an extremely memorable and romantic gondola ride right through New Orleans City Park. Our gondolier, Robert, was a class act from our very first correspondence through til the conclusion of our ride. I was concerned about the weather, and e-mailed him about my concerns and questions about cancellations and fees. He gave me his feedback and also suggested moving my 7pm scheduled ride to 5pm so that my husband and I could enjoy the sunset. What a wonderful recommendation that was! We got a much better view at that time of day! Robert greeted us warmly, set us up with some cheese and crackers, and a bucket of ice for the white wine we brought along. He played some Andrea Bocelli and gave us a mix of information both about the park as well as his gondola and years as a gondolier as we made our way through the park. Going through the sculpture garden was especially interesting. And, keeping the tradition of kissing under each bridge we passed through was cute. Robert even played "Time to Say Goodbye" as our tour concluded and we headed back. Tour was $95 for 50 minutes, and worth every penny!

I Eek! at writing one star reviews. But this quick trip away deserves it. 

Checked in late on a Thursday, no problems. Strangely, though, front desk had zero recommendations on a solid sports bar. Interesting for such a sports-crazy town. 

The worst of it came the next morning when getting ready for the day.

The inside shower curtain liner had black smudges/specks that have to be either mold/mildew, dirt or a Sharpie. Gross. Mental note made to not get near the curtain or touch any walls. Easy enough.

Then came the drying portion. Pull off a hand towel from the rack and *fortunately* open before touching/using only to see vomit all over the towel.

Beeline to the phone. Informed them of the Vomit Towel and the Questionable Curtain, which received a few "I'm so sorry"'s and "We'll be right up"'s. 

When we got back later that day, the offending Vomit Towel was replaced, but with two towels that weren't freshly folded, and thus were not used. Unfortunately the curtain remained.

Pillows were a bust. No free WiFi/Internet Connection. *Generally* functional TV.

Not what I expect in a "Luxury" King room. I'll stick with the old reliable brands and known chains. 

The pluses: Keurig machine and good coffee; location.

Opryland Facts:

- You can rent a Gibson guitar for 50$ a day to keep in your room
- Wake up calls feature country stars past and present
- You will get lost at least once trying to find your room
- You will spend twice as much as you ought to for dinner
- Service staff will be extremely helpful and friendly
- You will have Vegas deja vous
- Y'all will enter your vocabulary, if not already present
- Standard "features" for $15 include free Wi-Fi, two bottles of water and some local calls in your room. Per day.
- You will sleep very well on account of the comfy beds.

That's all I got. Huge place. Lots to do. Lots to see as you get lost in the labyrinth. 

You won't, however, find many recycling bins :(

My husband and I spent a few hours here recently on a Sunday. I think our experience would have been much better if I'd read the Yelp reviews beforehand, because we would have known we could bring water with us- the website says no outside food or drinks, but everybody there seemed to have brought their own food and beverages in with them. 

Also, they open at 9am on Sundays- not 8:30 as the website states! We were there during the earlier part of the day and it wasn't crowded at all, but definitely started to fill up with people in the early afternoon.

Anyway, I got a great massage from Valery, who worked out all the knots in my back. I've been having a ton of back pain lately, and was feeling great after my massage. 

The old Russian men hanging out there were thrilled to have outsiders like us there and enjoyed showing us around. I always appreciate going somewhere new and being welcomed by the regulars! They even got me to jump into the super cold plunge pool after sitting in the blazingly hot Russian sauna! 

This would be such a fun place to go with a small group of people. For a day. With snacks and water.

I have gotten 3 haircuts at the Collingswood Hair Cuttery, from 3 different stylists, and was pleased each time. The caveat, though, is that I have long hair, and I rarely blow-dry it or style it... So, my standards about what constitutes "good haircut" might be kind of low!

I would imagine that if you are picky about your hair, or have a specific style that you maintain, or like to have the same person cut your hair each time, then the Hair Cuttery might not be for you.

If you know me, you know that I love Indian food, as much as I love cats... and I have three cats, so that's saying a lot. 

So glad this place exists in my new home town. The food was excellent and our waiter, Jeremy, was perhaps one of the nicest and most genuine waiters I've ever had. Totally made the experience even better.

I had the vegetarian thali and my husband had the non-vegetarian thali. I ordered it medium spicy and it came out just right! I loved the paneer dish and the curried vegetables. The dal makhani was a little too tomatoey for my taste, to be honest, but still very good. 

Make sure to leave room for dessert. We had chocolate samosas (WHAAAAT!) with raspberry sauce. And gulab jamuns, which are sort of like warm rosewater donuts. 

Don't forget to bring some wine or beer, because this is a BYOB (dry town and all). I'm no wine expert... we brought a bottle of Cabernet Sauvignon that we had in our cabinet... it was just fine but would something else be better? I can't say.

I'm getting hungry just thinking about going back!

Sometimes what you really need on a Saturday night is to sit at home, watch tv, and order an astounding amount of sushi. This is what I did recently. 

I can only speak about the vegetarian items, as I do not eat fish. I liked everything I ordered (mango, oshinko, avocado, cucumber) except the avocado and peanut. There seemed to be too many peanuts in the roll and/or the peanuts were not chopped finely enough... something just wasn't right. 

A great addition to the neighborhood!

I was thrilled when I heard Han Dynasty was opening an outpost in Cherry Hill just a few minutes from home.... this new location is (in my opinion) way better than the Old City location for several reasons: it's less cramped, the waiters and hosts are totally entertaining (they offer extra rice and will, upon request, tell anecdotes about people's reactions to the spicy food), and the place was filled with NORMAL people and not Old City people. 

Anyway, I had the Dan Dan Noodles (without the pork!) and the Spicy Cucumbers. I had the Hot Pot Tofu. They do typically prepare the food a bit milder than in Old City, but if you ask, they'll cook your portion spicy. Make sure to take some Tums or Pepto Bismol when you get home; it'll take the edge off any stomach problems you will inevitably have in the middle of the night... trust me on this one.

For 4 of us, the bill was about $80, and we brought a big bottle of wine with us and it went well with the meal (in case you want to know, it was Rex Goliath Cabernet Sauvignon... keeping it classy), but I think next time I'll bring beers instead.

A wonderful special occasion spot!

I won't repeat what others have written, I'll just add two things:

1. If you request it, they'll make the antipasto without the meat/fish components. We had a giant dish brimming with delicious veggies, spreads and cheeses and it was AWESOME!!!
2. The noise really isn't that bad. Maybe I guess if there was a big group of people being loud like how big groups can be? But we were there and most of the tables were occupied, and... the noise level was totally unremarkable.

Loved the atmosphere. 

Loved the service. 

My husband and our friends loved their food. 
 
As for me, I wasn't a big fan of the fact that there was nothing vegetarian on the menu, except for one or two of the salads and some veggie sides. I'd heard great things about the gnocchi and was disappointed that they're not longer offering it! I asked the waitress if they could make me something, and I had a pasta with vegetables that was nothing to write home about.

Today is the first day of summer break for public school teachers in Philadelphia. Collectively, we had a tough year this year and we deserve some pampering. Also, collectively, we have a bit of a hangover from a few days in a row of intense happy-hour-ing. So, two of my girlfriends (also teachers) and I made the journey up Broad Street to Chung Dam today, and boy was it worth it.

I got a body scrub and massage- a 90 minute treatment for just $60. I am pretty sure I got about a pound of dead skin (that I didn't even know was there) scrubbed from my body. The massage was wonderful as well. 

After my massage, I enjoyed the different tubs and heated rooms that they had to offer. It was a nice variety and very enjoyable.

The facility itself is clean, and there were very few people there in the middle of the afternoon on a weekday- just my style! I'm almost hesitant to review Chung Dam Spa because it seems like a well-kept secret and I'd like it to stay that way. 

Also, it's open until 11:30 which makes me think, how awesome would it be to arrive after dinner, relax until closing time, and go right into a blissful slumber?

I actually had a very pleasant stay here last night.  The flooring was new, the bathroom was clean and a decent size, and the bed was pretty comfy.  I didn't use the kitchenette but I'd definitely appreciated having it, and I wouldn't mind staying here again particularly if I have to come up for a few days for work.  The folks behind the desk were all kind and helpful, and the location was good- there's a shopping center right next door.  

Two things I wish they would improve- I smelled some smoke in my room and in the elevator.  And their grab-n-go breakfast was not good.  The coffee in particular was weak and watery, and the muffins were small- Otis Spunkmeyer prepackaged...  I'd love it if they offered some fresh breakfast options and aired out the rooms that were smoking...   

But other than that it was great.  I had no issues with the wifi- I worked from my computer for 3 hours and had no issues.  And it was less than $100 a night- very economical.

Adorable, well-stocked consignment and sustainably-produced clothing and products for kids.  I LOVE IT.  They had a large selection of impeccably kept kids consignment clothing.   I would put my daughter in any of the stuff they had- it was super nice and all very current.  No outdated duds here!   I got 8 pieces for my daughter, 24 months/2T for $33.  There's no way I could do that even at Target... and the labels are all Gap, Zutano, Carters... 

The guy running the store was also super nice- even though they closed at 6pm they stayed open so I could shop for a few minutes, and he told me that their buyers are all very selective, and because they buy the clothing outright instead of taking clothes on consignment, buyers get awesome deals and a large selection... 

Seriously, I want one of these stores in Frederick.  Please please please.

Considering it's in the middle of the suburbs, this is surprisingly great Italian food.  I took my dad here for Father's Day and we had a great special: Gnocchi Pescador- home-made gnocchi with seafood like calamari and shrimp and mussels and clams in a red sauce.  It was awesome.
