Usually sweet drinks are meant for people who aren't drinkers and can't stand the taste of alcohol. And last but certainly not least, sweet drinks mean for inevitable hangover. I pride myself on being a veteran drinker and at most, get one hangover a year. In fact, my year anniversary of my last hangover is coming up. July 4. 

The fabulous thing is, Tiki Tolteca offers up *craft* Tiki drinks. Yes, you're reading that correctly. Look at my menu photos that detail the ingredients! They even offer up little stories with each drink. Their cocktails don't only feature rum, but such lovely spirits as my beloved Mezcal, and my much less beloved caçaca. I settled on a Hemingway Daiquiri, which is frozen and perfect because it's not a fruit daiquiri, so not filled with artificial nonsense, just lime, rum, & maraschino liqueur. And potent, seeing as I was feeling a nice buzz after two.

They also have a menu feature small plates with a tropical flavor. DO NOT PASS UP THAT CHOCOLATE TRUFFLE DESSERT. The Tiki gods command it, too. Seriously. It really is the stuff of the gods. Chocolate, coconut, banana sauce... 'scuse me while I talk in tongues. I look forward to going back and trying the sweet corn tamales (vegetarian!). No crab rangoons, though, thankfully (created at Don the Beachcomber and now for some reason is expected on any given Chinese restaurant menu for some perplexing reason).

Oh!! Be sure and order a High Life, if you're so inclined, so you can get the full bottle service experience. This is no joke. They serve it in Champagne glasses and ice your bottle. Luckily my drinking partners indulged so I didn't have to.

More fun trivia. You may see in my profile that my current (and forever) crush is Howard Hughes. Apparently there's a tale of him drinking one too many zombies at Don the Beachcomber and then killed a pedestrian with his car. Bad Howie!! I hope it's not true. But yeah, beware the ENTIRE ZOMBIE MENU (seriously. TIki Tolteca has an entire zombie menu!!)

What's next Tiki Tolteca? Maybe scheduled thunderstorms over a lagoon a la San Francisco's Tonga Room?

Give me a bottle of red wine and a backyard, throw in some good company and/or good music and I really can't really be much happier. Hello, Bacchanal!

Oh, but there's more! See, what you're doing is buying the bottle at the price you'd get it at the wine shop (essentially because you *are* at a wine shop), so there's no bar/lounge mark up, then hitting up their glorious back garden space, filled with trees, fairy lights and all kinds of magic. And wait... there's more! They have a fridge with cheese wedges, and you pick one or more out, bring it up to the counter to pay and within minutes, they'll whisk a huge cheese plate to your table that's overloaded with toast, some fruit and nuts. 

In the days of super lounges and other such nonsense when you're paying high covers and then $$ drinks as well, it's kind of hard to believe Bacchanal can be so generous. Maybe it's due to the city of New Orleans honoring the spirit of Bacchus on a regular basis? The god is giving back...

Kinda makes me want to move in... or next door or even upstairs. I won't complain about the live music, either...

I've gotta be honest. I'm slowly but surely losing my love for United. Sure, you get all the charm of the ladies answering the phone, not to mention, the usually AWESOME, friendly and efficient drivers.

But... I've had a couple terrible experiences recently that have me calling White Fleet, instead. 

During Mardi Gras, a United driver picked up three girls with suitcases he found on a corner in the CBD as he was driving me home from the Bywater. I didn't complain b/c, well, it was during Mardi Gras and that's probably enough said.

BUT... he dropped them off in the LGD on the way to my apartment Uptown, and then he charged ME for the extra passengers. WTF? I called and lodged a complaint because I stupidly didn't feel like arguing (also, I felt sorry for him, like a dumbass, because he was talking about putting kids through college and being broke and... well, it was Mardi Gras, LOL). I've come to find out that THAT waste of time lodging the complaint was not worth the inconvenience and money I was out.

Other issue with United: the last few times I was going to the aiport, I had no cash and apparently barely any drivers accept CCs so I was waiting at the very least a half hour and almost an *hour* once for a cab to pull up.

So, White Fleet it is from now on. Just the way it goes....

Thanks for the reminder, Yelp! I love Fair Grinds, yet I apparently never wrote them a review. So here's the five star review they've been missing for almost 2 years now. 

First a mention on how they are one of the only coffeehouses in NOLA that's dedicated to fair trade coffees and all of their tea is organic. That the tea is organic is a huge deal as I recently learned non-organic teas are ridden with pesticides. Not that I'm such a big tea drinker, but in September-October I'm all about dirty chai and by "dirty" that means a shot of espresso, not a spray of pesticides! Thankfully they make their own chai and hooray for it not being overly sweetened like that stuff from the box.  They have almond milk in addition to soy, so you don't have to worry about GMO-ridden lattes!

I haven't tried their baked goods, all of which look delectable, but I had lunch once, some kind of vegetarian sandwich that I can't recall other than the fact that it was quite good. If you're in the mood for lunch, be aware that they stop serving it around 2. Bagels and pastries are available all the time, though!

Fair Grinds is small and cozy and a traditional coffeehouse in that it's more reminiscent of being in a real house than a sterile storefront/corporate coffee bar. They have community-based activities like Kundalini Yoga weekly and various performances. The staff is so very kind and accommodating and I just love that side verdant patio that's off to the side. It's the kind of place I can easily lose hours in good conversation or a book. But typically I'm working on my laptop, so to that end, you don't have to go crazy scoping out an outlet. Internet works just fine every time I've been there. 

I have some great coffeehouses in my area, but none of them "have it all" like Fair Grinds. The fact that I actually get in my car and drive the 15 minutes or so that it takes to get here speaks volumes, doesn't it?

It's fun up in here!

A night here will include any of the following:

-karaoke (not my thing, but it's fun to watch your friends get up there and rock it)
-drinks, cheap 'n strong
-running into your neighbors from way across town (testament to a bar's greatness- getting people away from the bars in their own hood)
-friendly greetings from the regulars sitting at the bar. They may have seen it all, but they do make you feel like you're special walking in there. I judge a good bar by its regulars.

The good thing about the karaoke is that there is no host (it's all done fair and square by computer). Seriously, there's nothing like an annoying karaoke fluffer. I don't want to see some professional singer up there hogging up every other song just to keep people there waiting and drinking. And I definitely don't need a snotty KJ. Not that they all are but once in San Fran a large group of us were banned from the karaoke list because of the KJ's control issues. Really, should karaoke be so ridden with rules and egos? I think not. 

I may have left on the early side the last time I was there, but I have a strong feeling the place only gets more interesting as the night goes on.

I came to St. Louis expecting to try  *St. Louis style* pizza, which I only learned was an actual style of its own about a year ago. Yes, I had been living under a NYC rock. I mean, stone. A pizza stone.

I had been told St. Louis style pizza featured some kind of cheese known as Provel. Actually, I had been told by someone who is not from the area that it was Provolone, but I was quickly corrected by Abby S, that Provel and Provolone are two different things. Intrigued, but not without some trepidation, I figured, sure, I'll try St. Louis style pizza! Across the street from the hotel to Pi, we went.

Only, Pi is *anti* Provel, as it turns out (their t-shirts proudly indicate this). Instead, Pi is known for its cornmeal crust and although it is "deep dish," it's heavy on the sauce (*not* heavy on the cheese). Now *that* is my kind of pie. FYI they also have thin crust if that is your thing. Typically, that is my thing, but when in St. Louis, one should do as the St. Louans (is that what they're called?) do. Although, I think St. Louis pizzas are traditionally cracker crust. Ah, there I go again. ANYWAY...

It was a beautiful spring day on Wednesday, so we sat outside and were immediately taken care of by our friendly waiter who brought us water and drinks (really good house iced tea that is infused with some kind of blossom). We were warned that the deep dish pizzas take 35 minutes to prepare, which was fine with us.

It was worth the wait. Holy delish, batgirl! I ordered kalamata olives and mushrooms on mine and the sauce to cheese ratio was just perfect. I love the sauce! Chunky tomato, not sweet. Mmmmmm mmmm good. And that crust was just awesome. If polenta were a crust, well, there ya go! I just love the combination of cornmeal and tomato sauce. It wasn't tough, like i expected. Oh yes, I'm a fan!

We were there for a pretty long time and our waiter kept checking back on us, refilled our drinks without interrupting our meeting and finally, it was time for a limoncello cocktail. Oh wow! 

Now, where to get St. Louis style pizza that isn't traditionally St. Louis style, but *Pi* style pizza in Kansas City?

How to review such an iconic establishment? I've been to events here on two recent occasions: a burlesque show and a concert.

The nitty gritty:
-good sightlines
-good sound
-kick ass, fast and efficient bartenders (I've been to enough venues where they can't manage the crowds, or maybe they choose to be slow because the crowd is so anonymous to them).
-part of me wants to just live in those little houses that flock either side of the stage.

If you're "hungry like the wolf" (sorry, I had to go there), pop in next door for what smelled like good, greasy bar food (I did not indulge). It's also a good spot for a breather, as there are seats. The main venue doesn't have as much as a banquet. 

Side note: Doesn't "Howlin' Wolf" sound like something out of the gay animal kingdom?

Really, unless you're a Mormon, how can you *not* adore a festival that celebrates all things cocktail? If people into the intricacies of flavor, texture and ingredients of food are "foodies," what would you call the same types of people who are into cocktails and booze? New Orleanians.

Hence, this festival makes the most sense coming out of New Orleans and it's been a slow, steady explosion. I don't need to give you the history, though. I'm just going to give you my take on it.

I'll give my only criticism here and as you can see from my 5 stars, it certainly didn't ruin my experience. It does bear mentioning. Check-ins on the first day closed at 6pm. I arrived at 6:10 due to crazy traffic due to Obama being in town thus causing a regular 30 minute trip to take over an hour. Although the staff was still in the reception room, they refused to check me in. I think check-in should close a lot later than 6pm, after all, the opening bashes were all going on that night and without your tickets, you can't get in to them (or so I thought. Luckily I was able to get into both Better with Age and the Absolut opening party with my assistant's tickets since she had her media badge). Besides, with people coming in from all over at all times *and* it being that it's in a hotel, next year it would be nice to see extended check-in times.

That aside, I thoroughly enjoyed my lost week, I mean, incredibly fun-filled week at TOTC. From the volunteer staff who checked you in at each event and seminar (all of them incredibly nice) to the tasting rooms to the hotels and other types of event venues, all I can say is that I was left thoroughly impressed. There was just so much going on, it's impossible to catch everything. I paced myself rather well (time for a pat on the back). 

And that L'agniappe Lounge. WOW!!! This room, I believe, is only for media and other sponsors, but holy crap. All of the brands and sponsors left swag, product and other fun materials (favorite had to be the moleskine notebooks thanks to Tanqueray or Hennessey-- it's tastefully embossed into the cover). OH!! And the bottles of shrubs and bitters!!!! I also now have an entire bar of tiny bottles (there were regular bottles, too, but I didn't take any due to not wanting to carry them around). Boozers, you will feel like a kid in a candy shop in that room! Incredible. 

My favorite events were Better with Age and the Absolut bash (I mean... they had SNOW pumped into the room!). The Diageo Happy Hour was fun because of the people I was with, however the food left a lot to be desired (do not bring a bread bowl around to hundreds of people to dip their hands into. Whose idea was that??)
... not to mention that although there were master mixologists at the bars, they had to make due with the ingredients that were given to them (kind of like the "Chopped" for bartenders). I definitely preferred the vodka cocktails to any others.

While the booze flowed freely, my tip to attendees is to make sure and pack some energy bars because this event is not about food, so don't expect any. Plan accordingly! Also next year, I plan to stay in a hotel so I can stumble to/from events (and leave all the goodies I pick up along the way in my room). 

Note: I did not attend any of the Spirited Dinners this year.

Ever get overwhelmed by ostalgie? "Of course you can't, Joi, you grew up in the ol' US of A, safely thousands of miles away from the Eastern block, while your relatives were surviving the aftermath of a cold Prague Spring.

But, but... I totally *get it* just like I may be prone to yearn for times of the plague and consumption and I wasn't around for those either. 

Pravda offers up the Soviet chic in droves and I love every ounce of this place, from the dark red furnishings and communist chic (reminds me of KGB Bar, or perhaps a club car on the Orient Express) to the DJ nights to the lovely courtyard. 

I didn't look at (or see) a cocktail menu, but we came here for a decent selection of absinthe and Pravda did not disappoint. The bartender didn't do the lighting the sugar cube on fire BS that some do, a surefire way to wreck a good louche! Be aware, a decent absinthe will cost you 17-20 dollars, which I think is a bit much, but a little goes a long way. Just be lucid enough to avoid that Lucid crap (their absinthe is infused instead of distilled) and you'll be fine.

I am truly dismayed that I held back in my stardom with Bacchanal a couple months ago. I could have *sworn* I gave them 5 stars. WTH? Time to update and also mention they've added a cocktail bar. There are sick lunch deals. The live music is part of what makes this place so fucking phenomenal, so I'm glad that they are able to have it again after that nonsense with the Cranky McCrankersons of the neighborhood putting up an absurd fuss. I've yet to hear anything but really great music (think: mood music and not speed metal. Gawd.) and for the love of Bacchus, tip the musicians and tip them well. Each set. 

Sadly, this is a long distance love affair for me right now. You can't get more opposite end of the city from where I currently (sadly) reside. As I mention in my previous review, the plan was to move right next door or around the block or perhaps just get a tent and camp out in the backyard (and I'm high maintenance, so you know this is devotion). 

Yep. I'm stalking you, Bacchanal. And it's a compliment.

Holla, back to Pi almost exactly one year later! Because I'm all about devout worship of the thin crust I went for that this time, although fond memories of the deep dish almost made me choose otherwise.

Glad I went for the thin crust, as it too is cornmeal and perfectly crispy. For saucy me, I got extra sauce, plus mushroom, kalamata olives and spinach. Damn, that is some good pizza! 

Damn Damn DAMN that is some good pizza!

I'm staying in the Moonrise across the street and I have a feeling I'll be looking at all of these vintage moon photos that are everywhere, but instead of moons, I'll be seeing some Pi pizzas with big smiley faces in them. Maybe it'll be *me* transposed in Gibson girl attired in the photo as well, sitting on the pizza moons, gazing up at the pizza moons with love. Falling OFF the pizza moons. Fondling the nose of a pizza moon. OK, that's kind of creepy. But hilarious. Yup, I'm creepy, hilarious and I love Pi pizza.

In fact, I am going to make certain that I dream of Pi tonight as well. 

Love this place! Can't you tell?

I've been a longtime fan of Surrey's Café Uptown (healthy, hearty breakfast, brunch and lunch!) and just recently made a visit to this location. It's a lot smaller and there's no outdoor seating, so it helps to not arrive fiending for food first thing because you're probably going to wait. It's worth the wait... but... We arrived about an hour before closing, which I hate to tell you is the best time to go, but there it is.

What I prefer about this location is that the staff is awesomely prompt, attentive and just plain nice. I haven't been to the Uptown location in over a year, but I do recall feeling service left a bit to be desired. That said, the food is just so damn good that I really didn't care at all about that. The food at this Surrey's is just as good as Uptown. I had the special juice of the day, The Sweet Cuban (apple, kale, cucumber, celery, cilantro, ginger) and it tasted amazing. Not to mention, it's very fairly priced. Juice can often be hella $$ (just the other day I paid 10 bucks for 16 ounces elsewhere which, I'm sorry, is crazy).

The tofu breakfast with sautéed vegetables is SOLID! It comes over rice, but I substituted grits because 1. I love grits about 10x more than rice and 2. Surrey's grits are amazingly rich and delicious. Just a note that I'm pretty sure their grits ain't vegan because only butter, maybe even a touch of cream, can turn grits into breakfast decadence. Wow, seriously. It's breakfast time right now and I'm craving my half healthy, half richly divine concoction, but sadly I'm about 800 miles away, so no Surrey's tofu and grits for me. Thanks for the memories...

Picture this: idyllic, tropical courtyard filled with palms, multicolored fairy lights, and a fountain, with a bar to the side where the 'tenders are slinging rum drinks and music pouring out from the interior of the restaurant. Are you with me here? Yes.

And please, this is how you need to enter, through that courtyard on Frenchman, rather than through the restaurant itself, which is much more modest, bare bones, even, and is where you'll often find a variety of bands playing (last night, Thursday, was a Blues jam). It's just not much to look at when you consider the outside and if outside was not available, I'd be hard pressed to stay. First impressions are everything, as they say, and luckily mine was of the environs.

Although I can't speak for the food, I can speak for the drinks (you know me by now, right?) They have a fair selection of three red wines, one of which was organic but two of which were Cabernets and I avoid Cabs like the plague. I settled for a decent Shiraz, but really, this scene is just begging for rum drink sippin', so I can't fault them for their wine selection. The mojito list is impressive and Old New Orleans Rum is an option (and I highly recommend over that Cruzan stuff). There are plenty of fruits to add in to your drink, too. Blueberry, anyone? The bartenders are swift, friendly and because the bar is called Mojitos, you know they won't roll their eyes at you for ordering one.

I'm such a sucker for ambiance, that I will gladly return just for a drink in the courtyard. They'd even get me drinking rum and that's a pretty rare thing.

Sweet little spot nestled among other slightly ancient-looking storefronts on Burgundy in Bywater, Suis Generis prides itself on creative menus every week (I know this. I get the emails!), in addition to Mexican on Thursdays, and brunch on Sundays. Atmosphere: quirky (salt & pepper shakers on rat rod hot wheels; fake fireplaces, awesome plastic cup ceiling), but no over-the-top suffocating kitsch. Restrained kitsch? Kinda novel... I definitely like. 

I went once for a dose of Mexican and really dug the vibe of the place, more chill than Maurepas across the street (which i also love, it's just that sometimes you need chill instead of loud and bustling). I felt like the service was extremely nice and although there were growing pains (my dish was missing the add-ons I had asked for), these all came out immediately in abundance. Plus, they make a mean cocktail. 

Which brings me to Sunday (yesterday). Bellini brunch! My friend and I stopped in first to Maurepas for their sick grits that are as buttery as all fuck, but other than that, they didn't really have any brunch food, so we headed for our second brunch at Suis Generis. Seriously. Two brunches? Talk about eyes being bigger than our stomachs. A quick perusal of the menu revealed a stuffed Atlanta Falcon for dinner (brilliant! Love it!) and a decent brunch menu, but I only had eyes for the bellini. By the time the second bellini had been ordered, we both knew the intention to order food was but a distant memory.

These were the best bellinis I've ever had. They don't just dump in some crappy peach schnapps (any decent place won't do this, naturally), but use a really good peach liquor and a decent champagne (by "decent" all I ask for is super dry so that I don't have a hangover happening at 3pm).

The couple behind the operation are really cool as well and are there both working the DJ booth (awesome record collection) and behind the bar. I love receiving their weekly menus, which always offer a couple veg options, and I love that I now live close by so I can check them out more frequently.

Ahhh, the need to go to the DMV. The dread ranks up there with a visit to the dentist. That said, my experience here was probably the easiest and best I've ever had at any DMV (you don't want to hear my horror stories. What happened in Kansas, stays in Kansas).

I'm one of those typical people who put off things like renewing a license or worse yet, my car plates. As such, my car with expired plates remains in Kansas City because I was certain if I drove it down here, I'd be stopped and given an astronomical fine or worse, an astronomical fine and a night in the slammer (trust me, that is just my luck). And as interesting a story a night in a rural Arkansas jail might make, I wasn't going to risk it.

Fact: I never changed my DL from New York to Kansas when I moved there three years ago (which was a good thing, seeing as I then moved to Missouri after just a year in Kansas). Good thing I was never pulled over for anything, because I hear cops get pissy about such things. 

I was determined to do it right in Louisiana, though. My license was set to expire on my birthday in 6 weeks, so I did the unthinkable: I didn't wait until the day before it was going to expire! I braced myself for the worst, the endless afternoon lines, the forgetting of some vital document and having to do it all over again and the surly DMV staff.

But I encountered none of these things, save for forgetting my corrective lenses. The extremely kind DMV worker allowed me to borrow my friend's glasses and somehow I managed to pass, despite our wildly different prescriptions. I guess the gods were smiling down upon me that day. The wait at around 3pm was only about 45 minutes total.  And I got my license on the spot. The picture is even something I can live with. I almost want to go back there to hang out, the experience was so painless. 

I would rate it four stars, but I can't for the life of me say "Yay, I'm a fan!" of any DMV, anywhere. The staff get 5 stars, however! I feel like inviting them over for cocktails sometime.

It's always a good sign when you're warmly greeted upon entering an establishment. I don't know about you, but it's rare to be utterly disappointed after that. Or, perhaps you just don't let yourself be. The importance of good reception should not be overlooked!

With that in mind, I bring you my review of Ricardo's Italian Cafe. I had been drinking coffee all morning at the fabulous Park Avenue Coffee next door, but alas, a low fat blueberry muffin did not keep me sated for more than 3 hours, so come lunchtime, I checked Yelp and was overjoyed to see an Italian restaurant is located right next door. Especially because St. Louis is known to have some damn good Italian American food!

I was seated by window without even asking. Bonus points again for first impressions here! The menu has a good amount of pasta dishes, but I was dazzled by the eggplant parmesan, as is typical for me. It's offered both as a small plate and as an entree (don't quote me on this, but I believe the full size portion is offered on a lunch special).

Molto sadness: apparently due to the freeze in Mexico, there are no eggplants to be had, as I was told by the waitress. Soooo, if you were hoping to get locally sourced vegetables, well it ain't happening here (I know, I know... eggplant isn't in season in MO right now). I instead ordered the minestrone and penne tossed with garlic, oil and vegetables.

The Minestrone... I hate to say this, when I wanted to like a place so much (yes, that warm greeting really does go a long way), but it is possibly the worst I've ever had. I hate likening anything in a restaurant to store bought, but this is the stuff that Campbell's Alphabet soup is made of. Inexcusable in an Italian restaurant.

On to the main course: let's say it made up for the soup in droves. I quite possible inhaled this dish! Delicious pasta, crisp broccoli, fresh mushrooms with just the right amount of olive oil and garlic. Perfection.

The ambiance of the restaurant lends itself well to both a business lunch or a romantic dinner. There are two cozy dining rooms (you enter through the bar) and while it won't be winning any design awards, it's a familiar kind of scene that conjures up Italian American bistros across the US and I like this sort of thing. It's not garish with pink lighting and marble busts like Anthony's in Kansas City, and several notches above my beloved Milo's here in Saint Louis. 

I do think I'd return to Ricardo's when in the neighborhood. I judge most Italian American places by their marinara sauce, which I didn't get to try here. Next time! For now, though...

they had me at hello.

Meh to the Bloody Marys. Rare is it that I'm not compelled to order two, and here, I was not. 

And trust me, with the way I was feeling that day... it was bloody necessary. A bland Bloody Mary is a sin in New Orleans and I hold Bloody Marys up to my city's high standards.

As others mention, the front patio is all what this place is about. And truly, I'd probably give them three stars because I didn't eat and it's hard to judge a place on a single cocktail.

But... a Bloody Mary is a very important thing. Especially on a Saturday at 3pm.

I will never again have to deal with the prospect of going postal... Hello, lifesaver!!! 

I was just wondering... is there anyone out there who hates going to the post office as much as I do? Silly question, I know. Parcels & Post is here to save your day. Located conveniently Uptown on Magazine St., you will totally feel like you're entering the post office in a small town circa 1922. You get friendly, quick service, even at the peak of the mail season. Add that to that the convenience of having access to a variety of mailing options (USPS, UPS and Fed Ex) without having to deal with any of those often nightmarish offices/stores and I prove my point there in the first line. 

There are also fun New Orleans souvenirs/gifts in here, so don't seal your box of gifts before arriving! I had already and came pretty close to ripping it open to throw in a CD of local holiday music. 

Pro tip:Live in the area and don't like the idea of packages being left on your doorstep? You can have them mailed to Parcels & Post for $2 a package and they will keep them for a week, possibly longer if you arrange it beforehand, say if you're going out of town!

Dive bar? I just don't think so. Comfy, cozy bar in the Quarter populated with locals and tourists? Yes. 

I like it in here a lot. I haven't been since I stayed in the guest apartments above it back in '99. Music is damned good. Drinks are cheap. Bartender is friendly and it's the kind of bar you definitely want to sit at. I like that it's in the center of the room. It just feels right. I can just as easily see this place being fun on a quiet night (preferred) to a busy night. 

There's also plenty of tables to sit with small to larger groups with (long tables in the back). The only food I ate were the fries which taste hella good and yay for not being frozen. There are veg options (including a vegan chili. Pretty nice for a "dive bar.") One of the cooks is vegan, so you can be sure there's no slackin' going on back there.

Also came here on Mardi Gras day and think it'll be the start of a tradition for me (thanks for the tip, Andrea B!) It felt like an oasis on Tuesday and yes, their kitchen was open. 

I always get amused by tours that hit up bars that I'm hanging out in. I'm not complaining, it's just funny because those tours attract all kinds, some of whom look decidedly uncomfortable to have to be spending time in a bar like this (or 1135 when there are tours that go through there, if they still do). Anyway, it reminds me a lot of when I went to Egypt and tour guides would make stops in their friend's papyrus or alabaster shops. Hey, it's all about supporting the locals, wherever you are. All good.

My beloved Pravda changed hands a little less than six months ago. I have mixed feelings. I truly appreciate the operation behind the new Perestroika at Pravda, those geniuses behind some of my favorite mixology meccas in town, Cure and Bellocq, but I so badly miss the vibe of the original. 

Let me explain. The original was dark and red, where the new is drenched in lighter hues, but it's colorless as far as I can tell. The original was cozy and inviting (at least to the likes of me) with Victorian lamps and Soviet memorabilia everywhere. The new is rather devoid of any kind of signature style. Simply put: it's rather bare. And too brightly lit. This brightness makes whomever I bring here want to go elsewhere. I get that they have food now and you can't exactly be eating in the dark (well, I do, but I suppose it's not ideal), but... but... I prefer it a dark and stormy cocktail bar. Both Bellocq and Cure have the perfect ambiance, so I guess I don't understand what's up here. 

Where they will shine: cocktails. This is what this group does best. The original Pravda didn't have a cocktail menu and just stuck to mixed drinks and absinthe. Perestroika has signature drinks and I guess it's heading in the direction of an upscale Tiki bar, though the only evidence of that right now is a Mai Tai on the menu. I was here on repeal of Prohibition Day and they had a special menu which was awesome. 

I appreciate the slow change, it's just that right now it seems stuck in this kind of uncertain purgatory. I mean, Pravda is still in the name, so these comparisons will continue to be drawn.

I do hope for the best! I'll keep checking in from time to time. Just please, dim those lights a little bit? We all look so much *kinder* by candlelight.

Because I was feeling like having a light, healthy lunch the other day, I ordered a big basket of chips and 3 dips to accompany 'em. Great idea because you know, guac (quite good here) and queso (not bad) are practically calorie and fat free. And chips... oh come on. What am I 12?

While I don't recommend this lunch (your friends will say they'll share your spoils but they'll be lying because they won't be able to manage their own enormous plates of food laden with cheese, beans, tortillas and rice), I will say it was quite tasty. 

Sigh. I really need to avoid places like this or accept the inevitable.

Other stuff you may want to know: attentive, friendly service (though kinda chain-like with suggestions. Not his fault), boisterous packed house on a Saturday (of course) and huge TVs everywhere. 

Seems like the kind of place you'd encounter a huge table of executives on a biz trip from anywhere USA letting loose after indulging in too many frozen margaritas.

I know, I know, I can't possibly get more exciting than by offering up yet another supermarket review. And another review of a Rouses, at that. My first compelling review of a Rouses can be seen here http://www.yelp.com/biz/rouses-market-new-orleans-4#hrid:TNxLSyhrXPZCzTgmpqjeHg

And in the spirit of that review, I'm going to go with a similar formula and also show what makes Mid-City's Rouses a different shopping experience than the one in the CBD.

Why I'd opt to go to Rouses over Whole Foods:
(these are the same points as my first review, I took out a few for the sake of brevity)

1. It's Louisiana-owned
2. They have Cajun hot nuts
3. Related to the above, they have an array of other NOLA specialty items (tourists, buy your foodie souvenirs here rather than the FQ)
4. Kick ass olive bar (but just about as pricey as WF's)
5. They just have a lot more grocery items, and more affordable options at that
6. Not everything has to be gourmet specialty foods and products. They have those, but sometimes you want a bag of Zapps chips or a harsh cleaning product for eff's sake!
7. Phenomenal wine/beer selection (see my note about hard liquor below).

There is no hydrophonic rooftop garden at this one, but that's OK. What they do have that the CBD Rouses doesn't have is a larger and easier to navigate produce section. That said, the organics are still seriously lacking. And what's with the tomatoes imported from Mexico? The store is bigger and there is less of that clusterfuck feeling that you'd expect in any supermarket smack dab in the middle of downtown. 

The popcorn selection is bliss, by the way. An entire section of the snack aisle and I found those black and red popcorn types that promise all kinds of antioxidant benefits. I don't really care, though. I just wanted to buy black popcorn.

On a distressing note, I cannot believe there is an entire subcategory of Hot Pockets, as noted on the aisle sign (Ie the head category is Frozen and then below it, they have subcategories of normal stuff like pizza, vegetables, fruit etc.) I mean, Hot Pockets are a brand, not a type of food. Actually calling Hot Pockets "food" is also a stretch. Sorry, that's just my hatred of convenience foods shining through and has nothing to do with my star rating. But please, for the love of your body: Stop your Hot Pocket habit.

One thing that is really hella lame: what's with the separate counter for hard liquor? It's just terribly inconvenient and we actually skipped buying the bottle of vodka we had planned on buying because who wants to check out twice at the grocery store?

I think of all the Rouses, my favorite is the one on Tchoupitoulas, followed by Mid-City and CBD at a tie. Tchoup's location has the added bonus of the Cellar restaurant, which would make me drive the 5 miles out of the way just to get some of that veggie lasagna...

You'd think Bacchanal couldn't get any better (and a year ago, I would have agreed). Oh but it has, my cronies, it has!!!!

That newly opened upstairs is insanely idyllic! It reminds me of a hip ski lodge (well, way cooler than that). The good news is I've moved from Uptown to be closer to Bacchanal, as I threatened in my earlier reviews (OK maybe not *just* for Bacchanal, cuz that would be weird) BUT... The past few months have been pretty chilly and not great for outdoor wine sipping and cheese nibbling (if you're a warm weather lover like Yours, Truly). On the rare warm evening, we'd drive by and it seemed like it might be too crowded to get a seat, so we left.

BUT!! Now!!! There's that perfect space upstairs, with additional seating and, if you so desire, protection from the elements. 

There's also additional helpful staff (props to the super nice gal there this past Sunday evening working the wines. She helped me find a good bottle that was in my price range). Upstairs bartender was also incredibly friendly.

We had a bunch of cool Portland Elite Yelpers in town for Yelp Spring Break New Orleans and on the final evening of the weekend, I couldn't imagine *not* bringing them to one of the most awesome places in town. Perfection! And I guess even Vogue says so... But hey, I said it first (actually, Patrick G said it first and set the tone with his five star review back in '05.)

I am thoroughly charmed by Il Posto, or as I am likely to mistakenly refer to it henceforth, "Il Postino." I am *so* inspired. Now I just want to day dream at a corner table and rip off some of Pablo Neruda poems.

In all seriousness, once I stepped into this place I forgot I was in New Orleans. It was a dark and stormy day...

(yikes, that doesn't bode well. Neruda would never be prone to such cliché!)

So, let's just say that the overwhelming vibe of Il Posto is that of a rustic Italian cafe. Not unlike the cafe in the movie Il Postino. You may be overcome by the desire to just order shot after shot of espresso, but the sight and smells of the cafe's offerings will convince you to do otherwise.

I admit I'm not at all a fan of half service. I prefer to sit down and order from a server, receive food from my server, ask them for whatever else I may need, and then tip them. It's the whole anxiety of "will I get a seat after I order my food" thing, plus the fact that I just want to be served. 

Now that that's out of the way, I'll just ignore all that, because Il Posto is worth that little annoyance.

The pastry on the counter is incredibly tempting. A bite of my friend's insanely moist and decadent carrot cupcake proved that they might all live up to their expectations. 

The menu is on chalkboards above the bar. For near sighted people like me, this proves to be a bit challenging, though I understand that perhaps the menu changes frequently enough to demand it. I was undecided between a choice of two vegetarian panini and a cold sandwich with hummus, avocado and veggies on whole grain (this sounds like the perfect sandwich on a hot day).

But then I saw the antipasti and all bets were off. We split a cheese plate with all five cheeses they offer and then opted for a garden salad. The cheese plate is divine and has just the right amount of each variety, my favorites being the goat and Brie. The bread that comes with is irresistible and fresh, rather than the typical crostini. The garden salad was good, albeit not very exciting. My friend added avocado to hers and I think everyone should follow her example, though I doubt I'd order the same salad next time with all the other options.

It had been a trying afternoon. Ordering a glass of Chianti just seemed the right thing to do, yes, right in the middle of the day. After all, when in Italy...

It is with indescribable glee that I discover bars like this one. There's barely a sign to indicate you're entering a place that's open to the public (maybe a hand painted sign at the entrance and an old one in the window), and the only light is a Bud sign. It seems like it could be some creepy party dude's house or something. I only knew it was a bar because my friend lives around the corner from it.

FTR, FTR "First To Review" dancing in my head when I first set eyes on it. Damn you, Shannon S for beating me to it. But, I disagree with your two stars. 

You can count on/judge a neighborhood bar like this one two things alone: cheap a$$ prices on beer and liquor *and* a whole lotta regulars. If you don't have the former, you're probably not going to get the latter. Lots A Luck has both, I'm happy to say.

We sat down, ordered a Blue Moon and Ketel One and soda. 7 bucks. Within minutes, we were talking with a couple of the dozen or so regulars, who were mostly dudes (no overt pick-ups, which is nice) sitting at the bar. Ambiance is triple D (Joi-style) Dark, Divey and Divine.

I'll be back!

I first discovered the joys of World Market when I moved outta NYC (where there are none) and into the KC area. Look, I cannot stand chain anything for the most part, but Cost Plus World Market is like a cheaper, bigger, better version of Pier One Imports. It's a smaller, more boutiquey, more *worldly* Bed Bath and Beyond. And the grocery section, while small, is just so much cheaper than Whole Foods. So sue me. I cannot resist WOMA's charms.

I used to live quite close to one in KC and I was there an average of 2 times per week, picking up wine, candles, incense, seasoning, imported snacks, storage baskets, towels, outdoor lighting, bath products, hazelnut biscotti and more. Not to mention wickedly discounted Halloween decorations on November 1st. 

It just has all of my favorite things in one store. Even the decor is right up my alley (though admittedly, too expensive when you consider some, not all, is made in China). I move a lot and tend to stop in here for things like rugs, curtains, bamboo mats etc. 

Want to read about my purchases made on Saturday? Too bad, you're going to have to! Wine glasses, pot holders, olive oil, incense, champagne, amber colored soup bowls, pink Himalayan salt aaaaand the coup de grâce, black truffle oil. For roughly 12 dollars, the bottle I bought is twice the size of the one I bought at Whole Foods for 18 dollars (I was desperate). 

What stops it from the fifth, elusive star. I'm a member of the World Explorer club (far too many emails) and yes, I may print the coupons out, but I always forget to use them. Why not just make it a given if you, as a member (who suffers through opening and deleting all those emails) are shopping there, that you get the 10% off without having to go to the trouble of printing and remembering? One other extremely annoying thing: they sticker just about every damn item, including all the wine glasses in a box of 6! These are a bitch to remove and it makes me ballistic to have bits of sticker left on glassware. WTH? This has to stop. 

Otherwise, WOMA, I just can't quit you.

What an overall enjoyable experience. The kind of parade experience where, if you pick the right spot, you get a full view of everything without battling the masses. It's in the Marigny, which is definitely my favorite place to watch a parade. 

So, no surprise here that you're going to see the likes of Star Wars, Star Trek, and other science fiction characters that MAY, I ain't gonna lie, have gone over my head. But if you're a fan of such things, you will adore it. There are throws, sure, not of the quality and quantity of the big parades, and some of them are adult-oriented (I got some pills, lol), other things like roses and toys. The party in the Marigny surrounding this parade is also not to be missed. You can tell the folks in this parade are diehards and put a lot of time into their costumes and floats. Nothing like certain other krewes where some masked members just want to be dicks and throw bags of beads at people's heads. Here we've got nice, creative people just coming together to celebrate their nerdly love for sci fi (I'm a nerd too, I don't judge) in a parade is a wonderful thing to witness.

Pro Tip: Catch it on St. Claude for better viewing, or if you prefer to be amongst the partying crowd around Franklin, that's a great option, too.

I just adore hotel bars and even if Loa Bar isn't as grand as one of my favorites, the King Cole Room at the St. Regis (their bar snacks are macademia nuts), their cocktails are in fact, possibly better. 

I've spent many an hour in a hotel bar that gets away with expensive, but mediocre cocktails. Loa's bartenders are at the top of their craft and you'll get a drink that's on par with any that you'd get at, say Cure or Tonique. Check out all the curious garnishes, herbs, bitters, shrubs and spirits (sitting at the bar is where it's at, btw. I recently sat in the terribly chic lounge area and it just wasn't the same). It's like a lush drink laboratory. 

The cocktail menu is impressive. I've tried a bunch of different drinks and they were all top notch, yet I'm afraid I can't give you specifics. Note to self: next time pay closer attention.

Lilly's about saved my life last week! With temps dropping to the point of actual *icicles* forming, I still had to be out and about (not such a bad thing as pretty much anywhere is going to be warmer than my old drafty house) and although our intention was to get one of the amazing salads at nearby HiVolt, all I had to do was walk by Lilly's and change my mind because... well, vegan phó. 

Some of you are going to stop reading right here and that's OK, I don't blame you. I'm pretty certain that meaty phó is a whole other ballgame, what with the meat drippings seeping into the soup and adding that bit of unctuousness you're never going to get with a vegan version. But there I was freezing cold and do you know how hard it is to get a big bowl of vegetarian soup in this city?

Started with the spring rolls, because I can't ever pass those up. Vietnamese spring rolls are in my top 20 things to eat, seriously. And then came the enormous bowls of soup that warmed our souls that chilly afternoon. Flavor is light and I have to add tons of spice (wish they had sambal chili paste rather than sugary Sri Racha, just a note), but dang if that soup didn't make the rest of the day and frigid night bearable. 

And it was crazy cheap, too. Lunch for 2 (both of us had spring rolls and phó) was less than $30. True story.

Add in the sweetest, most attentive service (our waitress told us we "did good" as she took the bowls away) and Lilly's is definitely one of my favorite lower magazine eateries.

Whenever I find myself wallowing in the miasma of ostalgie (or in need of a stiff drink), I find myself here, my favorite bar in New Orleans (hello, I'm the Duchess), so clearly I need to update a review so woefully out of date. 

On a recent Sunday late afternoon visit, the bar toasted a half paralyzed 55-year-old woman who headed here straight out of rehab. She later came out to the courtyard to drink with us (don't worry. She was sticking to one absinthe/champagne cocktail) and proceeded to tell us her life story. That this is kind of par for the course in New Orleans is really no matter and still indicative of just how special Pravda! is. Whether tying one on with a friend or six, or sulking in a dark corner with a glass of Malbec, this is where I choose to go more than anywhere else in town.

Oh Pravda! Yes yes yes, Pravda! I'm so glad you have an exclamation point. It makes all the difference between you and that plain ol' Pravda (sans punctuation) in New York City. You're my bar, my blood, my bitch.

Hey, I got everything I wanted out of my service today at Walker Volkswagen and then some! I went in fearing the worst (look at the reviews), but was encouraged when I saw that a manager had responded to a review saying they were managing a major overhaul with customer service. He didn't lie! I was taken care of immediately by a friendly customer service consultant, Rita Day who was all around perfect. She handled my questions/problems swiftly and was extremely engaging and transparent about everything from estimated time (90 minutes) to what my extended warranty would take care of. Hell, she even advised us where we could get a cup of coffee (Starbucks right across the street, although she kindly informed us that they have an array of complimentary coffee, soft drinks and snacks in their waiting area). She even offered us a ride across Veterans to Starbucks! What more can you ask from a customer service representative, really? Oh and she called me with a price estimate as soon as they assessed the issues.

In the end, I won't dread having to take care of my car's problems anymore. I won't drive for 9 months with a donut tire. I won't drive for 4 months with a blown out headlight. I might even get my oil changed more than once every 14 months (well, I can go anywhere for that. Just illustrating how I let my car problems go unsolved for so long).

Another nice little bit of lagniappe: complimentary car wash and vacuum with your service!

Hey, before "rolling your own," know this...

By "illegal" I suppose what they really are referring to are the sizes. Jaysus!!!! I witnessed a grown man unable to finish the "small" burrito. Kinda ridic, but hey, people love them their infant-sized burritos. Or so they think. Do yourself a favor. Your eyes really are bigger than your stomach. Know your limits.

I had every intention of ordering a burrito after getting a glimpse of all the fresh ingredients, but then was plagued by thoughts of days of yore... When scarfing down a burrito for brunch meant not needing to eat for the rest of the day. I didn't want that going on with a scant few hours of being awake ahead of me, so I passed and had some of their better-than-decent guacamole instead. If you get it as a side order, it comes in a largish bowl (of course it's large, what isn't there?). Overall, I was very impressed with the burrito assembly line going on here. You really can get whatever you want in there. You can even get a BOWL if you, uh, don't wanna ROLL YOUR OWN. Muahahhahahaha

Come to think of it, I actually can't recall the last time I had a burrito... Possibly a sad affair from a local joint about a year and a half ago. No matter how good it smells/tastes, it just never seems worth the belly bomb.

Maybe some day. I'd do worse than return here!

Add me to the scores of believers... I mean fans. I live close to Creole Creamery and yet I only recently tried it. Probably for that very reason. I don't think I'll be the same again after this. Luckily I exhibit a fair degree of self control. The cruelest irony that ice cream season coincides with swimsuit season. WHATEV, right?

So, this is the best ice cream I have ever had. Want some cockamamie never-hear-of-before flavors (Green Fairy, anyone?) They've got that here. Die hard traditionalist? They've got you covered (anything from vanilla to butter pecan). Diabetic? There's both an ice cream and a special sundae for you. Can't have dairy? While I didn't see any soy or nut ice creams, they do have sorbet. On a diet? Well, then, I'm afraid you're SOL. There's a kiddie cup, but it's for the kids only. Their small cup *probably* won't kill you too much, though.

First visit had me sampling my friend's choice: red velvet cake. While not a fan of red velvet cake, I can't deny this ice cream brings it to a whole new level. Instead of being merely red velvet flavored ice cream, it's got bits of red velvet cake throughout. Scream-worthy, right?

Second visit, I came with a mission: to try four flavors via the 4 scoop sample (you get 4 small scoops for $4. A bargain, no?) My choices: sweet corn with raspberry and black peppercorn, Green Fairy, butterscotch butter pecan, and blueberry pie, my favorites being the latter two, however I wouldn't throw the other two out of bed... I mean the bowl. Green Fairy wins the creative award because I'd never think to have absinthe-flavored ice cream! It also has bittersweet chocolate and orange peels, which make for a really tasty, unique concoction. My only issue is that I'm not a fan of chocolate bits in ice cream, otherwise, I'd be all over this. Butterscotch butter pecan brings a bit of a more intense, grown up twist to an old timey classic (I had to wonder if there's booze in it). Blueberry pie... sigh. Just perfect. I need a moment alone with it. Perhaps even a year. The sweet corn is a bit too overpowered by the peppercorns and could stand to have more raspberry, in my opinion. That's the *only* criticism I'd have. With all those flavor choices, who cares? Oh and feel free to sample if you're on the fence (but obey the sign: don't be a sample hog).

The best thing about this ice cream is that it's not crazy sweet. I realize that sounds ridiculous, but it's true. Take the salted caramel, for example (I know you will). I tried my friend's and was quite taken with it. I love the idea of salted caramel but I've had that flavor before at other places and found it sickeningly sweet- not at all salty. Creole Creamery has somehow managed to achieve just the right balance of flavor.

And so, I bid Creole Creamery farewell... meaning in this review. Already planning what flavors I'm going to try next visit. Hey, it's ice cream season, don't you know?

Stop the presses: it's finally happened: I've found my nail salon in New Orleans, friends!

If you've read any of my reviews for spas/salons (Buff is more than just a nail salon), you'll notice that I have serious pedi anxiety. As in, it's generally something I do because I *have* to, not because I *want* to (I mean, living in a city where 10 months out of the year it's warm means for maximum foot exposure. And I'm prone to peelin' heels). What I appreciate here is that you have the mini pedi option (ie, they do away with the unbearable-to me-foot massage and it's about 10 minutes quicker), and instead of overbearing "massage chairs" (sorry, more like torture devices), there's a comfy cushioned bench that runs along the wall. 

So, there goes the pedi phobia.

Other stuff:
-a glass of red, white or Champagne offered upon arrival (and what's more, it's good! We're not talking cheap box stuff, but bottles from local purveyors, Keife & Co. Just one of the little extras that sets Buff apart from the competition)
-fabulous color selection in both regular polish and gel
-competitive prices with other salons in town, while at the same time offering a superior environment and services
-no technicians making fun of you to their coworkers in other languages (c'mon, you know they do)
-on that note, very nice technicians that are easy to talk to

and most importantly: Kim gave me the very best gel manicure I've received, possibly ever. It was evenly painted, did not at all peel off (so common when you have tiny nail beds like I do, not to mention super short nails) and I didn't see my nasty jagged cuticles again for at least a week. 

Oh, and can I just mention how in love I am with the ORIGINAL tile floor? It's just lovely.

Can't wait to go back for more and try their other fabulous services (facials, blowouts and waxing).

I can't leave this review at 4 stars. Nope, Mint is a straight-up five.

Five for the lychee mojito. Five for the creative cocktail menu featuring an array of tropical Thai flavors!

Five for the friendly, attentive servers.

Five for those divine avocado rolls, bursting with fragrant herbs, chewy vermicelli noodles and silken avocado (dipped into peanut sauce reminiscent of manna from heaven).

Five for the lemongrass tofu. This is the best I've ever had! It's crunchy/sweet/slightly spicy and the tofu texture is chewy rather than spongy. It is featured in the soups, rice/noodle bowls and banh mí.

Five for the enormous bowls, bursting with the aforementioned incredible lemongrass tofu (so many places skimp on this!), vermicelli noodles, crunchy fresh veggies & herbs. If you're vegetarian, they'll substitute peanut sauce for the fish sauce that normally comes with.

Pro tip: arrive hungry or take home the rest of your dinner so that you can have a delicious lunch tomorrow! Confession: I ate every single bit of my food (spring rolls and noodle bowl) and this made me want to go home and relax rather than get started on my night out on the town. And you know what? It was worth it.

I love this place and I need to come here more often. That's a promise, Mint!

My new favorite hotel in New Orleans. I'm an Omni loyalty guest at the highest level, yet I'll never again stay at one of the three Omnis in town (even with the promise of upgrades) because now that I've stayed at the Ace, I am ruined. Ruined, I tell you.

A stuffy corporate cookie cutter room just isn't going to ever cut it again when the promise of dark walls, vintage fridges and turntables with charmingly worn records are waiting for me! I believe the room I stayed in was a medium size (ie, not the smallest, not the biggest, not a suite). I absolutely adored it and wished I was staying longer than merely one night. Comfy bed, delicious bath products, space for dancing... What a unique space! I didn't indulge, but appreciated the variety at the mini bar (nice prices too. What?!) December weekday rates are so so incredibly fair, I don't see how anyone could opt to AirBnB it. Naturally when it's high season, rates will comparable with other hotels, however their group rates always seem the fairest in town and I book groups on the regular.

There's a dark and slightly mysterious theme going on throughout the hotel. Rather than old timey Southern style, which is kind of the NOLA hotel thing traditionally, the Ace is designed in the style of a wealthy artist, movie mogul or musician's mansion in the late 1930s... perhaps in Manhattan or Havana. I know, I know. I may not be making sense. I wasn't around in the 1930s (but I kind of wish I was). It's a little too much verging on, but not quite, Mid Century, and definitely post Art Deco (just not TOO post...) I suck at describing the things I love.
 
The bar area... I just never ever want to leave it! Between some of the best bartenders in town (not to mention super friendly, no matter how packed it is), the comfortable sofas, and lighting so perfect, you feel like a movie star... oh and the cocktails don't hurt either. I stuck to bubbly but tasted some of the other concoctions and was truly impressed. Then there's the sitting area just beyond Stumptown Coffee. They recently redecorated it and it's one of most hauntingly beautiful spots in town. Go see for yourself.

Do I need to touch upon the rooftop pool area? It's a popular spot in town. I've spent many an early evening here sipping on frozen goodness in the summer. Now I hear it's heated in the winter, but I foolishly didn't check it out.

The Ace Hotel is my favorite in town, whether I'm staying here or just popping by to visit. I declare a deep, deep love for the brand.

Three Muses = trifecta of booze, music and food. Add me to your long list of fans, Three Muses! 

When you think about it, they could probably get away with serving less than fantastic food. Many venues do! Three Muses puts as much attention and love into their food and drink as they do their bookings and this is how they are in a league of their own. Each time I've been here, I've been pretty blown away by what I've ordered (last night's tofu bulgogi being the best of the best!) Don't be deceived by a modest-sounding menu. The plates are small, but contain mucho deliciousness. You know what they say about too much of a good thing, right? That said, this is the kind of place you don't come starving after not eating all day (like last night). Besides the flavorful and light bulgogi, I also dig the edamame which comes in sesame oil. Falafel balls are amongst the best I've had, however I think they could use a lot more tahini (unless it was left off by accident. I couldn't taste any).

Cocktails. Last night's drinks were both a hit and a miss for me. The absinthe drink is described beautifully on the menu but the flavors described just did not come through. It really just tasted like absinthe. The lavender lace, OTOH, I could have drank all night. Champagne plus lavender? Oh hells yeah.

Music. What can I say? They book great stuff here. Each time I've been, I enjoyed the acts immensely. You'll get the quintessential jazz club experience. 

Service is friendly and if the bartender is able, will keep coming back to check on your table if you need drinks. A personal preference would be to have full table service, as I don't like ordering at the bar. Since they don't do separate checks, this requires one person from your party to go up and give in your entire order. It's just awkward if you're with more than one other person. That's about the only thing that makes this four instead of five stars for me. 

Bonus points, however, for that awesome blonde gal working the door and seating your party!

Tiki Tolteca has changed so much since my last review (being that I was FTR AHEM)! Although Beachbum Barry's is my ride or die, Tiki Tolteca has good vibes and good times in droves and although my guy had to be dragged here by friends the other night (he's been anti Tiki Tolteca since we were turned away around three times when they were seemingly having more private parties than nights open. But that was years ago), we all had a round + a pretty awesome time.

It's a Polynesian tropical paradise up in here! Get yo'selves upstairs above Felipe's and feel like you've stumbled into a perfectly preserved Mid Century Tiki Time Warp. From the ubiquitous giant glass orbs dropped from the ceiling encased in fish nets to the bamboo thatched walls to the Tiki totems and rattan furniture (couches, booths and high boys). It's pretty dang perfect. Even if the drinks sucked, I'd be happy here because this is so my jam.

What else has changed since the early days of five years ago? That menu sure has expanded. Tiki drinks galore! I had a Pain Killer and believe me, I wasn't feeling any after that one (understatement of the year). 

One thing I'm going to admit may be a draw for some people, but not so much for me is the giant TV playing sports. It clashes with the vibe big time, but hey, it's football season and that's definitely going to be a draw for most people.

Also that 11pm close time is a bit of a drag. On the bright side it's open 'til 2am on weekends.

One of the cool things about Suis Generis is that because the menu changes on the regular, I get to update my reviews on the regular!

I had dinner here on Friday night and there were two vegetarian options: a house-made gorgonzola ricotta baked pumpkin seed ravioli with asiago-parmesean cream sauce & asparagus AND a Burmese noodle bowl with organic baby bok choi, bamboo shoots & miso-ginger broth. I went for the latter because although the former piqued my interest (and my love for all things pumpkin seed), I figured it would be overkill with the "Fabulous Mezze Plate" (doesn't that sound like something I'd write on my own? But it's their words, not mine) that I also ordered. So much cheese, y'know? While one might think you can't have too much of a good thing, well that one wouldn't be me because you sure as hell can have too much of a good thing when it comes to foods that are rich and decadent.

A note on the mezze plate: It is, indeed, fabulous. It, too, changes so while I can go on about how that double-aged Beemster X-O North Holland Gouda got my taste buds in the throes of passion, you may not get that on your Fabulous Mezze Plate next week. You can trust the fine folks at Suis Generis to pick out other excellent cheeses, however. I'm sure of it.

A note on the Burmese Noodle Bowl: It's damn delicious. So, if they have noodle bowls on future menus, go for it. There was a ton of ginger in there. Seriously, at least a 3 inch fat root chopped up. I ate it all. I love ginger.

A note on Suis Generis' plates and glasses: they make me feel like I'm at a party happening in the late 60s or early 70s. I expect fondue to be served at any minute. 

I love Suis Generis for the food, but I also just love the atmosphere. I love how at night they dim the lights and throw on the fake fire places and disco balls so that you feel like you're in the super cool rec room of some hip teenager circa 1970. It's intimate enough to be perfect for a date and friendly enough so that you can easily come in and eat alone. 5 stars! And read my earlier review about their Bellinis...

It's been almost 8 years since I last visited and reviewed Muriel's.

I think I've resigned myself to the fact that this is just going to be one of those places that I visit for atmosphere and history, rather than for a phenomenal food. They just don't really seem to be inspired to do anything approaching creative nor outstanding for their vegan and vegetarian customers. It's a traditional kind of place and that is agreeable to a lot of people.

The restaurant really is lovely and the service is also excellent. Dare I say I just need more these days? I'd expect something a bit more interesting after 8 years.

So. You'll get a salad with the whatever-makes-it-more-than-just lettuce left off. You'll get a tasty, if unexciting, pasta with vegetable entree. I don't believe there were any dessert options.

I'll be back for wine at the bar and to soak in the beautiful surroundings

Where do I start? Angie and her crew are legit lifesavers. I use them 1-2X per week for a short term rental. But let me first tell you how my relationship with them began.

Three years ago, my regular cleaners told me that they could no longer work with me (moving out of town). I interviewed a few companies, but Angie really impressed me because I could tell she was organized and committed to providing a top notch service. At the same time, however, I had a friend who cleaned homes and was in need of a job, so I alternated between her and Angie's crew. Angie always could help me out in a pinch and her cleaners are super fast but very thorough (the benefit of having a team of cleaners rather than one person of course). I used her services sporadically throughout the past three years and she always came through for me, even tried her best when she was completely booked. This is crucial when you are relying on income from a STR and need last minute reservations when they come through.

When my friend gave her notice this past spring, I actually felt like it was going to be ok, because I had a company that had proven themselves to be dependable and loyal to their customers. Angie and her crew have been my regular cleaners ever since and will be henceforth! The best!

Birthday dinner at Muriel's? Yes, please!

It's so hard to settle on just one place for your big night, so my guy made the decision for me. That's nice for a change as you can imagine I'm always being asked to make the choices by friends and family.

My experience was again good, but not 5-star excellent, given the caliber of the restaurant. It was a Saturday night and the restaurant was reasonably filled, as it was Carnival season and getting close to the big day. My issue was with the lighting. I'm of the mind that at nighttime, unless you're at a diner or fast food joint (and that would be *never* for me), lights should be dimmed and the candles brought out. Not so at Muriel's. Some people hate dimly lit restaurants, so have at it if this is you! 

Another thing, and this is more of a criticism of my fellow Americans than anything: Muriel's doesn't have dress requirements like some of our fancier joints in town, but really, when you go out to a *nice* restaurants with table cloths and a typical bill for 2 is over $100 can you please make an effort?! Or how's this, please don't wear shorts and T-shirts. Or worn out jeans. At least the hostess made the guy take off his baseball cap. On that note, this "no hats" rule seems at odds with the fact that they let the table of 4 slobs in anyway. A brightly lit restaurant filled with tables of bachelorette parties (I saw no less than 4 tables of ladies on the prowl) wearing silly wigs and hats do not for a romantic dinner out make. If they are going to ask that gentlemen remove hats (and I get that, even if the hat is a really nice one), it seems they should stay consistent with a more refined vibe. No?

Now that *that* is out of the way...

I started with the wood-grilled Eggplant Reloude. *Incroyable!!!!! So good that I needed to exclaim in French. The eggplant is perfectly grilled and is sweet/smoky with delicioso (see? I did it again) ricotta/marscapone inside and topped with a bit of tomato sauce. Perfetto. (stop, Joi, just stop).

As I mentioned in my previous review, Muriel's main nod to vegetarians is with a seasonal "Vegetarian Soiree" entree. I appreciate the seasonality but last year's vegetable plate was much much better than this year's - I visited during the same season, winter. This time there was a so-so mushroom crepe rather than polenta. There was no kale. There was inedible eggplant that was tough/bitter/chewy. Pickled cucumbers. Pedestrian spaghetti squash. In fact, it was altogether unmemorable to the point that I had to just look at the menu to remember what was on it so I could write this review. Not bad, just nowhere nearly as impressive as last year. Give us vegetarians at least one other exciting option, perhaps? A vegetarian tasting menu? Dare to dream...

On the other hand, that butterscotch pudding dessert was birthday bliss-worthy.

So, there you have it. Five star lunch combined with a 2.5 star dinner (five star service and decor) means just hanging in there at 4 stars. I'm still a fan of this legendary and beautiful French Quarter restaurant. I think, however, I'll stick to having extravagant lunches here rather than dinner.

Lots of pluses for Pals! I could go on about the drinks (seasonal cocktail menu in a diveish bar that you need to be ringed into? Yes, Please!) and the fact that there's just something so cool about ordering champagne in this kind of setting. But let's get down to the nitty gritty.

+That men's room. Oh you better believe I pranced myself right on in to see the nude chick hall o'fame. Seems like Pal's has a thing for well-endowed girls of the 60s and 70s judging by what's up there.
-and who do the ladies get? Burt Reynolds?! I think it's a Playgirl shot. Whatever it is, it's just unappealing. Again with the 70s. Or maybe that's the 80s. Either way, I must be the wrong demographic b/c I definitely have no interest in seeing Burt Reyond's wang. Come to think of it, I may be blocking it out, but his wang might not even be visible. That thick carpet of chest hair, OTOH... Mondo trauma. 
+I love the curved staircase leading up to the ladies. I just don't like who's waiting for m in there. 
+bar snacks. Pretzels and champagne? Helllls yeah. Dinner of champions.

"Why can't oral surgeons adorn their space so it resembles that of your favorite day spa? Wouldn't that be cool?" I mused as everything slowly faded to black. But first I laughed because of course this is what I'm thinking as I'm going under. Aesthetics. They are uber important!

I was referred to Dr. Loyola by my regular dentist at Mid-City Smiles. I'll be honest and say I had misgivings when I walked into what could only be called a dreary waiting room (it's tiny, without windows). I was called into yet another dark, slightly sinister room (I was scared like a baby and I have a terrific imagination. C'mon, laugh with me here) and then realized it had to be this way because, X-rays. But come on, at least make the waiting room inviting?

OK, so I realize how ridiculous this all sounds. The *good* news? Getting my tooth pulled here was 10X more seamless than it was when I got my last one pulled elsewhere three years ago (I'll spare you the horror story). Dr. Loyola had me in and out in about 30 minutes. Can you believe that? I was terrified about going under with anesthesia as last time, I just received novocaine. And that, was horrible, so it didn't take much convincing. My last dentist couldn't get my bottom tooth out (after 20 minutes of yanking. I guess I can't totally spare you from that horror story), and so recommended that I go to a surgeon. Dr. Loyola told me that it's pretty common for the bottom teeth to be more difficult. He was also honest and said that I should just spare myself enduring the procedure while conscious. 

One other thing: he was also honest that the source of my pain could be due to something else (namely, clenching and grinding my teeth) and said that I didn't necessarily have to get the tooth out. I appreciate being conservative rather than "just get it yanked, you don't need it" philosophy that's all the rage these days, but I knew it had to go and I was right. 

Getting put under was not quite fun (I have these veins that are difficult to tap into) but what I did like was that it was almost twilight-y (not of the glitter and teenaged vampire variety) and I wasn't entirely unconscious. I didn't feel any pain, though I guess I was moving a lot b/c I recall being reprimanded a bit by the doctor. He's more stern than jokey, but whatever. The tooth. Is. Gone.

The reason for three stars? Their billing policy is utterly absurd and unheard of (to me, at least). Get this: even though my insurance covers anesthesia, I had to lay out the 300+ dollars *just in case they didn't.* What kind of BS is that? Oh and the clincher? The ridiculous % surcharge for using your CC. Because surely it makes sense to carry almost 400 dollars in cash around with you for dental services. It's unacceptable and I won't return here for that reason alone (it cost me well over 30 dollars for the "convenience"). I realize you've been burned by patients before but that doesn't exactly instill confidence in your professionalism. I've been to two other dentists in NOLA and they always bill you later if your insurance doesn't cover a procedure.

So, that's that. I'd give only two stars for the ridiculous payment policy but I was rather impressed by my practically pain and discomfort-free extraction (and that's probably what you really need to care about). Plus the ladies who assist and work the reception are really nice. And yes, I did receive a check from them right away after they were paid by my insurance. This was a month after the procedure was done and I can survive without that 350 dollars in my account but not everyone is that lucky. 

Oh and another positive note: the room where you get your surgery done is practically cheery, with big windows!

I've met the banh mí that I want to marry and live happily ever after with!

I shamefully admit that for a while now, I've been kinda meh about banh mí in general. I'd listen to people go on and on about them and was skeptical. I've found that in my experience, there's too much bread and flavorless filler stuff and not enough "meat" (OK, tofu). But now that I've met Lilly's, I've seen the light... These are some serious sandwiches! They aren't shy with the protein and what makes this sandwich more flavorful is that they slice the tofu up really thin before marinating and frying up in what I believe is lemongrass and various spices. Add on some soy sauce and super-tangy but flavorful slaw and you've got the best damn banh mí this vegetarian has ever had. It's also large (think: 6" po boy) and at a very fair price. 

Need something a little heartier and/or hotter? Veg heads take note: there are loads of vegan options (including pho). Fantastic spring rolls that have both tofu *and* avocado. Bun. They love us, they really love us!

My days of bemoaning the fact that I can't fulfill a cheap Chinese craving here in NOLA are over. I really do not care AT ALL when there's far healthier and more delicious Vietnamese to be had.

Let's say you're looking for a creepy Victorian-era baby portrait in an oval frame with curved glass...

Hey, don't judge. One of these can really add freaky flair to a wall.

Magazine Antique mall has the best collection of creepy Victorian portraits I've ever seen and I've been to many an antique mall. There's one of a lady that is positively bone-chilling (and I don't mean one of those silly fake hologram deals where the 'normal' portrait turns into a grinning wraith). 

This is also a place where you can find a decent amount of vintage Mardi Gras throws (Czech glass beads) and other memorabilia (like a framed poster from 1986... which is *not* an antique, OK? Just sayin'). 

I like this place and if I ever had an extra 125.00, I'd buy one of those aforementioned portraits. Thing is, the prices here are fairly higher than I am used to spending. Y'know I'll say it time and time again, I blame shows like American Pickers for ruining it for the rest of us. That said, my boyfriend picked up a stellar piece of religious folk art, also in an oval frame with curved glass that was marked half off for some bizarre reason. I hope it's not haunted. No, seriously. There are such things- haunted paintings. Google it. And if you wish to be able to sleep tonight, do NOT Google haunted Victorian dolls. There's a seller on Ebay who is truly disturbed, as she fabricates an entire fucked-up story about the dead child who is haunting the dolls. Not for the faint-hearted.

Haven't I made your day now?

Truth: I love Vietnamese food so much, I could eat it daily. I'm a regular at Lilly's Cafe in the LGD because they have such an incredible variety of vegan dishes and it's insanely cheap. That said, the ambiance lends itself better to lunch (not to mention they close at 9pm and sometimes that's dinner time for me). To add to that, they don't have a bar. This year for my birthday dinner, I wanted Vietnamese food and I wanted a cocktail or two... enter Mint.

First of all there's the name conjuring up both minty goodness served alongside a giant bowl of bun or pho and the impression that this place is *mint*. I've wanted to try it since it opened last year, although it's on the other side of town from where I live and I know it gets really packed on weekends.

Ambiance: more spiffy, more... mint than Lilly's, with their mirrors, modern furniture and chandeliers, not to mention a large bar. I'm not too crazy about how bright it is in there and definitely not a fan of the huge TVs, but that didn't detract from all the other greatness going on... like the food and the cocktail I soon had in my hands (I can ignore TVs, but it's funny how the child next to me was transfixed on the Simpsons as soon as he sat down. We need less TVs in restaurants, world!). 

Getting back to the cocktail: Mint Iced Tea. GET. IT. On this warm Sunday in February (75 degrees in the evening!), I couldn't resist a taste of summer and even though I typically detest sweetened tea, this drink is on point! I can easily see myself throwing back three of these on a porch somewhere. It goes just as well with the avocado spring rolls I ordered, however. These spring rolls are now my favorite in town, because they are just bursting with fresh ingredients, like mint, avo, carrots, sprouts and vermicelli. Dip these babies into that perfect peanut sauce that comes with. So so so good! 

Veg heads get happy for there are options a-plenty. I can't refuse a bowl of bun, and there is a lemongrass tofu option that is brimming over with tofu and vermicelli noodles. Lilly's has an option to add veggies to that, so next time I'll ask if that's possible here because it could only make this better! The lemongrass tofu is spectacularly tasty, with a texture that is crunchy on the outside and slightly firm on the in. Herbs and hot sauce only serve to heighten the fresh flavor that's going on up in here! (side note: please keep those Sri Racha bottles clean... the nozzle had that unsightly crust going on that makes me kind of ill to consider).
