Dessert? Not for me, as I was far too full. I couldn't even manage a second cocktail (my typical dessert, truth be told). Portions are enormous, but the food quality and freshness do not suffer. I'm adding Mint to my regular rotation, especially when in Uptown and needing a restaurant that's both affordable and on the nice, not-too-fancy side.

First to review this store that I haven't been able to forget since I last visited four long years ago? OH YES!!

I used to be a regular patron of Mystic Curio, which was located a few stores down from Erzulies on Royal. RIP Mystic Curio! Four years ago, Erzulies had the last precious stock of oils from Mystic Curio, which I believe closed right around the time of Katrina (I understand the owner is happily retired in Florida).

Sadly, the oils no longer exist, and Mystic Curio's owner remains a cherished memory (he'd pull out an oil to recommend to you after talking to you for just a few minutes...my favorites were Musk Royale, Voodoo Nights, Black Rose and Cleopatra). But  Erzulies' oils deliver! 

There is a fabulous woman (maybe the owner) who greets you as soon as you pass the threshold. She is there to answer any questions you may have and suggest various fragrances. I think she has a sixth sense and can tell what scent will work for you not unlike the owner of Mystic Curio. There's a fair amount of variety to choose from, but I zeroed in on my favorite, which I had run out of, as well as a newer oil that she showed me.

You can also get readings here as well as various other esoteric needs fulfilled. It need be reiterated that the owner is so friendly and approachable that you feel you can ask any question, no matter how clueless you are. I think it's important for one to feel comfortable with the occult (rather than frightened, that is). Nothing intimidating here! Pure white magic in the best sense of the word. 

I have no doubt you will walk out of here just as satisfied as I have been on my past two visits.

Review by a coffee fiend...

True, when one is fiending, you might think any ol' bean extraction would suffice, but I'm no coffee whore. I'd gladly suffer the headache rather than swallow down some weak swill.

Envie's got the goods. The espresso drinks are buzz-worthy here (don't ask me about their drip. Don't ever ask me about drip). What's more, you can add booze to 'em! Do it! I have... one fierce hurricane afternoon. The occasion called for it. It was during Hurricane Isaac (this was about the only good coffeehouse open in the area). No one had power in their house for days. Most people were skipping work. And most people seemed to be at Envie. They kindly set up power strips and extension cords and it was like a Social Media Palooza going on in there. Because of course Facebook and Twitter is vital at a time like this. As is a giant, sweet, cold boozy coffee drink.

The bubble tea gods have smiled upon us here in New Orleans! 

Although I know you can get bubble tea at various Vietnamese restaurants in the city, sometimes you just want a quick grab & go plastic cup of blended frozen deliciousness STAT. If I worked in the area, I'd definitely stop into Honeydeux on the regular, especially during those times when I'm on a coffee hiatus (rare, but it happens).

Their menu features a decent variety of flavors from fruity to tea-based and if you're allergic to super sugary concoctions like I am, you can get them to adjust that, as well. I went for a blended Thai iced tea version and it's pretty on-point. The consistency of the pearls is excellent, although flavor-wise, they could be a *touch* sweeter and less pasty-tasting. It didn't detract from the extremely delicious Thai iced tea, however and I'm definitely a fan.

Although Honeydeux is more of a take-out kind of place, they also have a decent seating area, with a comfortable loungey area up front that's nice to work at, especially if, say, the closest coffeeshops are packed with people.

For my 1100th review, I review the iconic Muriel's Jackson Square, one of the loveliest restaurant/event spaces in New Orleans. I first attended a wedding here on Halloween 2010. My two fabulous friends pulled out all the stops and had an amazing horror movie-themed wedding where Jason and Leatherface got things started with a bang (er, a chainsaw). Sure seems like the folks behind Muriels worked well with my friends and the wedding was an occasion to remember. We were upstairs, where private events are held, and took breaks from the main room in the bordello-like seance room. One of my favorite things about this night included hanging out with cocktails on huge balcony overlooking Jackson Square. 

By the way, if you're dining here and there isn't an event going on, you're free to go upstairs and check all that out. You can even have a drink and bring it up to the Seance Room (and I strongly recommend that you do, if you like rooms dripping in red, chandeliers, velvet and brocade. It makes me want to decorate my entire apartment in a similar fashion). 

Recently I came to realize that besides the gorgeous environs, the restaurant serves up some really great food and drink. My friends and I had lunch here recently. We were seated in the room where they open the huge glass doors to the sidewalk so you can watch passersby and listen to music being played out in Jackson Square. 

At lunchtime, they offer $4 Bloody Marys, wines and martinis. I indulged in a Bloody Mary, as I am often wont to do, and found it to be quite satisfactory (garnished with olives, pickled green beans and citrus and served in a pint glass. No skimping here just cuz it's a mere 4 bucks). 

I ordered the modestly-named Vegetable Plate. I'll be honest and say I wasn't expecting much because I've had many a pedestrian veg plate where they barely even marinate the vegetables before skewering them and grilling. Booooring. 

I'm thrilled to report that Muriel's Vegetable Plate belongs in the Vegetable Plate Hall of Fame. First of all, it contains braised kale. Almost 'nuff said there, but I'll go on to say its flavor is just so so so very good. The other star of the plate is that compact square of polenta flavored with herbs and Parm cheese. Everything is so delicately placed, which I love, and nothing overwhelmed with oils or heavy sauces to "make up for" the fact that you're eating a plate of vegetables. There's a delightful little bit of everything from beets to parsnips to tender shittake mushrooms. A healthy, hearty plate. Thank you, Muriels! I seriously could not stop thinking about it all day.

They also have a gluten-free menu.

I think I'll be dining here on the regular when I have visitors in town. It's just the perfect place to take them when they want the quintessential French Quarter dining experience.

Yes, you're reading this correctly: I, Joi B, mostly raw vegan chick, not only went willingly to a steak house, but I'm giving this steak house 5 glorious stars, yo!

It's old school as you can get. The kind of place where even someone like Yours, Truly, is compelled to order a steak and a martini. While that didn't actually happen, what I did order made me extremely happy, not to mention the attentive and friendly service, and the environment within this boisterous old jernt. 

My friends and I got in on one of those fabulous curtained booths. I love private booths, what can I say? So, they had me there. I was dubious about what I'd be served here, I can't lie. And I was ragingly hungry after having worked up quite the appetite at the ostrich and zebra races earlier (yes, yes, I realize I was not a very good vegetarian on Saturday. I might as well have worn leather shoes while I was at it. Oh wait...)

A perusal of the menu had me ordering sides of spinach, mushrooms and German potatoes. I also indulged in some of my friends' garlic bread, though I've pretty much sworn off all kinds of white bread. It was impossible to resist because seriously, this garlic bread is perfection, pure comfort food and like I said, I was starvin' marvin.

And I had a glass of wine, a decent pinot noir (they have a very respectable list of wines by the bottle and glass). 

And then I gorged on the side orders I mention above. Whereas I expected reheated dishes of frozen monstrosities, I received: *fresh* baby spinach leaves, *fresh* whole mushrooms  and freshly sliced/flash fried potato rounds. Granted the spinach had been sauteed in butter, but not overly so, and the mushrooms were served in a butter broth (oh come on, like who the hell could resist that?), but it wasn't overpowering. I prefer olive oil to butter any day, but this restaurant is, like I said, old school, and hey, they treat vegetables right! I ate all of it. ALL. Of. It.

After dinner, I commenced upon cigars and brandy.

I'm going to start off this review with an exclamation: Hallelujah! I've found a hotel that *has it all*. I felt so privileged to be staying at this top-notch property and that's pretty remarkable, seeing as I typically have found some fault with just about any hotel I've stayed in.

When thinking of how to describe the style of hotel, the words "casual luxury" comes to mind. It doesn't have the glitz & glamah of the Four Seasons, nor is it tragically hip like the W Hotels (read: no glowing Buddhas in the room). 

Think: sophisticated, yet approachable. No bells & whistles. No parading ducks. No fountains, nor waterfalls. No Buddhas glowing in your hotel room. No dance music in the lobby and no suits on the make in the hotel bar. It actually makes me think of how hotels might have been in the 1960s (though it does not have a consciously retro vibe or look). Classy!!!

There's a complimentary wine hour. There's art that's not trying too hard. There's comfy couches and shiny wood floors (slight criticism that they need to avoid the orange oil as I almost took a spill a few times).

Not for a minute do they skimp on the amenities you'd expect (bathrobes, killer bath products, amazing rain showers, sumptuous beds), and then some (turn down service with ice, chocolates and bottles of water) 

Espresso machines in the hallway are a nice touch seeing as I don't like drip coffee (there are drip machines in the room, if you so desire). I hit these up periodically throughout the day. The gym is a step above any hotel gym that I've used before, with complimentary bottles of water, headphones, green apples and towels for your convenience. I used it three times during my five days, which made it AOK for me to indulge in those damn fancy peanut butter cups and chocolate turtles the housekeeper left on my pillow every night. 

The staff, from front desk to concierge to valet is superb (and I might add, quite easy on the eyes. Hells yes, you can help me with my suitcase, kind sir!) I swear, I did not purposely leave my purse in the cab so that I could rely on the help of the valet to retrieve it for me... *bats eyes*... but I can't say I regretted it either.

Hutton Hotel, I can't imagine how you could be better. I want to return to Nashville just so that I can stay here again.

Soooo, it's like this:

Now I have to decide what's the lesser of two driving evils: Uptown or Metairie for my WF needs (I have such needs on the regular). I swear, I've inherited my father's utter surlitude (TM) when it comes to driving just about anywhere there is potential traffic. 

The prepped foods and salad bars are more extensive at this location than the one Uptown, where I've been known to spend 20 minutes figuring out if I want to pay a small fortune for food that just doesn't appeal to me. Never had that happen to me in a WF before, just staying.

Here, there's sushi/noodle bar, pizza, bread, display cases of deli prepped stuff (plenty of veg options), a sandwich bar with plenty of tempting options, as well as build-your-own. Yeah, I can get behind all of this. 

There's also a g-damn COOKIE BAR. Is that really necessary, I wonder? Too funny. Thanks for putting that in my head, Whole Foods. Whatever. I can't quit you. 

Their bulk section is also far superior to Uptown's. They have chia seeds! If you buy them by the bag, they are a small fortune, so you do save a considerable amount buying in bulk (tip: use the peanut butter containers for these, as a tiny hole in your bag of seeds will ruin your day). 

Then there's the massive produce area that's so well spread out, thanks to the much larger space. While this location lacks the charm of old Arabella Station (of course), what I need in a supermarket is not necessarily charm (imagine that coming from me). Everything here is sparkling clean and I must also mention that the staff is oh-so-helpful and say hello as soon as you approach their counter area.

You know it's bad when the suburbs are beckoning to the likes of someone who prefers to stay within a safe drive away (that is, not driving at all, if you must know).

Ode to the overused "hidden gem" on Yelp.

Sentiments might be my favorite place to ever stumble upon in New Orleans. It is perfect.

Perfect, I tell you.

First of all "wine and cheese dive"-- if I could have thought of that myself, I would have written the business plan.

Located above the gorgeous Feelings Cafe, you simply cannot get a more divine environs. Sit inside and feel like you've stumbled upon The Lost Generation's hideaway in Paris.

Drape yourself over the balcony alongside it and feel dangerous, as you sip a glass of something wonderful, decadent and red.

It was a slow night. I cannot complain... just wish they would have stayed open later (selfish, I realize). 

I will come back with my bestie, Oscar W and we'll scribble bon mots as our vision blurs and our tongues get thick.

So far so good. I hesitate to write this review before the necessary procedures for my cats are completed, but so far I'm liking this place more than Magazine St. Animal Clinic when it comes to follow-up, which I've come to realize is pretty damn important overall. 

Especially appreciated: the friendly vet techs who spoke to my kitties not unlike I do (thus making me feel like less than a cat freak? Possibly).

The thing here, though, it's really expensive. Also, it's now located on the other side of town now that I've moved. So, I'll probably looking for something closer to home (and hopefully cheaper) once current procedures are completed.

What a fun, friendly place! Y'know, I'm not normally prone to saying, rather, *appreciating* such things, but it holds true in St. Lawrence's case. I like. I like very much.

There's the little surprises. First, it's on N Peters, so it keeps company with places like Coyote Ugly. So, you'd expect lousy drinks, a gimmick and tourists lapping it all up. That's not at all the case here. There's local art on the walls, craft cocktails (even the daiquiri choices are craft. I mean, Pimms and Harvest Pumpkin?! Plus the best mint julep I've ever had, with ginger and St. Germaine, no less!) and good food coming out of the kitchen. I only tasted the chips with pimento cheese, but a perusal of the menu reveals that there's lots of good going on there. It's an inspired menu, with comfort favorites, as well as creative takes on such favorites. I did hear people going on about the special of the day (duck, so obviously I can't comment on that). There are at least two vegetarian options besides salads and apps, including a sloppy joe. 

Then there's the extremely nice and as of yet, non-jaded staff. Our bartendress was extremely nice and came and checked on us regularly. We arrived hella early, so we were the only ones in there. Nice that no one forgot about us (far more common than you'd expect and I can totally understand, having worked in the industry for so long) and went the extra distance to be friendly, while not overly attentive. It's a delicate balance, folks.

This is a pretty straightforward review (what? no stories?), but I'm sure I'll be back so I can embellish upon things...

A bearable bar smack dab in the middle of Bourbon Street? I've found it in Funky Pirate. Not only bearable, but a good place to catch some good blues acts that play on the regular (Big Al, and the trio that plays on Sunday late afternoons), cuz it's intimate and what's more, no cover, just a drink minimum (one. One?! Yes, one.) The Bloody Marys are as decent as you're going to get in just about any New Orleans bar and all drinks are just 2 bucks more for a double. Can't argue with that, right? Even during Mardi Gras, this place was a refuge from what was going on outside on Rue Bourbon. 

Do check out the sweet little courtyard in the back, which affords you to still hear the music and enjoy the (sort of) fresh air (if such a thing is possible in the FQ).

The eternal (yelper) question: Does this- insert iconic establishment- even need another review, when they already have X hundred reviews? To this I say, uh, yeah they do. You can never have too many positive reviews. Plus I look at it as a note to myself upon returning (ie, see my note below).

Yo Mama's is one of those places that was always on my itinerary when I'd visit NOLA. Truthfully, though, once I moved here, I have not been back since yesterday. And I also had only drank here, back in the days before they even had veggie burgers. 

So, it had been a long day of drinking and no eating. A parade day... By 6, or was it 7 or 8pm, I was really feeling it. I hate being hungry in the French Quarter because I don't have tons of options here (that aren't dress-up places, that is). I remembered Yo Mama's famed burger list and immediately was craving some crazy veggie burger piled high with whatever other crazy concoction they could come up with and insisted we make an immediate beeline (er, crooked, inebriated beeline). My friends and I were relieved to find an empty booth and slid on in. I love the atmosphere here-- just a cozy FQ bar with all kinds of characters hanging around. I remembered the bartenders always being pretty damn nice and that still holds true. You might have to wait a bit for service, but that's how it goes and it's never too long. The bartender also waits the tables. Something to keep in mind. 

While the veggie burger here isn't anything special, the way it's dressed up makes a plain girl into a vixen. And that giant baked potato is her perfect not-to-be ignored accessory (you can get these all dressed up too, if you'd like!) I had the Mexican version with salsa, avocado and jalapeños. While I agreed to have it dressed, I think next time I'll have them leave off the mayo because it didn't go with the salsa at all (that's my note to self, in case you were wondering). The baked potato is perfect, by the way. 

Drinks are cheap and good. I'm glad that I have another go-to for a cheap, casual and quick meal when crawling the Quarter.

A cobbler saved a life recently. That of one of my favorite purses.

Out on a day of shopping/sightseeing far from our hotel, the zipper on my purse became stuck thanks to a bunch of stray frayed bits of material. I thought I was doomed to having my purse tucked under my arm all day so that my wallet and phone didn't fall out...then I walked by this place and almost screamed with joy (again with the hyperbole). I walked in and it was like walking into my grandpa's basement (he was a wizard with shoes). Every inch was CRAMMED with shoes, cobbler flotsam & jetsam and family photographs. I knew I had found the right place to save my purse's life.

Sure enough, the friendly cobbler was able to fix the zipper in minutes. In addition, he showed me a neat trick: the way to get rid of those positively evil stray frays is to light 'em on fire! For real! They shrivel up and disappear, not unlike the feet of the Wicked Witch of the East when Dorothy takes the red shoes from her after she kills her with her house.

Just to be clear, I look at mani/pedis as necessary evils. I dislike having to take the time out of my day to get them done and in New Orleans, that always means for me having to go to one of the places I like Uptown, which is too much of a trek (crossing Canal. Dealing with traffic and road blocks and schools letting out) and even more time out of the day. I'm limited on time, can you tell? Cue the stress. Is it really worth it? All I need do is look at my hands and feet. Sigh.

Don't tell me to just relax and enjoy it! I don't relax because I'm too busy being neurotic about someone touching my feet and kneading them to the point of serious foot cramps if I don't catch them in time. And after paying all that $ for manis/pedis, I inevitably wreck the polish because I can't take the damn time to just sit without touching my phone, moving, etc. I am the WORST customer.

But yesterday, I was kind of the best customer at Nail Spa 27! I've found my quick and easy, no hassles salon, friends. First good sign: easy parking right out front. Second, a mostly empty salon around noon on a weekday, so no wait! Third, a friendly greeting right when I walked in. Fourth, a wall of cool colors. And... best of all??? They did my hands and feet at the same time! And it was so fast, I had time to sit there and wait for that shit to dry! They have gel, but I've sworn off gel b/c it truly was destroying my nails (naturally I cannot resist peeling that stuff off).

The salon is not much to look at and I really don't care because efficiency and speed are all I care about when having to endure mani/pedis. Both nail techs were nice, didn't try to torture me with massage, and when I asked for a second coat on my hands, it was not big deal. Again, it was such a quick, thorough job, I couldn't stop thinking that I'm now going to be a 2X a month regular!

And the price is right. No, these aren't New York or Chicago cheap deals (none to be had in NOLA), but 34 plus a generous tip. I'm down with that!

Where to even start!!!  This is a such a great way to experience the real charm of New Orleans, I can't recommend it highly enough.  Where else can you get a chance to do some hands on cooking with a top notch chef in his own home kitchen?  It was such a comfortable and intimate atmosphere - the class is limited to 8 people total plus the two chefs - it's like a great dinner party with old friends.  Robin was the main instructor for the day and Chef Bond was the dishwasher and of course provided the color commentary throughout as well as the lesson on roux.  These folks clearly love what they do and it just makes all the difference.  

After we washed up, donned our aprons and armed ourselves with our dry towel, we warmed up by making bread pudding - but not the boring old standby standard - chocolate chip bread pudding with mocha brandy sauce that was the absolute bomb!!!  We measured absolutely nothing, decided as a team how much was enough (which turns out to be a lot when it came to the brandy!!) and it turned out to be THE BOMB!  I have tried the soggy standby raisin cinnamon variety and never liked it, but now I can't wait to go home and try all the flavor pairings we dreamed up in class.

After we popped dessert in the oven, we started our mise en place (cutting veggies!).  We learned some basic knife work, how to make stock, where you can take shortcuts without compromising the end result.  Then we took a little break for some whine, playtime with Gumbo, the andouille loving pup, and a lesson in the courtyard on roux.  Then we each got to make beautiful, dark, cajun roux (something I've never been able to do right before!), and the eight of us melded into a cooking machine, finishing our chicken and andouille gumbo and shrimp creole.  Robin gave us lots of tips on how to freeze the dishes at different points to speed things up at home as well.

Finally it was time to chow down (about 2:30 p.m. or so) - and what do you know, we can cook, baby!  The food was so well seasoned, so very yummy, we were all impressed with our ourselves.  Robin said we wouldn't be hungry again until 9 p.m., but it was more like 1 a.m.!  

And clearly we weren't the only class that had a good time, some Mardi Gras SoC alums stopped by with their catch from a day of deep sea fishing that they planned to cook up with Chef Bond that evening!  Our 23 year old daughter and her boyfriend enjoyed it as much as we did, and Robin has already called dibs on catering their wedding :)   As a bonus, we walked away with an awesome list of recommendations for places and dishes to try all over the city (the pineapple cilantro margherita's at El Gato Negro were awesome, thanks Robin!).

Taking another class is at the top of our list the next time we are in NOLA, no doubt!

Gluten free menu is okay, though I would call ahead or look it up online to be sure you're in the mood for what's on the gf menu - I say this because only part of our party was. Maybe we had a tough crowd? We had a party of six, everyone enjoyed their meals - I think the steak was the most enjoyed by all of us.  Desserts were great- vanilla gelato and creme brûlée.   The service was outstanding as was the atmosphere.

Yay for running into random places to go pee!  

We were in Santa Barbara this past memorial day weekend & it was time for a late dinner.  As we were walking towards State Street to another restaurant, I had the sudden urge to pee (I guess I had too much water in the car).  I rushed into their washroom as it is labeled.  I came out & found the BF already sitting at the bar!  Ok, we will have a drink I thought, but we ended up staying all night!

It was the Ahi nachos that suckered us in.  I will dream of eating these in my sleep!  It was a layered tower of wanton chips layered with diced ahi & drizzled with wasabi cream fraiche...I was in heaven!  After having the Ahi nachos, we wanted to try more!  Had the Baby back ribs with sweet potato fries....the rib meat was tender, fall off the bone & the sweet potato fries had a nice flavor as they were sprinkled with cinnamon which was a nice touch!  Also came with a side of apple slaw...tasty....I usually hate coleslaw but this twist on a traditional coleslaw was good.  Also had the chicken crepes which resembled enchiladas but were so tasty!  The crepe was rolled & filled with ricotta, spinach, & chicken in a marinara sauce.   

The best part about this place is definitely the drinks!  Stiff drinks & friendly service.  Props to Andy from New Zealand who was our bartender!  ;-)  We had the Cucumber crush, the OHD (Oh Hot Damn) margarhita, Hob nob cosmo, Blueberry bombe, sidecar...all great drinks!

Definitely recommend if in Santa Barbara.

We arrived into Santa Barbara & we were hungry after the drive up there.  I am always in the mood for seafood so after doing a Yelp search, we headed to the end of the pier to SB Shellfish Co.  

First of all, it was Memorial day weekend, so the pier was packed with people & they all seemed to be waiting for a table at this place or waiting for their order at the to go window.  Good sign but bad thing since we were hungry.  We put our name on the list (there were at least 10 parties in front of us), then noticed the side to go window so ordered from there.

We had...
*Steamed mussels in wine garlic reduction sauce....the mussels were fresh, plump & tasty in the sauce...the BF was even slurping the sauce from the shells!  You also get two bowls full of mussels (1 lb.) for $13.
*Crab sandwich - this was on the small side, but the crab inside was tasty.  Came with a side of cole slaw & huge onion rings (I liked these).
*Clam chowder...chunky & creamy, but not too thick...this was really good!

They do have several picnic tables outside with umbrellas & finding a seat was no problem.  Do recommend ordering from the to go window to skip the wait...only problem is that alcohol can't be served through the to go window.  Although I left my little four legged one at home, this place was very puppy friendly if you sit outside.  The inside of the restaurant is actually really tiny with only 4 tables...the rest being bar seating.  I think the outside worked out better for us since we enjoyed the view.  Also entertaining to see an Asian family that each ordered a whole steamed rock crab (there was like 10 of them) cheering each time their number was called so they can pick it up. :-D

This was a very pleasant experience. The room was big and clean, nice kitchen too. The hotel has an indoor pool, fitness room, tennis court and free laundry for guests. Everyone was friendly and even the breakfast was good. I would definitely stay here again.

This was a fun place for the most part. Day one: it was a breezy day and the water was also freezing, so less enjoyable. Day two: warmer day and warmer water. We got what we went there for and had some fun so can't complain. I wish there was more outdoor stuff.

Not my best experience and I am a big fan usually. They forgot the biscuits, the gravy and the grits. My eggs were prepared wrong and the server while helpful was not generally pleasant. Being seated in 15 minutes on a Saturday at lunchtime was a plus.

We had a great dinner at Stella. For the two of us, we ordered one tartufo pizza, one order of broccoli raab, and 4 cocktails. A perfect amount of food, even though the total bill was a little high at $70ish. (It's the cocktails, which were good but not necessarily worth $11 each).

The food was just. So. Good. How can you not love an egg, cream and truffle pizza??? The broccoli raab was covered with a snow of grated cheese, which perfectly complemented the garlicky greens. So great. Stella is definitely in my Philly-visit rotation for next time.

Also, I just discovered the cozy bar area below the main room. Might be a good place if you want to get further away from the families with kids.

I still like the ambience of this neighborhood bar. Last night however I experienced terrible service. I ordered soup. My friend with an entrée was finished eating before my soup even arrived. The waitress was completely unapologetic ans simply said she delivered it to the wrong table. I was not happy and I left hungry.

I always order a gluten-free pizza. It is consistently inconsistent. Sometimes the crust is very dry and sometimes it is palatable and even delicious. It is always a little bit on the salty  side but I don't mind. The ratio of sauce to cheese to basil always changes as well. I just wish I could expect a more consistent pie. Additionally, the delivery is usually lightning fast, but yesterday I had to wait an hour and a half. Again, some consistency would be appreciated.

It's a very cozy neighborhood bar. The desserts are huge and the beer selection is good. There aren't a ton of vegetarian options on the menu. There is a vegetarian hoagie, but it's $10. 
I go there for the ambiance and comfort.
The staff at this shop are very generous, kind and expedient in their work. I really do appreciate them being able to help me in a pinch. Great guys and gals!

I am beyond excited that I finally ventured into this place after hearing about it for months. I'm sugar, dairy and gluten free and have been craving sweets for months. This place was a little too amazing. I can see doing some damage here, both financially and to my sugar habit.  I tried a red velvet cupcake and a mint cookie sandwich. They taste gluten free, but that is not a negative thing. I thought the treats were delicious and I was ecstatic to be able to indulge my sweet tooth.

The food has never disappointed me here. I like the combinations that they create.
I did have a funny experience during Sunday brunch yesterday. Some menu items are starred, saying that they can be gluten-free. I asked about the tofu hollandaise (which was listed as having an english muffin). They said to make it gluten free, they just leave out the muffin. I *guess* that's gluten free, but it seems like a bit of a gip.
In any case, no complaints here about the food.
It IS a little pricey, so I save it for special occasions.

These guys were super helpful when my bicycle was totaled. They took it and wrote me a letter stating as much. I then bought my new bicycle there and they fixed it up nicely for me. I had to go back to have my seat adjusted they were happy to do it on the spot for no charge. It's a small store and they are not open on Sundays, but they are friendly.

I've always been a fan of the food, since the Girard location opened. Last night was my first time in the South Philly location. The food was excellent as always.

I tried chocolate tea at the end of the meal which was my first time and it was amazing!

What most impressed me most was the service. The (manager?) went out of his way to be accommodating and friendly. It was a pleasurable meal and evening.

I was looking for a gluten-free option, which basically left me with a taco salad. It was basic and not very filling, but good. I'd like to try the green smoothie- it looks delicious. I applaud this place for it's location and well designed menu. I hope that they can one day expand their venue to include seating and more gluten-free options.

The environment here is calm and Eva is the best acupuncturist I've had in many years. I highly recommend going here, as I always feel great afterwards. It's affordable and the care is good. My only advice is to book appointments online early, because slots fill up quickly.

I live in Philly and was visiting a friend staying at this hotel. He had to change rooms because they were so oddly shaped. I very literally got stuck in the bathroom because the door frame was swollen(??). That wasn't a pleasant experience.
Lastly, I went there to swim in the pool with my friend and it was disappointing to say the least. The only really good thing about the hotel is it's location, which is superb. I probably wouldn't recommend this hotel to future friends visiting Philadelphia.

First of all, Pep Boys always have awesome coupons online, so I go there. They are really prompt in dealing with my car. Often they find *a lot* wrong with my car when I go in for an oil change or notice a problem, but they at the same time, try to play with the price for me so it's not too much. I have an inherent distrust of mechanics, but these guys seem okay and at least reputable.
High caliber art exhibitions, free classes for adults, workshops for kids, classes in many media and a beautiful sanctuary. It's a great community space for art lovers.
This is a lovely spot to walk and observe native animals and plants.  It wasn't crowded and only cost $3 to get in. I appreciate their rescued birds in the aviary.

I came in today for a birthday cupcake. I was excited to order a salted caramel cupcake. The woman at the counter dropped it on the counter. I asked for one that had not been dropped on the counter and she obliged while rolling her eyes. I then saw her put the dropped cupcake back in the case. That just doesn't seem sanitary to me.

Had a great waiter here, young blonde guy.  Anticipated everything I would need before I even thought of it!

Had a salad, it was ok, served the purpose: fill my belly in the healthiest way I could at the airport ;)

Huge outdoor store.

Comparable to a REI + Cabelos with a fudge store and cafeteria.

They have everything: hiking, biking, running, swimming, fishing, hockey, hunting, golfing, and home decor.

In addition they have sights of wonder:  2 humungous fish tank arches (fresh & salt), a large Ferris wheel, talking presidents (though sadly only 2 are animatronic :(,  a large fake mountain with taxidermic (sp) animals of the region.

I love this place!  Over the top decor, comfy beds, quiet climate control in the room, friendly competent employees, and I won!

I have been coming here for about 10 years, and they definitely treat you right with the comps, also love that it is family owned, not some big corporation.  Nice to know some families can still work together :)

Had pho here for lunch, was good, large menu, would like to get back and try some more things, especially the Hot Pot; which is only served for dinner.  It was very busy, but they got us seated right away ;)

this rating is based on 1 sandwich. i haven't had anything else and cannot profess love for anything more than a glorious sandwich special they had today. it was a ham (either blackforest or virginia) & swiss with thin green apple slices, grilled onions and toasted with copious amounts of butter. it comes with mayo but i requested otherwise. UNBELIEVEABLE. our waitress Morgan was also very patient and accomodating. good stuff!
Great local Italian food. Went here a few weeks ago for a graduation dinner and food was outstanding. Ambience was good and food felt authentic and very tasty. Will definitely return!

My parents and I just enjoyed the first of many wonderful meals at this great restaurant. 

Fantastic lamb korma, chicken biryani, fish curry, and garlic naan. More importantly, the staff was extremely warm and thoughtful - we felt extremely well cared for and had a thoroughly enjoyable night. We will definitely be returning to this hidden gem of Newtown.

This is a fabulous Chinese restaurant.   Family owned with the owner preparing all the food.  Has take out and sit down services, so its kind of between a take out and a sit down place.  It is not a buffet type place but more of a little restaurant where the owner will remember you the next time you come in.  He also takes your order and prepares your dinner.  The owner loves Frank Sinatra and has Sinatra posters up and Sinatra songs playing amid the Chinese decorations, but that is not the only surprise!  The food is excellent, and many dishes have the owner's special sauces, one of which, the "fragrant sauce" is addictive.  It is both spicy and lightly sweet and a perfect complement to chicken or shrimp.  I usually don't like Chinese dishes with beef, but the beef here--which the owner special orders--is extremely tender and full of flavor.   The owner prides himself in selecting only the finest ingredients, so you are getting dishes made with superior ingredients and that shows in the taste.   The shrimp he uses are huge!  Really, this is just a dazzling place on the Northwest side, Lafayette Rd., not far from the 56th St. entrance to Eagle Creek, and it is a hidden gem.  If you love Chinese dishes do yourself a favor and stop in.

We left our two Samoyed for a week and found the service excellent.  Our dogs returned happy and obviously very well cared for.  Sleepy Hollow is run by dog lovers and they do little extras such as cuddle time, walks, and email 'letters' with pictures from your dogs telling you how they are doing.  These all cost a little extra but were well worth it to us.  The kennel also appears to have a variety of staff working with the dogs, so we knew our dogs weren't alone all the time.  We were very impressed and will use again.

The place to be on a warm summer night.  This is a Classic American Drive-In that hasn't changed in decades (a good thing!).   Clean, safe, and kid friendly.   Great concession area with great popcorn.  One of my favorite places in Indianapolis.

Coolness Alert!!!!   If you look up "dive" on Wikipedia, there is probably a photo of this place--but ooh what great food!  A classic hole in the wall, that serves really terrific "authentic" Mexican food.  This place is a step up from the ubiquitous Mexican restaurants around town that all offer the same boring stuff that all tastes exactly the same (like the chips they serve).  The food here is prepared more on the authentic side, with very good sauces and traditional elements.   Very friendly waitress and cook.   It is obvious true that the cook at Mexican In (I'm not sure if the name is a good or bad pun) not only knows the recipes, but is an amazing cook in general.   If you look past the register you can see into the kitchen and see her preparing the meals.  I have eaten here several times and have never been disappointed, in fact, I have been amazed at the quality and taste of the food each time.  The mole is sublime.   The carne asada perfect.   The place is family run, and ihey definitely saved money by not putting it into the decor which is a bit worn and and sun faded walls with old Naugahyde upholstered booths, but the food is what your looking for anyway right?  If more people knew about this place, I am sure it would have a  following such as El Sol, which is the closest restaurant I can compare it to in terms of how the food tastes.  But this place is far less pretentious or  expensive.  If you can get over the divey look of the place, and the location, and just appreciate the quality of the food, you'll will have found a great alternative to the clone like Mexican restaurants where you over eat and can't even remember how it tasted afterward.  In fact, this is likely where all the people that work at those restaurants go for breakfast, lunch or dinner out at a place like this.  I should mention that although the restaurant is a bit threadbare--I have observed a a very clean kitchen, with the cook wearing a spotless apron, so we know we have a cook who is serious about food and her kitchen.  All great finds like this one have their quirks and this one's quirk is it is easy to miss.  Although it is right on Michigan just west of the intersection with Rural on the near east side, and across from an old Hardware store, it kind of just blends in.   Do yourself a favor and take a chance like I did--you'll be back again and again.    Best of all it doesn't seem to do much advertising so it is never crowded, and often you can have the whole place to yourself--perfect for that long date where you just want to sit and talk with someone, but go with your boho adventurous spirit, and appreciate the place for what it is.  Oh, one more quirk--it is cash only, but that is exactly what you would expect.  :).

My parents brought me a kids bean and cheese burrito from this restaurant one afternoon when I wasn't feeling well. I'm telling you... I don't know what was so magical about this burrito but it was one of the most delicious things I have ever eaten. The tortilla was so good and the balance of bean and cheese was spot on. It was sheer perfection. My dad's burrito was also very good, as was my mother's nachos. I can't speak to the service or the cleanliness of the establishment. It's the taste of the food that matters anyway and this place does it up right. Totally recommend.

I've been to Santa Barbara countless times. Seriously, literally, countless (not even including the two months that I lived there). And I've never really felt inspired to try Something's Fishy. I walk by it on State Street day after day and nothing really calls me in. 

Well this time, with a rumbly tummy and little motivation to walk any farther than the door in front of me, I was seated at the bar before I even knew what happened. The waitstaff was a little difficult to flag down and we were seated at the farthest end of the sushi bar where it sort of tapers off. Not a lot of chef contact happening.  frown face.

We ordered three rolls, salmon sushi and unagi. Everything was made super fast and put all onto one big plate. I know this is a weird issue but I don't like all my rolls on one big plate. It makes it hard for me to distinguish what I'm eating. Just a weird pet peeve.

Not only did the big plate keep me from separating the rolls but the rolls themselves were just plain. Everything was sort of the same. And extremely mediocre. The only thing that really stuck out to me as notably delicious was the unagi. I was tempted to order another one it was so good.

Disregarding the nomnom unagi this entire experience was shockingly blase. Next time, I'll kick myself in the pants and walk a few doors down to any other restaurant on State St.

We were so lucky that our house was only a block away from this awesome breakfast place. I wish we had tried it on our first day and not the last. We could have spent so much more time here!!

The staff was uber pleasant and nice to be around. I adored the fact that all the condiments were stored in a rack on the wall rather than cluttering up the table. Whatever genius came up with this plan is a ruler in my book.

I had the breakfast croissant. It came with a side of grits. I also had a cup of tea. Everything was perfectly executed. The croissant sandwich was a special that day and I'm so glad I had it. The scrambled eggs and sausage inside were scrumptious. I ate every bite! If I had to change one thing I would wish that the grits came with cheese and not just plain. Even still, they were quite delicious with butter, salt and pepper. A very nice meal.
Delicious. Great service. Dishes that even a meat eater would love. And run by wonderful people!

I was spoiled in college for the fact that I found the world's greatest video store.  Video stores are a dying breed due to PPV and netflix, etc.  Rumor is Blockbuster is getting ready to fold (fingers crossed).  

Here is why Casa's the greatest...

1.  Free popcorn
2.  Collection of 80s cartoons on VHS (i.e. Transformers)
3.  Largest collection of foreign films I've ever seen.
4.  Movies grouped together by director or by classic actor/actress
5.  Largest random horror and sci-fi collection
6.  Always weird characters fumbling around
7.  Great documentary section.
8.  Complete Twin Peaks series.

Casa was great to find the most random videos of all time.  I dedicated once summer to renting Sci-fi / horror movies that had cool box covers.  It was a fantastic summer indeed.  

Casa is the only great independent video store that I know still exists.  I hope it can survive in a market where all other video stores seem to fail.

This. This is why St. Louis is known for barbecue.

For starters, Bogart's makes some of the best ribs I've ever had. They are properly cooked, porky as hell (in the best way), and if I had been smart enough to order a full slab, I would've eaten until I was very, very ill. 

As it is, a half slab of ribs is a solid meal, and Bogart's offers the generous and astonishingly sweet deal of adding a 1/4 lb. of any meat on for just a few bucks. Forgive my saying so, but if you don't add on at least some burnt ends, you're a goddamned fool. 

The burnt ends are the most delicious meat candy you've ever been lucky enough to put in your mouth, and walking out of here without any is the worst mistake you've made since the 90s.*

I'm of the opinion that neither the burnt ends nor the ribs need anything else, but Bogart's offers up several sauces for your use. Of the four, the Sweet Maegan Ann is my favorite, with its sweet molassesy goodness mixing in very well with pulled pork (which does need something else). My wife is a very saucy lass, and she threw the Voodoo and the Vinegar in there as well. 

As always, sides are an afterthought to meat, and Bogart's could honestly serve slaps to my face along with those ribs and I'd still come back for more. Thankfully for my already misshapen face, they've got a delicious deviled egg potato salad, some nice pickles, beans, and slaw instead. 

To sum up: 

Come here. Get ribs, burnt ends and some sides (more than you think you need of everything). Eat all of this food on the picnic tables outside. Listen to the blues covers coming out of the speakers. Enjoy the beautiful day and our place atop the food chain, because at one point in human history we were just gnawing on berries and sticks. And barbecue is better than that. 
_____________

*Don't think we don't remember that summer.

12 Facts About Snake & Jake's. It's Christmas [Club Lounge], after all.

1. It is the best dive bar in existence.*
2. It has the best dive bar name in existence. 
3. You drink for free if you are naked.
4. I've only seen guys take advantage of this.
5. It isn't pretty.**
6. I don't know if I've ever been there before 3 am.
7. It embodies that saying, "Nothing good happens after 2 am."
8. Don't leave with anyone you meet here. 
9. Your decision-making skills are impaired. 
10. They probably have a gun.
11. Nobody will ever see you again.
12. This is New Orleans, and I love it.
____________

*Undisputed, now that Mars Bar is no more.
**I suppose this depends on your taste.

The Good.

-There's a very decent hoagie shop.
-I'm a sucker for high ceilings. 
-There's always places to sit. 
-It's better than Penn Station* in almost every way.
-The bathrooms are surprisingly not that filthy. 
-Free wi/fi.

The Bad.

-There are no late night food options except for McDonald's.
-I broke my three year streak of not eating McDonald's.
-It costs more to get a bacon, egg and cheese than it does to get a platter of eggs, bacon, homefries and toast. That's not right.
-The place that serves fried chicken, meatloaf etc. puts all that food out on the hot plates at like 9:30 am. Which scares me. 

The Ugly.

-Eagles fans.
-Phillies fans. 
-Me.
__________

*NY Penn. You couldn't pay me to get off in Newark to see what that station looks like.

The dulce de leche gelato is absolutely fantastic, except when paired with Brooklyn Brown Ale.

The cones are nice, but not as amazing as you would think, considering that they are handmade in France and smuggled into the US by pre-pubescent teens that are summarily executed if even one cone is cracked.*

There is nothing emasculating about having another man buy you ice cream. Especially if you call him Daddy for the rest of the day. I swear. 
__________

*I may have made part of this up.

Upset that the line for Acme is around the block? Your charbroiled oyster fix can be had right here in the middle of the French market. 

If you don't mind ruining your shirt and/or you are more coordinated than I am, the crawfish are big and beautiful and $10 a pound. Grab a tray, post up at one of the tables and get in there. Don't forget to suck the heads.

Bourbon Street, when you look beneath the surface, can be pretty depressing. It stinks of desperation. And vomit. 

But if you drink a couple hand grenades, you're quickly rendered incapable of seeing anything beyond the surface. Sometimes you're incapable of seeing anything at all. 

And you're ready to have a good time. For pretty cheap.

I wish I could tell you about the sandwiches, or the selection of snacks, but I don't know anything about that. 

What I know is that I promised to provide ice for a party nearby (a necessity for any party, and something that will get you in just about anywhere), and I was late and frantic.

Olde City may not pick up the phone...ever, but they sell ice for $2.50/bag, they have plenty of it, they are conveniently located, and the guy at the counter seemed nice enough as I ran in, grabbed ice, and threw money at him. 

Thanks to them, I have not been disowned by my family.

I can't say for sure why we chose to spend our afternoon at Winners and not Losers when we all know where my friends and I stand. However, with some folks (not me) it's probably difficult to diagnose the full extent of their problems with a cursory glance, so they let us inside anyway.

In any case, Winners might look like your average sports bar, but they did have complimentary bail bonds koozies, picklebacks, buckets of six Bud LIghts for $12, and the sweetest bartenders around. 

And although the food is just your standard fried fare, the cook will gladly give you handful of flour as long assure him that you just want to slap your friend in the face with it.

My train arrived at 30th Street Station on a Sunday afternoon; I needed a late lunch, and Bridgewater's fit the bill. 

Normally, I would order their burger and never look back. Unfortunately, my girlfriend recently accused me of eating four burgers a week, which is completely absurd. OK, so MAYBE I had already eaten three that week, but I would NEVER eat four. What sort of glutton eats four burgers a week? 

In any case, since I would rather be unhappy than allow her to be right, I went with the crabcake sandwich on the bartender's recommendation. When it finally arrived, the accompanying sweet potato fries were barely cooked, but the sandwich itself tasted pretty good. The crabcake fell apart (as crabcakes are wont to do), but I bet they make a good burger, which I'll have to come back and try when I haven't reached my weekly quota.

Now, Bridgewater's doesn't look like much. The food is a little better than decent, and their flatscreens could use some updating to HD (you want to be able to see the pain on Favre's face). But this is the best train station bar in existence, and I'll tell you why: their beer selection is shockingly awesome. You'd never expect to find so many great beers available in a train station. It's even updated seasonally. Right now, they have all sorts of Christmas ales.

If they would only stay open a bit later, I can guarantee I'd have a pint here before every train back to NYC.

Forget cowboying up. Personally, I prefer to burger up before I do anything at all, and that certainly includes before consuming prodigious amounts of bourbon. 

I'm not sure there's a better choice for a gigantic group of dudes to have dinner. We were seated in the outdoor patio under a few heat lamps, and the staff here handled us like pros: offering advice when it was needed (which included when to urinate outdoors), kept the alcohol flowing,* and brought us plate after plate of excellent eats. 

We started with the habanero wings (not as hot as you'd think, but fantastic), fried pickles, fried mushrooms and more. They've got some great sauces, which I always appreciate: the blue cheese dressing was legit, the honey mustard fantastic, and the homemade Jack Daniels ketchup good on everything, especially the motherfucking TRUFFLE FRIES. With sliced parmesan on top, those things rocked, and the sweet potato and the house fries were nothing to sneeze at either. 

And of course, we ate burgers. Grassfed, juicy burgers. Cooked correctly, well-proportioned to the bun, and flavorful. Not the best I've ever had by any means, but damn good nonetheless. Our waiter made no bones about the fact that the Woodstock was the move, but I must say the pimento cheese option was no slouch. Having tasted both, I'd be hard-pressed to pick between the two. 

Basically, Burger Up held up their end of the bargain: If you put a dish in the name of your restaurant, it has to be good. And it was. 
_________

*Be warned. If you ask for a double bourbon on the rocks, you are basically going to get a pint glass of bourbon. Two in, I was a mess.

Cocktails and Dreams, Flanagan's isn't...and for that we can all be grateful. Of course, I can't promise you that Tom Cruise won't recite inane poems from atop the bar when you come in, but it hasn't happened for me yet.

This is one of the best bars in the Quarter precisely because you'd never know you're a few blocks from Bourbon, and as such they aren't trying to completely rip you off with their prices. The bartenders are good people with heavy hands, and the low-key crowd is always a winner; whether local or out-of-towner, everyone's trying to have a good time, and that's how it should be.

Oftentimes, the first thing I do on a NOLA morning is find a good bloody mary to wander around with, and Flanagan's makes my new favorite bloody in a city full of fantastic bloodys. It's like drinking meat in a glass. In the best way (as if that could be a bad thing). 

"Days get shorter and shorter, nights longer and longer, before you know it, your life is just one long night with a few comatose daylight hours."

He might've been talking about New Orleans.

A charming bar with undeniable character, Pravda specializes in absinthe and vodka. After a stint in Amsterdam, we decided to stick to the latter which is more than enough to sustain your buzz before you stumble home in the AM. 

The real prize here is the bathroom, where there is unfailingly a roach waiting for you, and at least once, a phone number scrawled on the wall requesting a picture of your genitals.

There are a lot of bars on Bourbon St. that can give you the same things you can get here: live music, cheap drinks, aggressive shot girls, grimy everything.

While I do love at least 50% of those things, I'm not a fan of this bar in particular. 

I'm pretty sure they can't be blamed for the fact that my wife's wallet was stolen out of her purse that was hanging on her shoulder (but that did happen inside their doors). However, they can be blamed that they wouldn't give a visibly overserved girl water, instead demanding she buy a bottle of it. 

I'll find my aggressive shot girls and grimy everything elsewhere.

I knew it was going to be a great place to stay when we pulled up and there was a man in a wife beater using a nail clipper to trim his calluses on the front sidewalk.

Unfortunately, that usually rock-solid indicator of quality was a bit off. 

I was surprised that a man like that would stay in a place where the beds are so uncomfortable, the shower is so unimpressive, and the hairdryer is so useless (so says my wife). I do appreciate the risqué touch of the full wall mirrors behind the bed, but the horrible lighting and the general appearance of her husband turned my wife off to the point that it was a futile design choice.

What especially galls me, though, is the blatant favoritism. The room my in-laws booked contained a fridge; where am I supposed to put the leftover wings I definitely should not have ordered on the drive down? Where is my fridge, Microtel? And while my wife's towel was shabby at best, it was downright luxurious compared to the scratchy, threadbare napkin that I was forced to dry my body with. 

This inequity cannot stand. 

At least Tina, at the front desk, was nice. And the room rates are affordable, because you get what you pay for.

At least once in their life, everyone should partake in the pleasure that is a jazz brunch.

While Muriel's might not serve the best food in the French Quarter, their brunch is an experience anyone with a soul will enjoy. After all, this might be the only time in your life that it's acceptable to eat veal, or a pork chop, or pecan-crusted drum first thing in the morning. 

My alligator hash and her andouille omelette were solid, if a bit overpriced. (Don't be frightened by the gator; it's in tasty sausage form, and you wouldn't know what it was if they didn't tell you.) The flavors were good, but the eggs (poached and scrambled) were overcooked. 

But although I might not revisit either of our entrees, I would GLADLY start any day with Muriel's Bloody Mary and the ridiculously rich crawfish and goat cheese crepes. That's the move here. 

The band starts the party and keeps it going, and in between songs you'll see that they are not only talented performers, but genuinely good guys as well. Not realizing my absolute ineptitude with all instruments, the leader asked if I wanted to sit in on bass. I declined, but offered him some of my Bloody Mary. Now we are best friends forever and ever. 

And ever.

I'll say it: I'd switch teams for John Besh. 

Restaurant August was already among my favorite restaurants in the nation, and Luke is a casual alternative that offers up an entirely different but equally tasty view into New Orleans food. 

For one thing -- and let's be serious: probably the most important thing -- they make an EXCELLENT burger. It is massive (and shareable according to some), covered in caramelized onions, Allan Benton's bacon, caramelized and Emmenthaler Swiss cheese. And although the brioche bun stands up well, it's unavoidably messy when cooked to a juicy medium rare. Our bartender friend informed us that this particular burger was chosen as 8th in the nation; I'm not sure by whom, but I'm not mad I got it, just mad I'm not on the committee. 

The shrimp and grits are also apparently a specialty of the house. We were told that they do them a bit differently than most places; as far as I can tell, they just cook the shrimp perfectly, and make the sauce good enough to drink. 

I was a bit disappointed that the fries were cooked past crispy into crunchy territory, but the lady on my left loved them all the same. For me though, the only downsides were said fries and the fact that their bloody mary is merely a mix (although I do like the Gator Blood), and they don't provide a spicy bean. Sacrilegious, I know, but give them a chance to make it up to you with the food.

Welcome to The Hutton, the Unofficial Bachelor/ette Party Hotel of Nashville.

At least that how it seemed. On our own mission of mayhem, we ran into large group after large group of folks also there to celebrate a friend's impending doom...nuptials. I meant nuptials. 

But I can't blame any of them for choosing the Hutton, because as far as I can tell, this is the best hotel in all of Nashville. All right, this might be the only hotel I've hit up in town,* but I have absolutely no complaints and I'm not sure how it could've been better.** Basically though, they've got everything I want:

-Free, fast wireless. Without even the hassle of a username/password.
-Clean, well-appointed rooms with outlets everywhere.
-The most comfortable of beds.
-A modern, gorgeous bathroom with every amenity.
-A friendly, courteous staff that was on top of our every need, and didn't even stop the 3:30 am Natty Ice chugging contest that took place on the front steps.***

Well, almost everything. They didn't let me extend my checkout time past noon. But I can't really blame them; I would've wanted us out as fast as possible too.
____________

*The filthy fleabags I slept in during college visits do not count as hotels. 
**Unless they could somehow find the hundreds of dollars that seem to have gone missing from my bank account at some point over the weekend.
***Although, several people who shall remain nameless would've sincerely appreciated it the following morning if the contest HAD been stopped.

Full bar and quite spacious.

VERY few tourists and caters to mostly locals.  If I lived in the 'hood (and could stand smoking indoors) I'd be a regular.

They allow outside food.

Honestly, a pretty decent place to stop in for a drink for a tourist who needs a quieter hour or two....but probably better for a local.

With as many transplants from the upper east coast you'd think the Italian Restaurant selections in this area would be an embarrassment of riches.  However, this is not the case.  Numerous times I have heard my relatives lament on the lack of good pizza and pasta around here.

Gigi's stands out from the rest of the mediocre crowd.

Food: They have a medium sized menu and dishes that are both familiar and unfamiliar (mostly familiar).  Basically, if your familiar with Italian food you'll find whatever stand-by you like on the menu.  The food is prepared well and the pastas are done well too.  I believe it would be hard to go wrong on your food selection.

Service: This is a mom and pop so take that into account.  That said, service is pretty good.  It may look a little lackadaisical but the staff is knowledgeable and friendly.  If there is a mistake it is corrected promptly and appropriately.

Ambiance: It is so much bigger than it looks from the outside.  It is relatively dark near the booths and well lit in the middle.  Actually, I'd say the Ambiance is unremarkable.  This is a compliment.  At a family restaurant I should leave thinking about how good my meal was rather than how interesting the place looked.

Accommodations:  Large party friendly.  Kid-Friendly.  Small group and couple friendly.

Alcohol: Wine list passable.  Need some better beers on tap but they make up for it by having a decent selection in bottle.  Perhaps they should contract with a local brewery to have a signature brew on tap.

Overall...you really can't miss here. It is better than most I've had in this area.  Pretty much will always be an option.  Once you've been you'll see why they have been open for 20+ years.

In all honesty, there are much better places to go within one block...however, the one star is indeed earned due to the fact you should go here at least once.

Nothing like seeing people puke, outside of the bathroom. Or, consistently being ignored by every bartender.  Or, seeing a shot girl stick her hand down a purchaser's pants....'cause $3 is worth acting like a crack-whore right? Or, having your drink spilled countless times by idiots who seem to never had a beer before in their lives.

Yeah, generally a shit-show.  I'm guessing the dude who got a four second cock grope may rate this place five stars...

I'm going to say three stars is the average.  Four stars for day drinking and visits...two stars for after the sun goes down.

This, for me, is solely based on the shit show this place becomes at night.  I'm done fighting for a space to hopefully be within shouting distance to get a round.

I'm done having to shout small talk to others in my group who I may not know well.  Conversely, I'm done shouting a good conversation with those that I know well and actually want to talk to..and only hearing 75% of their response.

I think I emerged from the pupae who likes frequenting bars like this at night around 27 years old.

As for day-time...tables outside, local crowd, good servers.
Updating to 3.5 stars due to proactive management and good customer service.  Like I said, I'd be there probably 2x/month ... but during daylight for me!

So yeah 5 stars.  I'll tell you why.  No, not 5 stars like staying at the Don about a hundred yards away but 5 stars in a very different way.

1-Personable, knowledgeable, friendly service.  They went out of their way in each attribute during my stay.  I also saw them give this service to many other customers.

2-Location.  Close to the Don, close to quality beach bars right and left, close to the older folks condo complexes for those of you who are visiting relatives, close to Walgreens....pretty much in the middle of St. Pete Beach...on the Gulf side of Gulf Blvd.

3-Rooms.  They offer flexible sized rooms.  Mine was huge.  Slept six if needed, had full stocked kitchen, large bathroom, basically a large studio apartment.  They were very clean and had the usual Florida tacky decorating.

4-Property.  Foosball/computer/business room, laundry facility on site, really bad miniature golf course on site, giant chess board, nice pool, private beach nad cabanas, ample parking...

5-Clientle.  Witnessed a family conducting an Easter egg hunt...outside my room.  

6-The intangibles.  You just know that you'll be back year after year.

So no its not a world class hotel.  You're in St. Pete Beach...Florida not the Cote d'azzure.  You're there to visit family, relax on some nice beach, take in some sun, basically get away for a couple days.  This place becomes an easy home away from home.

Oh, also my PSA for the day.  Please people...tip your hotel's cleaning staff.  God knows they put up with a lot of disgusting stuff.  A couple dollars a day won't kill you.

Lastly, (soapbox please) I never get political on Yelp but the thought just popped in my head.  For those of you that buy into this wild goose chase of a national issue aka Illegal Immigration open your eyes or we'll all end up opening our wallets.  The supposed dent they make to taxpayer paid services is dwarfed by the amounts that EACH AND EVERY ONE OF US save from the services they provide.  If you want super strict immigration policies than expect much higher: restaurant prices, produce, meat, bread, hotel rooms, shipping, and household services.  Get a grip people.

I stopped in here on my own for a quick dinner without having read all the previous glowing reviews and my experience was nothing less. Brian the bartender greeted me with "Are you hungry?" So much more human than the usual "Would you like a food menu?" I ordered the seafood gumbo, which was richer and darker than any I've had before. It came with a thick baton of bread, perfect for dipping in the broth. My dark and stormy was also expertly crafted- more kudos to Brian. Next time I'm in town I'll be coming back to Mr. B's for sure.

Delicious!  I love this place and the notorious St Louis thin crust pizza here is delicious.  Every time I am in St Louis, a stop at Imo's is a must.  

If you like bacon, the bacon pizza here is delicious.  Whole strips of bacon top the pizza. 

The iceberg lettuce salad with cheese on top and creamy Italian dressing is great.  You can purchase the bottled salad dressing which I would recommend to satisfy your post-Imo's visit cravings!

Delicious!  

I was recently in Nashville and stayed with a friend who lives there.  Burger Up is her favorite place so she insisted that we go.  First off, the decor it cute.  Not over the top, but understated, comfortable and cool.  I enjoyed the special of the evening which was a pulled chicken sandwich with apple butter and grilled onions.  It was so tasty.  I savored the vibrant combination of flavors.  Now can we talk about the fries?!  Omg.  Incredibly tasty!  My friend enjoyed a crab salad special that she is still craving.  Did I mention the wine?  I'm not sure if the glass are usually that big, or if they were just being generous, but I only needed one glass.  They had a nice selection of drinks.  Since dinner was so good I had to try dessert.  The chocolate peanut butter dessert is legit.  

Go here.  Have a burger or don't.  Regardless, I hope your dining experience is as fun and tasty as mine!

This is a good brick oven pizza restaurant.  A great place to grab a slice.  It's a popular late night eatery.  

It is pretty small in the interior.  Not a leisurely place.  More of a quick place to dine.

Hey, I'm not a chain restaurant person at all and I'm damned picky. Maybe they're changing their ways, I've read the previous reviews. We had excellent seafood here. I had sea bass that was cooked just right and I tasted the shrimp with pasta, also very good. Salads were AOK and veggies not over-cooked. Add some fantastic service. The manager checked our table in addition to just the right amount of checking by the waiter. Wine selection is very good. Is it pricey, yep, cause it's tourista-land all around, but oh so convenient to Union Station. We went very early, maybe that's best. If you feed the fish first, right outside in the lilttle lake, you'll be sure to have a hankerin' for seafood, haha, just kidding.

OK, exterior is fanatastic and the fountain right across the street by Carl Milles is such a treat. The old train station/hotel lobby is AWESOME, beautiful, a step back in history. Downside of the hotel, the pillow-top mattresses, with pillow-top mattress pads, nearly killed us twas so soft. After 3 nights my back was outta wack. We took the mattress pad off and got an extra sheet, which helped. I'm usually very happy with Marriott beds, but not here. The rooms are nice and clean, pool is a special treat, heated and under the train shed (still gets sun). If you want quiet try to stay away from the side that has the "lake" (kids will enjoy feeding lots of fish in it). There is live music/monthly outdoor movies which is nice goes til about 10-10:30. All in all it was a GREAT experience, I just cannot sleep there again, but plan on re-visiting the area espec with the light-rail steps away. We didn't even rent a car.The Mall is OK, it wasn't anything special but I'm sure mall-lovers will be interested since it's just steps, literally, out the hotel door. No fancy shops here, lots of trinket shops. The smoothie place is good.There are some exhibits scattered through the mall that are charming and fun, old suitcases, history of the station, etc. so that's a plus for the mall. I HEART ST. Louis now!!
Had the steak frites with garlic spinach - thought it was just okay. Microbrews are decent. Do have TVs to watch the game. Close to the casino.
Stopped by on a whim strolling down this street. Adorable kids' store with cute and unique items. Bought some cute dishware. Recommend!

Convenient to have a full service grocery store near our hotel. Took advantage of their prepared food selections for the plane ride home - meatballs were unexpectedly spicy,Asian sesame noodles, turkey meatloaf were okay. Also bought some local treats here for small souvenirs (praline pecans, keurig coffee). There is a seating area with TVs near the elevators - on the day i went there were a decent number of Saints fans watching the game enjoying food and wine! Microwaves are near this area too. Private lot.
Loved this restaurant. Probably the best grilled cheese sandwich I've ever had. Also enjoyed some delicious oysters. Very friendly service which made the experience even more enjoyable.
Did the quick pedicure in this cute, stylish salon space. Swan was so nice and the owner was friendly as well. I found the place using Yelp and was glad to stop in during my trip. Recommend!
Casual beach atmosphere with live music. Portions were generous. Had fish tacos, conch fritters, and grilled grouper sandwich. Food was okay. Mojitos were small.

Not a bad dim sum place but small. Service was friendly. There was only 1 lady pushing a cart around since there weren't many diners, and you could get some custom orders. Some dishes were better than others - beef tripe was good, chicken feet - so-so. A very affordable dim sum meal though.
Spectacularly delicious cocktails and equally spectacular service. Well worth the $$$.

For some reason the week I needed to be in NOLA for work, every hotel was booked or/and charging ridiculous prices (190+) so I ended up here through Priceline. The hotel is nice enough but definitely not worth the price I paid (mid-100s). The rooms are small. The first day I got there they had run out of shampoo. Then when they cleaned out the dirty towels, they forgot to refill them with new ones. There were no bath robes. The cable went out during Oscar night and they charged 13 bucks a day for internet. The rooftop pool is teeny, though the gym is a decent size.  I would only stay here if it was a lot cheaper, it's definitely not a luxury hotel.

Yes, it's expensive. But it's everything you want in a fancy gym. From an indoor track, pool, boxing, squash, racquetball, tennis, to amazing spinning classes. The Bellevue understands that spinning should feel like going to a club in Ibiza with plenty of hip-hop, trashy techno and house pumping and even black lights! I tried out PSC too and after a particularly bad spinning class at PSC, I ran away and signed up for the Bellevue. And every time I go to spinning, my choice is reaffirmed. Yay!

Great lunch place. Perfect portions, nice presentation, and tasty. I had an eggplant salad that was delicious. Lunch for two was around 20 bucks and considering the cute ambiance and awesome service, it is a steal.
My favorite place to work in this area: coffee, outlets, wifi, and friendly staff. And their peanut butter cookies are deeeelicious.

Our first of many more visits to this breakfast/brunch restaurant. From the owner to the servers....staff is friendly, knowledgeable and extremely attentive. We enjoyed the poppy seed bread French toast infused with blueberries, lox and an omelette. Everything was simply delicious and paired well with the specialty mimosas. .

We went here a while back and I have been meaning to write this review for a while but a friend asked about it yesterday and here is what I told her.  

I really really wanted to like it but I couldn't. I need to add my review to Yelp but even for old fashioned home cooking it was bland. I have decided that if a restaurant is at least half full of customers by 5pm and they are primarily over the age of say 75, turn and run. Lunch it's hard to judge by time but still can judge by age. I have found it to be true enough times that it is one of Melissa's Rules (like Gibbs' on NCIS). It was Friday and the special was catfish. We asked what was special about the Friday night catfish special vs the catfish on the menu - it had hushpuppies for the same price. REALLY, you added a couple of hushpuppies and that made it the Friday night special? Jeff had that and it was okay. I love fried pork chops so I chose that based on the recommendation of our rather young waiter. What makes a pork chop irresistible is that layer of fat around the edges and the sweetness of the meat clinging to the bone. My favorite places for pork chops know me and know that the uglier the chop, the better and select them especially like that for me. What was I served at Nana's? A couple of flavorless, overly thick slabs of pork loin sans fat, sans bone, with the breading heavy and not clinging to the meat. I ordered some greens and mashed potatoes and gravy as my sides if I remember correctly but I tried Jeff's sides and I know we had some sort of beans also. The greens were so bland that no amount of pepper vinegar and salt could season them. If things are not seasoned properly from the start, there is almost nothing you can do to save them and these were obviously one of those. The mashed potatoes were not even room temperature and the gravy was not hot enough to help warm them. As we were getting ready to leave, we heard others complaining about their steak special. I normally try to give a place a second try but each time we pass by my stomach begs me not to stop. Oh and while Nana herself might be there, I didn't find this place feeling particularly homey or welcoming and the service was at best average. There you go - my no holes barred review. I'll stick to Bolton's Spicy Chicken & Fish, Danguire's, or Skillet's for my pork chops and meat and three.

I forget to check in every time we go but we come here almost every Friday night now. This has become our "Cheers". We know all the waiters if they have been there long. We just walk in and sit where we want. They know what we want to drink and sometimes bring it before even coming to our table to verify. The food is always good. My husband almost always has the East chilaquiles with chicken which most places don't even have on their menu. I have tried a lot of things and never been disappointed. They have recently changed the menu up slightly so I am trying to figure out where a couple of my dishes went or what they are called now. I started to list everything but realized I have probably had between 1/3 and 1/2 of the things on their menu. So just a few favorites:
Queso fundido (cheese dip with chorizo and flour tortillas) - sometimes I will have this for my meal.
Cameron Ranchero (shrimp in ranchero sauce with grilled onions, peppers, and tomatoes) - this is SO good! The ranchero sauce adds a touch of heat but not too much.
Steak Alambres (sort of like fajitas but with bacon and then cheese melted on top) - these are SO good but how could it not be with bacon and melted cheese?
Milanese (very thin cutlets of chicken or beef that are breaded and fried) - Lately these have been my go to. It's two fairly large but thin pieces of meat, I've had both and they are both good.
Authentic Mexican Tacos (three soft tacos filled with your choice of carnitas, chicken, carne asada or chorizo) - It's hard to choose but the carnitas are good and again I asked for them to be shredded a little more and fried a little crispier. The char beans are whole beans cooked with chorizo and so good. If you like hot stuff, make sure to have them bring you the special hot sauce that goes with these tacos - warning it is HOT. I always ask to hold the raw onions on the tacos but make sure they bring me grilled young onions that go with them (not the little green onions/scallions but just small onions with the greens still attached).

I had gotten food to go from here a long time ago and I didn't remember it being anything special but everyone kept raving about it and several friends that know their food said that this was their favorite Mexican place.
