We tried several times to get in and it always had long lines and waits which we passed on.  However last night we got there fairly early and the wait was only 10 minutes so we decided to wait.

It was 10 minutes or less when our pager went off and we were escorted to a table back near the bar.  I don't know when I have seen a place that had the tables crammed in as much as Pueblo Real.  I even noticed as we left they had pulled a table from somewhere and put it against the low wall where our table was - I had wondered how that one spot had been left unoccupied.

The food was nothing special.  No better than almost every other local Mexican joint.  The place was noisy, crowded and bustling.  I will say that despite the crowd, the service was probably a little better than some.  The servings were pretty generous and prices about the same as other places.

It was an okay experience but I see no need to drive down to Franklin for it nor put up with the wait or the noise level.

When I judged in the Music City Wing Festival last year, there was one wing so good that I had to wait around and find out which one it was and whether or not it won.  It won and it was Hillwood Pub's.  Finally made it out here and they were just as good as I remembered.  Catfish was also good.  Friendly and prompt service.

This was our first visit to this location of Porta Via and I really want to like it but just like at the original location, it's not that great.  The service was slow even though we were there on a weeknight and early and were one of only a couple of tables at the time.  The food was just so so.  The pizza was ok but the pasta and meatballs was disappointing.  Pasta was overcooked and the meatball was just so so and barely room temp.

One of my first experiences with Logan's many many years ago was enough to keep me away for the most part.  But recently we have been enticed by the Monday through Thursday dinner specials.  They are a great bargain and there is enough variety so that there is something for everyone.

However, we discovered their happy hour drink specials and they are really pretty good.  And now they have a happy hour menu with items ranging from $2 to $5.  You can easily go have an early dinner complete with drinks and appetizer or just a dinner of drinks an appetizers for an affordable amount.

The onion petals ($2) were very good.  The fried dill pickles ($2)  are not quite as good, sliced too thin (think they used presliced dill hamburger slices which are too thin for frying most of the time) and in a cornmeal crust.  Other specials are Cajun Popcorn Shrimp ($5) that were fair, main problem is they toss them with spice afterwards and they were VERY unevenly coated in spice, some too much and most none.  Cheese fries ($3) and Chili cheese fries ($4) appear to be large portions.  Breaded mushrooms were good but greasy.  I asked about the clue cheese buffalo chips and was told it was the breaded dill pickles tossed with buffalo sauce and served with blue cheese dressing - the one drawback tonight was our waiter really didn't know the menu which was obvious when he answered this question.

My frozen peach margarita was very good, served in a frosted mug and only $3!

It's free and you get free beer so you have to give it four stars.  The bottling line is shut down on Sundays so we didn't get to see that and the rest is so so - it's just looking at big stainless tanks.  The older buildings are beautiful so from that point it is nice.  My biggest disappointment was not getting close enough to the Clydesdales to actually touch them or take a picture next to them so you can really get a feel for their size - they are HUGE!

Looking for something to do, I remembered that Alton Brown had visited St. Louis on Feasting on Asphalt so I looked up and saw that he said these were the best donuts ever.  Well, I have been disappointed more often than not by most of the places visited by 'celebrity' chefs but not this time.  We were already on a sugar/carb overload so we got two things each and now we wish we had gotten more.  This is another place that is worth the drive to get to!  The glazed yeast donut was just heaven.  The fact that they are making donuts fresh and as fast as they can is part of why they are so good but dang these were good!!!  Apple fritter was also great - crunchy on the outside, warm, soft apple cinnamonny goodness on the inside.

I have really mixed feelings for Noodles & Company.  Like Wild Noodles that used to be over off Cool Springs Blvd., I really want to like the noodle places but they just aren't like the noodle houses that we have eaten in when we travel.

On first try I had the steak stroganoff.  The beef was fairly tasty but the noodles were just off as was the sauce.  It had a strange sort of tang to it.  The other person in my party ordered the Pesto Cavatappi.  It looked nothing like the picture on the menu that was bright spring green from pesto.  You could barely see the tiny green flecks and lacked much pesto flavor.  And the cavatappi was dry, not enough sauce and again, a strange texture.  I think the noodles are precooked or something and it just shows in these dishes.

We had noticed that most of the people around us on the first visit had all ordered the Asian noodle dishes.  They are on to something.  Then I got a coupon for a free bowl complete with the meat.  So I got the Japanese Pan Noodles with the naturally raised pork.  This dish was good and had a lot of flavor.  It didn't seem as dry as the other dishes and the noodles didn't seem to have that off texture.

So right now I am still on the fence with this one.

I wanted to like this place more than I did. First the atmosphere - I did like the clean, open and modern feel. I did not use the restrooms but I noticed a long vanity with two sinks along one wall in the dining area that was very unusual and a little uncomfortable feeling and must admit I don't like it.

I tried several dishes to get a feel and satisfy my cravings that night. I started out with the fried calamari. In an Asian restaurant I pretty much expect this to be a tempura batter or at least panko. These looked like the typical pre-breaded frozen calamari rings you can buy in the grocery and they pretty much tasted as much. Not particularly fresh and just a hit of toughness that comes from not being fresh or slightly overcooked.

Next was the shrimp tempura. This was just ok. The only thing that kept it from being good to great was was such a small thing but the whole difference. The tempura batter was not cooked enough or the oil temp was not hot enough when they were dropped.It was soft, but not soggy, instead of crispy.

My biggest disappointment came in the Korean fried chicken wings. I wanted to try both sauces but on the side for several reasons. I wanted to taste them plain. I knew something would be going home with me and probably some of these and the calamari rather than the tempura so if they weren't sauced, they would reheat and crisp up better. And because I wasn't sure of which sauce I would prefer. I was told that they cannot send them out plain because they can't finish the dish that way. Well finish the dish out must have meant sprinkle the sesame seed on top of the sticky sauce coated wings and have it stick. I was not crazy about either sauce and particularly disappointed that they both had a good bit of sugar in them as I am diabetic and it's just something not needed to make the sauces good. And since I did take most of them home, they were soggy and did not crisp back up with reheating. I also asked them if their crust was gluten free and the waitress could not answer me nor the hostess but she said they could make it gluten free. That sort of made me uncomfortable with bringing my friend that truly has celiac here. We had another place that made all of their kfc and sauces gluten free.

Overall it was an okay experience but not good enough that I really want to go back. There are several places that do these dishes well nearby though they don't all try to attempt so many different Asian styles under one roof.

I have had two visits here since April and both were much improved over my first visit.

On the visit in May I had their salmon and it was as good as any place in town.  Definitely will order again.

On the visit in August, my daughter ordered for both of us because she wanted both the sheppard's pie and the steak and guinnesse pie.  The sheppard's pie was okay but the steak pie was the winner.

We like lamb so I really like a lamb sheppard's pie and this was ground beef or at least it tasted mostly like ground beef.  The gravy was nice but it's just a preference of mine for the lamb.

The steak and guinness pie was hands down a winner with a nice flaky puff pastry crust full of nice chunks of beef in a well balanced gravy that wasn't too heavy on the guinness.

We will definitely be going back.  

The service was good however I will say that on both occassions the servers messed up orders that were not standard straight off the menu - ask for a substitution and it likely won't come out the way your ordered it.  So that would have to be my main thing keeping me from going higher on the score.

Beautifully done custom cakes - which are as tasty as they look.

The problem with some bakeries which can uncork beautiful Instagram-worthy wedding cakes is that they don't actually taste that good under the thick layer of fondant.  Certainly not the case with Bittersweet.

Ordered a lemon/cream cheese custom cake with a thematic topper; actually dropped by earlier in the week to try the cupcake version of this creation (though with lemon curd, not cream cheese), and was quickly convinced that I'd made the right decision.  The cake itself was aromatic and flavorful; surprisingly, the thin fondant surface was definitely tasty enough to be worth eating. 

Solid communication.  Emails were quickly responded to, even on Christmas, and interpretation of our desired theme was spot-on.

A caveat - if picking up from the store, don't let the cake sit for too long outside of the refrigerator prior to presentation as humidity may cause the fondant to sweat and bulge; doesn't affect the flavor (probably tastes better a bit warmer, but takes a bit away from the presentation).

Historic chic NOLA wedding venue.

Visited as a guest to a December wedding at the Eliza Jane / Board of Trade.  Though renovated in 1993, the BoT maintains a vintage shabby aesthetic that seems similar to that which drives designers at Anthropologie.  Otherwise, architectural and interior design features are on the spartan side - the posh Roosevelt Hotel this is not.

Courtyard fountain offers a pretty location for photos.  Light rain reduced its use, but improved the shine of candlelight.

High marks for exclusive food service vendor Pigeon Caterers.  Though I have no idea how much they charge for the buffet spread, memorable dishes included shrimp and grits, gouda mashed potatoes, and crawfish etouffe.  Bananas Foster were a cool effect, but ended up too soupy for excellence.  Reasonable bar selection of mid-level wines and spirits with simple mixed drinks only (no sazaracs, French 75s, or gin fizzes at this wedding) - again, don't know what our friends sprung for.  Unique is that leftovers were packaged for the wedding party to bring home.

Second line up Poydras was pretty special.  Must do.

Smart hotel, free parking.

Cashed in some points to treat ourselves to a Hyatt Place experience after a long road trip featuring multiple AirBNB stops.  Similar aesthetic to a Hyatt House (a Residence Inn-like extended stay suite concept), but without the kitchenette.  Instead of a separate room, our room had a partial divider between the bed and the living room space (a Junior-one?) that made for a more refined experience than the usual hotel room with four walls and four right angles.

Featured all of the family-friendly Hyatt Place/House features including a better-than-serviceable breakfast.  This location featured a pool, as well as plentiful free parking (not always the case - see Pittsburgh, PA).

While I understand that the Hyatt Place/House series is set lower than the Grand/Regency properties, there are certainly some design wins here that can be implemented up the ladder.
This place is all about the experience.  You need to go if you have never been.  They have great food with great service.  If you are in Broad Ripple this is a place you have to check out!

Great experience! I would highly recommend trying it out. The team is incredibly friendly and knowledgable regarding men's hairstyles. The additional services offered are worth looking into. I will definitely be back.

The Next Act buzzes with energy - or at least it does on the first Tuesday night of every month - when Alley Kat arrives with a cask of its seasonal ale. 

Service is friendly and the bar has a great selection of beers on tap. Apparently, the food is also pretty good, but I have yet to try it. 

They show old movies on the tv screens rather than sports, and the bar has an air of sophistication, but without any real pretense.

And with a number of drink specials, the Next Act can be a relatively inexpensive fun time out.

Yay! Edmonton has a Wal-Mart with wide aisles and a wide selection of anything you would ever need. Of course, I still prefer supporting local merchants, but I don't want to go shopping around to find a shower curtain rod.

 And while I was at it, I could pick up a turnip, some potatoes, and an 80 cent can of kidney beans.

The Red Ox Inn is a first-class fine dining experience in an understated, comfortable atmosphere. The vintage sign out front indicates that the Red Ox Inn has existed in some form for years, but the interior and menu indicate that the proprietors are forward-thinking.

Located in a small storefront in the Strathearn neighbourhood, the general ambiance is that of a clean, high quality neighbourhood restaurant, accented by white tablecloths and hardwood floors.

There are maybe about ten tables in total, but spaced well apart from each other. The restaurant isn't too quiet, but not too loud either. You can converse easily and listen to some carefully picked mid-tempo indie rock tunes in the background.

Naturally, the food is the star here. The focus is on great flavor and great texture while still presenting the food in a unique way.

In our party of four, three ordered the (Vegetarian) green pea, hazelnut, and white chocolate soup as an appetizer and everybody loved it. I had a little taste and concur.

I went for the beet salad with goat cheese and received a completely new interpretation of an old favourite. Instead of larger beets cut into rounds, this was served with small, halved beets instead. This salad, while tasty, didn't wow me the way the soup did.

But the pheasant I ordered as a main did. The bird was cooked perfectly, complete with crispy skin. I also appreciated the romesco that they served with it. I'm a sucker for romesco.

Dessert was also warm, awesome and delicious. Service was non-intrusive and efficient - just the way I like it. And while Red Ox Inn doesn't officially serve bread, we asked for some to sop up the soup and they provided us with some delicious, and buttered, rye bread to do so.

If you are looking for a refined, fine-dining experience in Edmonton, you will not go wrong with the Red Ox Inn.

Like any other chain, Famoso is very much a restaurant concept, ready to take over the world, or at least Canada. The atmosphere in the restaurant lends an air of sophistication that is much needed in big box land. I enjoy the decor and feel at this location more than the Jasper Ave one.

While Famoso makes sure to use "00" flour and accord to standards prescribed by some sort of pizza authority in Naples, it's very much the Edmonton equivalent of California Pizza Kitchen - right down to the Barbecue Chicken and Spicy Thai Pizzas. I also like how Famoso, while using authenticity as part of its branding, isn't above including Pineapple as a topping option.

And while the pizzas at CPK are considered sacrilege by ex-New Yorkers who happen to live in Los Angeles, I enjoy them. Comparing Famoso to CPK is a tremendous compliment. However, Famoso's crust is a bit fresher tasting - if a bit on the flimsy side for my tastes.

And considering the quality of the ingredients, the prices at Famoso are relatively reasonable. If you're looking to go out for a more-special-than-normal lunch, the $11.75 pizza and sandwich combo is a great value.

Also, make sure to take advantage of Famoso's Pizza-and-a-Movie deal if you ever go see movies at Cineplex Odeon theatres on weeknights. Essentially, Famoso will sell you a movie pass for $6, which you may use for any movie from Monday to Thursday. The passes apparently expire two years after you purchase them.

I'm looking forward to Famoso's arrival on Whyte Ave.

JB's reminds me of the kinds of restaurants that my grandparents liked to go for breakfast, but the decor has been nicely updated. And there's lots of flat screen tv's located around the room if you want to watch sports while enjoying your meal. 

Price-wise, JB's is competitive with Denny's and Cora, but I find my meals more satisfying here. And they often have specials. On Thanksgiving, I greatly enjoyed my Roast Turkey Benedict, which came with a homemade Hollandaise sauce.

They have an all-you-can-eat pasta special on Thursdays for $10. It's not Corso 32 or Cafe Amore, but you don't need a reservation and it's a good value.

Oh, and they serve pancakes to kids for free.

While I was all set to write a two star review for this, the "Eek! Methinks not" descriptor seemed a bit better. While I guess that the teenagers who work at this time warp to the 1980s were fairly friendly, I think I'm going to steer clear of this place again. It wears its years very poorly and nothing appears to have been updated since the 1990s. 

I'll admit that I don't particularly enjoy 3D film for the sake of 3D film, nor do I enjoy paying an extra 3 bucks for it. Because the Grandin Theatres don't have 3D capabilities, all of the films are shown in 2D at all times. The prices are low, on all fronts as well.

We walked into the theatre when all of the lights were on and it was a scary sight - who knows how much gum there is stuck on the floors and under the seats? Additionally, we couldn't see the entire film, either because of an obstruction on the projector or an issue with the placement of the screen.

I'm very happy paying the extra cash to see a new blockbuster at the Cineplex Odeon North or the Scotiabank Theatre at the West Edmonton Mall.

Everybody else has discussed most of the reasons why Bulk Barn is awesome, but I will add one pro (and one con)

Pro:
There is no need to write down the bin number of the item you are buying, unlike at Save On Foods.
Con:
If there is only one till open and those in front of you in line have a large number of bulk bags, you could be waiting a long time to pay.

I look for every excuse I can to get a cuppa from Elm Cafe - it's actually worth the $3.50 for a large cup of brewed coffee and I like how you can sweeten it with simple syrup. The sandwiches are always an adventure as well - lots of unique flavours and always changing.

Sloppy Hogg's is owned by the folks who own Absolutely Edibles, located in the same awkwardly shaped building. The two restaurants' kitchens are connected. This means that you may order Sloppy Hogg's food at Absolutely Edibles. Both rooms have completely different feelings - Sloppy Hogg's has televisions, and random crap on the walls (and as an American, I'm admittedly offended by the display of the confederate flag on a license plate on the wall - I know the restaurant is trying to convey the hospitality of American South, but the Confederate Flag is a symbol of a racist past). Long booths make the restaurant conducive for large group meals, and the tables work well for twosomes. Sloppy Hogg's feels like a fairly typical barbecue place, while Absolutely Edibles feels a bit more upscale, and significantly more quirky.

So, the food at Sloppy Hogg's is good, but wouldn't impress anybody from Texas, or California, or North Carolina, or anywhere else with a strong Barbecue culture.

Portions are gigantic for the most part. Most of their crazy sandwiches, with tons of meat piled on, are generally good for two meals, or for sharing.

I've been impressed with their barbecue sauces and their brisket when I've had it. It tends to the chewy side, but i like that - flavours are very strong.

The St. Louis Style Ribs are good, but nothing particularly special - not worth seeking out. I've been very impressed with the smoked chicken when I've had it in sandwiches.

Other good dishes - the taquitos, which are not really taquitos in a 7-11l sense, but taquito ingredients thrown into what seems like a wonton wrapper and deep fried, and the fried macaroni and cheese.

Admittedly as I am not much of a coffee connoisseur, I judge a cafe based on how it makes me feel when I step inside. When I pay $5 for a fancy coffee, I want to feel like I'm indulging in some sort of fantasy world outside of my day-to-day reality.

And the combination of tasty drinks such as the maple bacon latte (well, it's essentially a latte with whipped cream and a piece of candied bacon on top) and urban warehouse decor takes me to a trendier, more urban place than Edmonton.

I like how they're making this an all day establishment and look forward to checking out their wine list.

I will second Mike W's review here. Sam's essentially serves Royal Pizza, with a moderately thick, pillowy crust and cut into squares, but without a royal pain of a wait. Delivery was friendly and fast. I'll order from here again when I'm craving this style.

This location is substantially nicer than the Christy's Corner location. Washrooms are very clean. The staff is friendly and helpful. The floors are hard (they look like wood, but are probably laminate) and the store doesn't smell musty - which is a feat for a storefront packed with used bargain merchandise. And it's right by the Pasta Pantry!

Sherbrooke provides an almost overwhelming selection of beer. But to help you navigate the nearly 1,000 different types, friendly and knowledgeable staff members can help you. The store also uses bright green tags to denote which beers are on special, thereby improving your ability to spot a good value in the cooler.

Sherbrooke also features a number of beers which are brewed specifically for them, but these beers tend to be priced at about $16-$17/six pack, which is more than I generally prefer to spend. But with such a great and frequently rotating selection, you'll find something good to drink at a decent price.

Famoso is taking the concept of Wood Fired Pizza and franchising it across Canada. But I believe this is the original location. 

And while Famoso is committed to using the authentic "00" flour for its dough, Famoso isn't above offering pineapple as a topping. My wife insists on eating her pizza with pineapple as topping. As Famoso's thin crust tends to be spongy and flexible, rather than cracker-like, Famoso crushes its pineapple, rather than serving it with larger chunks. Larger chunks would create too much of a mess and make the pizza difficult to eat. Famoso's crust may not be stiff, it never becomes soggy. The pizza was a winner - by far the best I've had in Edmonton, but I'm still no Edmonton pizza expert yet.

We also ordered a sandwich made out of the same dough  - the Sophia Loren. But as the sandwich lacked a sauce, I found it to be dry and boring. I need tomato sauce, or cream sauce, or mayonnaise, or aioli on a sandwich. The extra virgin olive oil, oregano and minced garlic spread didn't cut it.

Also, a significant number of tables at the pizzeria are bar-style high tables. And these tables do not have a place to rest your feet, resulting in the placement of your feet on your chair directly beneath you. I did not find this comfortable. And I like comfort when I go out to eat.

I have to give Famoso props for offering a great Groupon ($20 for $40 worth of Food and Drink) and for employing servers who believe in the Famoso concept.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but I feel that the Century Hospitality Group tends to cater to a certain type - proud truck-driving Albertans who vacation in Las Vegas and like to class it up every once in a while.

DeLux is their version of one of the fancypants "Burger Bars" that every Vegas hotel seemed to have a few years ago - right down to the retro-chic decor.

I only visited once for lunch, but I thoroughly enjoyed my burger - The Delux. And I liked how it was served to me medium-well, though I'm not sure if that was the intention. No matter what, it was juicy, with a great balance of flavour from the bleu cheese to the caramelized onions.

DeLux is certainly more expensive than Red Robin, but worth the splurge. Service was on the slow side at lunchtime, so it's definitely not a place to go when you're in a hurry.

This Chicago Joe's delivers to the South Side of town - for a $3.50 delivery charge! But if you're within 6KM, delivery is free.

And I want to say that it's the best delivery pizza I've had in Edmonton as of yet. Prices aren't Royal Pizza High, but neither are they Pizza 73 low. The crust is dense, but not greasy. It's more akin to what numerous pizza websites deem "pub style" than Chicago Style. 

My only qualm is that the person taking my order claimed that their spinach was fresh, but they actually used frozen. I'll try this again without the frozen spinach and review again.

While I love that this organic market is right on Whyte Avenue and in a more convenient location than the other nearby organic markets, but the prices tend to be significantly higher than Earth's General Store and slightly higher than Planet Organic (fine, this is based entirely on the price of Romaine Lettuce and Green Cuisine Tofu). 

Service is friendly, the produce looks great, and the market is clean. But it makes sense that Blush Lane is a chain from the presumably less price sensitive Calgary.

Unless I need a product that Earth's General doesn't carry, I think I'll continue shopping at Earth's General for my organic grocery needs.

I'm still on the search for the best pizza place which will deliver to my house for a reasonable price (the prices at Royal Pizza scare me a bit too much). I think that Checkers may top the chart as of right now for a number of reasons.

a) Quick delivery - fewer than 30 minutes on a Friday night
b) It's not too soggy
c) Fresh Spinach as a topping
d) Roasted Garlic as a topping
e) It's not too greasy

This isn't a place I would brag about to any out of town guests, but it functions as a fine, and inexpensive place to get a pizza delivered from.

They also no longer offer veggie meats as toppings - if I want those, I still need to order from Panago.

Future Shop - where you're bombarded by sales people when you don't want to be, and you can't seem to find anybody to check you out when you need them to. But you'll still find what you need when you need it, and in a relatively convenient location if you are driving a car somewhere along 170 st.

This location's sprouted lentil hummus has become a staple in our household when we want something a little less garlicky than a more traditional Lebanese hummus. The 100 Mile Salad is also fantastic - full of local grains, pulses and other healthy things.

And they also have a great selection of cold drinks. My wife is addicted to the Steaz tea and I'm always keen on their Kombucha selection. They also have a great selection of cold pressed juices.

Unlike the Whyte Ave, location, this location stocks organic meat.

Prices here are significantly better than at Planet Organic for produce, and the quality tends to be higher, as they only sell produce that is in season, or acquired from a location where the produce won't spoil before it reaches Edmonton.

Make sure to remember your re-usable bags.

While the atmosphere still reminds me of a windowless Denny's (or a Moxie's, if I'm going to be generous), I'm happy to give the Underground 4 stars. 

On my first visit, while I was impressed with the number of taps in the wall, I wasn't impressed with the space or the service.

But a few months later, with improved service and a great selection of truly rotating taps, I must profess my fandom.

I cannot comment on the food.

B's Diner serves high quality, well prepared diner food. They  make their own perogies and use real potatoes for hash browns and fries. They use a delicious, thickly cut and fairly dense wheat bread for sandwiches and toast.

I greatly enjoyed my breakfast - spicy bison sausage (inferno), fried with onions, served with two poached eggs, toast and hash browns. The hash browns were not as brown as I generally like, but I figure I can ask for them well done next time.

And for vegetarians, like Sarah (my wife), there's an entire vegetarian section of the menu. You can also put together your own Eggs Benedict concoction.

For vegans, they serve a Tofu Scramble.

There are a number of Eastern European and Asian accents on the menu due to the ethnicities of the owners. 

There's some great local art on the walls, which I believe is for sale. Otherwise, the decor is minimalistic, but pleasant. I imagine that eating here will be nice in the summertime, when we can take advantage of a sizable patio.

One caveat with B's is that they only accept cash as payment - they don't even accept Interac. There's a cash machine in the back of the restaurant if you haven't brought any, but you'll be charged $2 plus whatever your bank may charge.

No matter what, the prices are reasonable considering both the quality and the cost of the food you are ordering.

Cafe Amore is a neighbourhood restaurant - not a destination restaurant. And if you set your expectations accordingly, Cafe Amore will wildly exceed them. Prices are not cheap, but reasonable. And portions are large.

The restaurant is small, but festive. There are only about 10 tables in the establishment. While we didn't need to wait for our table around 6PM, there was a line out the door at 7PM when we left. This may be due to a recent glowing review in the Edmonton Journal.

The menu changes regularly and according to season. Everything is written out on chalkboards. This is not because Cafe Amore is some sort of yupster joint located in some coastal city, but because that's the way this place has always done their menu. 

They have a rotating list of pastas of the day, but you can order any of the sauces on any day. You can also add chicken, meatballs, or a seasonal vegetable to any of the pastas and sauces.

I ordered a linguine (or as they called it - long pasta) with sliced italian sausage, rapini, and an abundance of olive oil and garlic. Ingredients were all of top notch quality. And while the dish was oily, it was too delicious for me to care.

Sarah also enjoyed her long pasta in sambuca rose sauce.

I look forward to trying out more of the menu - I'm moving to the neighbourhood shortly.

Wow. I've only reviewed this place once before?? How can that be?!? I practically live there. Needless to say, this is now probably my favorite restaurant. Three quick tips: 1. this place always has an amazing beer list, 2. This place has the best lunch special in town -- hand down. Pizza and an amazing salad for $10. Their salad is amazing. That's crazy. Try it. 3. This place has the best cheese plate in town. Better than Sydney Street, Baileys or Bridge. Twas amazing.

AMAZING MENU. I've been there several times, picking different items each time. Wow. Really amazing stuff to pick at. It seems like a true tapas place even though they aren't really that at all. Definitely check it out.

The newest business in the Grove was launched by the former owners of the Cabin Inn (which split ways with the City Museum a few weeks ago). It's a good space, good theme, good patio and full of bike art (with more coming in each day). The only problem is that the beers are a little pricey and the selection is still somewhat limited. Let's support this place to see where it goes.

Hours: Opens at 4
Special: If you bike out there you get 10% off your bill

Future note: they're working on a kitchen.
Last note: until the kitchen is up and running they let you bring in your own food for the nearby venues (ie, @cowboy or everest)

I really like this place, but it can definitely improve. 

Reasons why I like this place:
- it's a few blocks from the Des Peres bike trail
- it's a very cool space
- they carry other's beers, not just their own
- their objective to brew belgian-american hybrid brews
- they will carry @Salume Beddu (@Yelp, you really need to add referencing functionality. it's so 2007, which makes yelp 2006...no bueno) -- so damn exciting
- the copper bar top
- the dart board
- they use a gravity brew system

Need to improve
- their beer. sadly, it's not 'there' yet. it's not bad, but not great, yet. i believe they can get there, hence the 4.
- the leaves painted on the wall
- cash only

great place with great pizza and great beer. the parking isn't the best (it's a pretty busy area) but the experience is well worth a few drives around the block. here is what you need to know: they have an amazing pizza oven that makes perfect dough every time: fluffy and light, while still crispy. also, their pizza recipes, phenomenal. finally, they have a great beer selection. the place definitely ranks among the top beer venues in the stl area (iTap, bridge, ciceros, stable...you get the idea).
Lemon ice and strawberry ice cream combo is the best on a hot summer evening.

Forsake the fancy donuts (ok, I woke up too late) and dive right for the cinnamon. This is perfection - sweet, a bit salty, fresh. Pair it with a cup of Federal's great coffee. 

Service here is friendly and knowledgable, and I love the design of the place too, from the rube goldberg cold brew drip system to the stowable counter seating. 

It's rare to see a restaurant get all the elements right, especially a fast food place, but Federal is respectful to donuts while operating in a class by itself.

Oh, and the chicken? Yes, also great. 

The crowd here is happy too - who wouldn't be, eating delicious donuts and fresh fried chicken?

The Indianapolis Children's Museum is impressive but I think it was a little too old for our 6 year old daughter.  We had fun but the museum dances between being an interactive museum for the younger kids and being a history lesson for the older kids.  It was so large that it was almost too big for us to take in.  

There were some exhibits that she really enjoyed (Barbie) and some that just fell flat (Mr. Potato Head).  The dinosaur exhibit was really good and could be in almost any history museum.  The glass sculpture very impressive and very interactive.  The Train exhibit was odd and just kind of there.  

The museum is in a very "rough" part of the city and we drove through some "rough" looking areas going to and leaving the museum.  I am not that familiar with the area and it was nerve racking wondering what was around the next turn.  

I would recommend this museum for kids 8-10.  Maybe a year over or under but I think the age range for this museum is very specific and it can be too much for younger kids.

Haha, I totally forgotten that I had eaten here. Sometimes when you're bored in Truckee the next biggest place for things to do is unfortunately Reno. Sometimes you get caught up with people with not so ordinary lives and they restart their future in less glamorous ways. I never was able to track that person again, but this was one of the stops I made to find them. Had decent solid meal but still It's Olive Garden. Nothing to write home about!

Where are you going to go to get a solid sandwich while rocking out to Pentagram? Yellow Sub of course! It's seems to draw the alternative crowd and it's full of crazy things seemingly stacked throughout the years? Creepy baby dolls? A pic of young Selma Blair? The logo of Buena Vista the bar with the great Irish Coffee in SF? It's all here. Capocollo and provolone for the win. Oh and rock out too.

Maybe one of the more interesting businesses in one of the strangest strip malls Ive ever seen. Walking in it looks like a fast food place. Milk tea on one side and food on the other. THere are lcd screens above that highlight both generic and Taiwanese specific fare. If not for a friend's rec, we wouldnt have known what to go for or that this place existed. Got the stinky tofu, Taiwanese sausage, beef tendon in chili oil, pork belly bun and green onion pancakes. The pancakes were under cooked but the tofu, tendon and sausage were good. Pork bun was ok. Service is what you'd expect and they were efficient but not too talkative. I guess for Reno this is pretty good.

I used to go to the Truckee one a while back but that's gotten really popular and crowded. Cool to find they opened up one in Reno too. Got a pretty solid iced tea after they couldnt make an iced con panna (even though it says any espresso drink iced). All the workers seem to be young and female. Actually most of the clientele too. The link to the pizza place next door and the cool industrial patio area to the south makes it good for hanging outside. It does get a bit toasty inside as one of the baristas declared as she was pouring.

Similar to my beloved Dutch Bros, a drive through caffeine vendor. The girls working are similarly attractive though not as uber friendly. Their specialty hazelnut coffee is quite good. They also give out a chocolate covered coffee bean with the order. The whole poor coffee convenience thing is being turned on it's head as now you can get better coffee from a kiosk than some cafe's now

Id been to the coffee shop next door a year ago and recently the desire for wings and pizza hit. Ao we dropped in for a few bites. Angey pig which had a load of pork and the baked wings were the fare. Pepperoni, salami, bacon, sausage goodness. The one problem was the outer crust was good but the center was a tad soft in the center. I think the cooking style has to adjust for this i think. Aside from that it's a solid pie and wings. Next time i try the hidden pig which has a garlic sauce instead

Wow people really be hatin on the Steak and Shake. I have a friend from Indiana that doesnt shut up about this place having grown up with it. So when driving through town we had to check it. Didnt realize it was a sit doen style place, though they do have a drive through. Double bacon steakburger, fries and an orange cream shake. Burger was actually pretty darn good as was the shake. Fries were decent but not killer. Servers seem to all be young women while the cooks were all guys. Interesting. Anyways for a fast food joint it's pretty decent.

Holy Moly,. Did Cabela's and Sports Authority have a baby with an amusement park? That is what Scheels is. Lots of sporting goods stuff throughout and then the crazy hunting stuff upstairs. The giant hill of taxidermy is crazy next to a hanging airplane. But then there's more. A ferris wheel! this place is just nutz!

I had no idea Grimaldi's was so open across the country. I always envisioned it as a small place under the Brooklyn bridge. Guess they're all over the place. I did not envision them being in Sparks NV! It's large and very un NYC I have to say. But the pizza was actually pretty solid. Pepperoni, sausage, and black olive. Crust is nice and thin and has a good crunch/chew factor. Not quite the same as my old upper west side go to (replete with two old Italian American dudes) but still solid. I like that they've simulated the old brick oven with the flapping door and such. It's just crazy big with lots of seating which is the opposite of the counter only standing room that Im used to in NY

The Hub has become my coffee of choice in Reno. I've been to the midtown locale and really loved that one too. Though this one is way more spacious, has a great design and it's next to the river and thsoe huge-mungous houses on the hill. Got their Toddy cold brew iced coffee. So damn good. The quote of the day came from my friend who when seeing the new Strada they had yelling" NO WAY!!!" and then running over to practically pet it. Not only great coffee a humorous outcome too.

We had another restaurant in mind on Frenchmen St. After a so-so vibe at the place we were considering -- I honestly don't remember its name -- we bailed and went with a recommendation from the bartender (bah-tenduh) at Hermes Bar at Antoine's.

The place was pretty low-maintenance with a lot of cool-looking servers in hats. It seemed like a mix of tourists and locals.

Since we never got the hang of ordering properly -- us Californians are used to smaller portions -- we asked for an ungodly amount of food. An enormous basket of fried okra, fried chicken, mustard greens, collared greens, mashed potatoes, and cornbread. Though the fried okra was pretty good (also seems hard to mess this up), and the sides were fantastic, the fried chicken stood out for me. That batter is insane. We didn't talk the whole way through the meal: a sign of a good one! Pralines to go made my day later on.

I'd love to spend more time on Frenchmen St. -- for food, music, and bars -- next time we're in town. Nicely out of the way from Bourbon Street madness.

After contemplating going to the Hard Rock for dessert (give us a break, my friend had a gift certificate and we wanted to save money), we popped into Mike's first. The tiny place was packed and the line was long but after a glance at the menu we decided to stay. The line moved quickly and I got myself a peanut butter/chocolate shake. Slurp slurp slurp.. heyyy.. where'd it go? I downed that baby with a quickness to cool down from the hot Tennessee sun. It was a good portion and mixed well aka.. not too milky, not too thick. 

The staff was friendly. I love that the cashier said that the flower in my hair was "still cool" even after I told her it was fake. And like all cute little places, they had a list of celebs that have walked through. I just recognized Jimmy Fallon and some other country stars on the list. 

They're open till 2AM (summer hours?), so I can see how'd they be popular amongst the bar crowd on Broadway.. but even if they didn't rely on the late night bunch, people would definitely still stop by for a good scoop!

I've been to Bailey's Range 3 times in the last 4 months. That may not sound like a lot...but I also live in Las Vegas. I found out about Bailey's Range on Yelp as I was looking for a good selection of local beers at a place that would be open between lunch and dinner. The local beer selection is excellent and the staff who work the bar seem to know quite a bit about the beer. Of my three visits, two of them included the best service I've received in St. Louis.

I have had 3 different burgers for  each of my three trips. The most recent was a Big Popper, which is my favorite. I've also had Dave's Chop House and The Carolina. After my three different burgers I will believe that they do not serve a bad one. The fries are also a favorite, as well as having some of the best fried pickles I've ever eaten. I am still dreaming about them. 

I have also sampled a couple of the lemonade cocktails which are both strong and refreshing. 

I will most definitely be back to Bailey's Range on my next visit to St. Louis.

Def a must see if you like old churches. The lawn across the street from the church is pretty. We did find girls in bikinis sunbathing too. uhmmm.. weird... 

Moving on....

I liked the rose garden area with the stations of the cross.

I didn't do the tour.. but yes; they have a tour.

The church is pink and HUGE from the outside.

My boyfriend did a very good job picking this place for our first breakfast place during my trip to see him in August.
I loooved the vibe....

It's very movie-ish. I felt like my boyfriend and i were the only "tourists" in the restaurant...

I did enjoy my food... and my boyfriend did too...

They do have a variety of selection to choose from...

Loved the quesadilla.....
Loved the pancake....

Great coffee taste...

Quality is So there... But why only 2 stars? READ on...

I had the almond milk latte and it was good.

The butterscotch cookie was intensely satisfying as well...

But..what's up with the cashier??? Minus 1 star for a rude male (or in between) cashier.
He calls me and my husband over and asks us for our order.. and in the middle of my order; he gets in a conversation with another customer..and lets me repeat my order? oh hell no.
My husband asked if he could get a latte. Male(or in between) cashier asked if chocolate or vanilla.. My husband said chocolate... and he said.. so you want a mocha... He said it in a condescending tone... He might have just left it as how he said it at first. chocolate latte. easy. less confusing. 

My husband got our table while i went to use the restroom...
I came back and saw my husband sitting with a plastic cup of his iced drink and a paper cup of my hot drink.
We were sitting in and why is it that we didn't get a REAL cup like everyone else?
Why did that cashier assume we were to get our orders to go?

I'd think because Santa Barbara is like a tourist spot... they shouldn't be rude to tourists who live in cities with the best coffee EVER. (i miss you Philz Coffee).

Ambiance is Great... it's just full of students and their macbook pros sippin on teas. (FYI. i just read how one coffee shop shut down their wifi and their sales went up! because people who actually pay have a place for them to sit... not with students being there for hours and hours just having one of the cheapest drinks they offer.)

-1 star for not having a trash bin in each stall in the bathroom.
hello. not everything is flushable like the plastic part of a tampon.

GREAT COFFEE.
UNFRIENDLY and RUDE CASHIER.

Total Vibe Killer.

I observed every single person working at that bar. all of them seem to take their job way too seriously.. no personalities shine here.

Do Not Recommend unless you want to feel agitated to punch someone in the face.

I love the fresh steaks here. Nothing beats a huge  cut of the delmonico. The thick-cut smoked bacon is also incredibly flavorful. I'm almost glad that this is far from home. Otherwise I'd be buying stock in plavix and lipitor.

The coffee is definitely weak but the breakfast sandwiches are pretty good.  I definitely appreciate that they use shaved deli ham rather than a single slice of a ham-like meat.  The bagels are on the small side but fresh with a nice shell and soft interior.  I was disappointed that they didn't have any asiago bagels though.

Yum!  That's the only word that comes to mind when you have a bite of the vegan chocolate chip cookie.  Usually, vegan cookies tend to be bland and dry but not here.  It was soft, chocolatey, and delicious.  Minus 1 star for the hefty $3 price tag, though.

Serious staff attitude problem here.  I almost considered conducting a study on the number of eye rolls it takes to complete a transaction.  The weekend staff are horrible and I had to wait for 17 minutes at the register to pay for a belt because there wasn't anyone at the counter.  Even after the cashier arrived, she exuded such an air of affected ennui and practically snapped the amount I owed while throwing the item almost angrily into a bag.  I' sorry if you abhor your job but that is no excuse for treating customers poorly.  I also noticed that other customers were getting impatient waiting for their shoes and just for someone to be at the register/counter to help them pay for their items.  The weekday staff is a lot more efficient and friendly, especially the day manager who is simply a sweetheart.  It's just the Sunday staff here that are certainly yelp-worthy, to say the very least.  They do have some cute accessories so I will continue to stop in every once in a while but never again on a Sunday.  The experience here definitely takes the term "customer service" (or lack thereof) to a new level.  1 star for the experience today.

The brisket is a bit on the tough side but the broth is very flavorful and the meatballs nicely seasoned.  Plus they give you a generous serving of meat.  The summer rolls are good but very much on par with those at every other Vietnamese restaurant.  The service is what sets them apart.  They are just so nice and attentive here!  I was accustomed to the south Philly service level and it's a complete 180 degrees from that.  Even when we order takeout, our bags are handed over with a smile and double check to make sure that we have whatever extra sauces, utensils, etc we need.  Love it!  Plus it's only 10 min away.

This is my favorite Panera location in the area.  It's a bit smaller than the Norristown and Conshohocken branches but the cafe is cleaner and the service is A LOT friendlier and more efficient.  Plus, they always have most of the menu in stock (every kind of bagel), unlike the Norristown location.  The hazelnut coffee here is also slightly darker.

The brunch here is fantastic.  The highlights:

1.  apple-smoked turkey bacon (flavorful and lean - definitely not as greasy as your everyday bacon yet it is still crispy and tasty)
2. quiche lorraine (fluffly and light with a flaky, buttery crust and just the right amount of gruyere)
3. omelette station (need I say more?  they have every imaginable topping for a great made-to-order creation.  try one with a combination of spinach, fontina, and mushrooms)
4. carved lamb with rosemary and mint (tender and flavorful but it was well-done and I tend to like my meat a little on the raw side.  It was still delicious, all the same, and I went back for a second serving...because being pig-like is excusable at a holiday brunch)
5. chicken in bechamel (very juicy, tender breast in a buttery sauce that doesn't taste heavy - pretty good although it wasn't my favorite)
6. salmon with baby shrimp (the addition of the tiny shrimp was ingenious and really added a welcome twist to any otherwise good, but kinda overly prevalent dish - the sauce was buttery and flavorful)
7. lox and cold cuts (your typical display - not bad but not very memorable either)
8. clam chowder (edible but kinda bland)
9. challah french toast (okay but not as good as Sam's or Sabrina's, by a long shot; it wasn't very thick and a bit overcooked)

They also have a waffle station and your typical breads, toppings, fruits, and sides.  The range of dishes and offerings never ceases to astound me and it's always rather overwhelming.  I would advise looking everything over before deciding on what to try since there is always more than you can physically eat in 1 meal, even if it is breakfast and lunch combined.  Service was great and my coffee cup was never empty.  To be completely honest, Thayer's "famous" brunch was not as fantastic as the brunch here.  It would be 5 stars, for sure, if they improve their french toast and imported actual NYC bagels (I can dream, can't I?)/
Closed.

I came here for the garlic soy crispy fried wings and made sure to call in my order, which made the process flow much more smoothly.  My chicken was ready when I arrived and it was crispy, juicy, tender, and perfectly salty-sweet.  The key is to place your order 15 min before you expect to get there and your takeout will be hot and ready-to-go.  Honestly, you won't find a better place to get Bonchon-like chicken in the area.  That crispy skin comes from the chicken being double fried and will easily derail any New Year's resolution to stay away from fried food on the first bite.  The wings are small, though, so an order won't kill a diet.  Plus, it's super close to home, which gives it an additional convenience factor

Really loving the $6.99-7.99 trio special right now.  My tarragon chicken salad on a pretzel bagel was full of almonds, red onions, chicken, and craisins in a savory, creamy blend; the pretzel bagel itself tasted like a soft pretzel with a nice crispy shell.  The clam chowder was decent but didn't really stand out from the versions at Au Bon Pain or Panera; it was very hot though so kudos for that.  The combo also came with a medium drink, too, which was definitely an added plus since that alone will cost you over $2 at Panera's.  Overall, service was fast and friendly and I had a very filling and good meal for about $8, which is almost unheard of these days.  Will be back to try the smoked salmon cali roll sandwich, which has smoke salmon, avocado, and wasabi cream cheese; it sounds quite interesting.  Anyhow, will update once I try that but definitely stop in and grab a trio if you want a fast, filling, and very inexpensive meal that isn't from your local BK or Wendy's or McDonald's.

I love this location because the service is unsurpassed, it's newly rennovated, and they have a great selection of designer bags and shoes.  The manager is the sweetest woman ever and she was extremely helpful in addressing a not-so-easily-fixed situation.  Most of the staff are great and they have a great Lily Pulitzer section for the prepster in you.  If you, like me, are a shoe fiend, then you will definitely appreciate the stock of vintage and limited-edition Manolos, Pradas, and Salvatore Ferragamos.

The essentials:

Stoltzfus: yummy, fresh, soft, homemade pretzels and whoopie pies (get the classic chocolate)
Ultimate Bake Shoppe: chocolate chip biscottis (need I say more?)
Di Bruno: um, kinda speaks for itself but for constiency's sake, all things cheese
Seafood Market: fresh lump crabmeat and fresh fish (love the salmon and seabass) 
Sushi Sei: fresh, made-to-order sushi rolls (love the dragon and salmon avocado - much much better than anything from the supermarket and on par with Sushiland - just without the baked lion king roll)
Saxby: yes. it's a chain but the caffeine will give you the energy to carry all of your many purchases at the market...and you will end up buying a lot in spite of your best efforts to resist

That's definitely reason enough to get it...ASAP.

We came for brunch and were seated by the window on the wooden benches on top of the gravel, which was great, especially since it was no beautiful outside and we had a prime view.  Service was very attentive, prompt, and friendly, and the food itself was phenomenal!  We wanted to order everything but decided on a smaller selection due to stomach size constraints.  They were also great about separating items since one of my friends had some food allergies.  We had:

1. smoked salmon with egg salad and creme fraiche on toasted thick bread: Pretty good although the salmon was very salty by itself.  The combo of bread, creme, and salmon together was perfect, though.
2. potatoes bravas: The tried-and-true classic and yes, we ended up ordering seconds.
3. mixto cheese plate of truffled lavender and honey, fig and dried cherry, and pistachio: Fantastic, especially the truffled lavender and honey, which was the unanimous favorite.
4. lemon ricotta blueberry pancakes: Great but the creme fraiche makes all the difference.  Without it, the pancakes are just solid.
5. black cod: Okay, this was TINY but INCREDIBLE!  The fish was buttery, silky, and melted on your tongue.  I could eat this for days.  And you might want to get 2 orders...per person...minimum.
6. chorizo: Very flavorful and grilled to perfection.
7. chorizo with roasted potatoes and poached egg: This was a great rendition of a standard breakfast classic.  Mix it up bibimbap style!
8. grilled mixed mushrooms: Buttery and decadent.  A must-try for vegetarians.
9. chocolate cake with pistachio ice cream:  This was delish but to be honest, there was only a faint hint of pistachio flavor in the ice cream.
10. caramel flan topped with candied cherries and pear pieces: This was a very good custard but I felt that the additional candied fruit toppings made it overly sweet.  It actually would have been perfect on its own.

As expected, Garces delivers.  Make sure that you make reservations as the wait can be long on weekends but the ambiance is great so it isn't a bad thing to have to wait by the bar for a little while.

The happy hour here is fantastic.  

The food highlights:
1.  Short rib sliders are served with a great onion jam on a buttery, lightly toasted roll.  The meat is flavorful but can be a little on the dry side.  Solid 3 stars. $3
2.  Raisin pecan bread with gorgonzola fondue is simply delicious.  It's a great combination of sweet, savory, and creamy flavors with a nutty crunch.  4 stars.  $3
3.  Poutine fries were delicious.  They come with a savory, rich gravy and fresh cheese curds.  While they are not as great as the ones found in say, Montreal, they are flavorful, crispy, and very very good for the area.  I have yet to find another restaurant in the vicinity with these fries.  4 stars.  $4

As you can see, the prices are almost unheard of so you can literally get everything on the happy hour menu and still have change left to spare for a nice glass of wine (recommend the sauvignon blanc and chardonnay, both of which are also half price).

Plus, you CANNOT beat the ambiance.  Who doesn't love a stroll through Renoir's Boaring Party masterpiece followed by a fantastic meal comprised of French cuisine-inspired small plates and French wine?

Yum!  I finally got around to getting the carnitas burrito and was very happy with it. I had it with the saffron rice, pinto beans, cheese, guacamole, sour cream, onions, corn, and BBQ sauce. It was huge and the flavors meshed together quite well. All for just $5.78. I'll be back tomorrow to try the barbacoa. The carnita itself was very tender but a little bland. Not to worry though because the other ingredients and sauces definitely help to rectify that.

This is one of my favorite vegetarian restaurants in Philadelphia, for sure.  The food is fantastic and perfect for sharing.  We had the following:
1. marinated beets - flavorful and dressed with an apple vinaigrette served with a side of creamy panna cotta
2. charred Caesar salad - your classic Caesar but with charred romaine, which gave it a slightly smokey flavor.  A nice twist.
3. wild mushroom and barley on toast - flavorful with a touch of garlic and thyme on toast
4. chickpea fries - very innovative use of chickpeas and very tasty with a touch of garlic seasoning
5. roasted Brussels sprouts - classic and simple with perfectly roasted, buttery Brussels sprouts sprinkled with bread crumbs
6. Bouillabaisse - made with tofu in a slightly spicy saffron and tomato broth and served in a delicate papillotte shell.  Definitely recommend trying.
7. Buccatini and "meatballs" - absolutely fantastic with a spicy fra diavolo sauce.  I am not a vegetarian and would order this over the meat-based version.

Service was great and  the ambiance is very classy and cozy, with small tables and dim lighting.  A great setting for a date!

We came for lunch today and it's still a solid option, if you are looking to stuff yourself with passable sushi.  If you are a sushi connoisseur, head to Bluefin.  The other dishes were okay, but a bit on the greasy side, although I did like the sashimi salad.  They do have tuna sushi but no eel or macarel during lunch.  The rolls are decent, and I would definitely recommend those over the cold salads.  Noboru makes a better and less oily sashimi salad.  It is not as busy here as it was a few years ago but it's a decent lunch option ($17+ tax and tip on Mon-Fri).

This is in the old Sushikazu location next to Rita's and they do have pretty good Korean fried chicken wings.  The fried wings have a crispy skin with just a thin layer of breading with a very juicy interior; we got an order of the garlic-soy, which came glazed with a  sauce is simultaneously sweet and salty.  While the sauce was tasty, the highlight was definitely the crispy skin.  It's not as great as BonChon but pretty good for Blue Bell, PA.  They also have sushi rolls but I don't know if I would get my sushi here; I would rather just stick to the fried chicken wings.  Service was on the slow side but the food was worth it.  Each bite was a nice combination of crunchy-savory-sweetness.  If you want a Federal Donuts-like experience with an Asian twist, head next door to Suzy Jo and pick up a couple of glazed donuts.

Came here to grab 2 sandwiches and decided on the chicken salad on croissant with havarti.  The sandwiches were tasty and the accompanying potato salad was creamy with just a touch of dill (only ~$8 for the combo, which has the sandwich, salad, choc. chip cookie, and a soda).  They were also made very quickly, which was much appreciated since I was in a hurry.  We have also ordered our holiday hams here, and they have always been fantastic.

I love the Farmer's Daughter, and the prix fixe menu is solid and  quite reasonably priced.  It has almost become a family tradition to grab a weekly dinner here, partly because it's right next door and partly because we always have a nice experience here.  I wanted something savory so it was the roasted half chicken for me with the reliable grilled romaine and olive bread.  The chicken was tender and nicely seasoned with a coating of herbs in a garlicky jus; it came with a delicious scalloped potato tart and a carrot puree (okay, not a fan of carrots, in general, so I very "chivalrously" offered it to my father who happily finished it).  The garlic jus gave the dish an extra flavor boost, which I liked a lot since the roast chicken dish is a rather uniform and ubiquitous one.  The side of mushrooms was a nice touch too.  Definitely better than the typical mashed potatoes and green beans sides.  Dad's butternut squash ravioli was also great and the brown butter sauce was rich and flavorful.  It's a great fall dish and on my radar for the next visit, for sure.  For dessert, we split the chocolate pot de creme and bread pudding.   And by split, I mean that I gave him 1 bite of the pot de creme.  The bread pudding was good but I liked the chocolate pot de creme more, probably because of the hazelnuts and hazelnut cookie.  Service was great, as always, and our french press coffee was delish.  Will be back nect week to report on my own order of the ravioli.

It's better than Ramen Boy but still not quite Ippudo, by a long shot.  The Terakawa broth was just slightly greasy but it was very rich and decently flavored, so I can imagine that it would be good on a cold winter day.  It came with roast pork, seaweed, bamboo shoots, woodear mushrooms, scallions, and half a marinated egg, which, to me, stole the show.  The noodles themselves were decent, as was the pork, but the egg had that wonderful sweet, well-marinated flavor and a semi-soft yolk.  Next time, I'm skipping the pork and getting a whole egg instead, although you do have the option of adding an extra half for $1.  The takoyaki were pretty good, with perfectly crispy outsides and soft, flavorful interiors..  In fact, I liked them more than I liked the actual ramen, ironically enough.  Service was fast and friendly and it's a good place to grab a bowl of ramen or takoyaki.  It's not Ippudo, but for Philly, it's good enough.

A decent Asian restaurant with just about every variation, including Chinese, Thai, Japanese, and Malaysian.  It's surprisingly decent with the typical Americanized Chinese fare, all at very reasonable prices for Rittenhouse.  My Buddhist Delight and beef chow fun were solid, and not overly salty, although the portions are on the small side, compared to Square on Square.  Service was good, and I really liked that their green tea is actually brewed from tea leaves and not tea bags.

AMAZING unbreaded veal schnitzel!  The creamy mushroom sauce is delish and wonderful when mixed with the spatzle and roasted Brussels sprouts.  The pan seared duck breast with the red wine reduction, cherries, and baked cabbage is also superb.  Be sure to add a side of the potato pancakes with chive sour cream and applesauce and a pretzel.  Absolutely one of my new favs in Philly!  BTW - the service is very helpful, friendly, and FAST.  They are always more than happy to bring you a sample of any brews as well.

Great crab wings and steamed crabs. Get the mid/large at $3 each. They are huge and very fresh. The crab cakes are pretty good, as is the crab Mac and cheese. The seafood salad was the only subpar item I had. They also have pints of soup. The clam chowder was decent but not as good as the ones that I have had in Boston; it was creamy but just slightly on the bland side. It did have a generous serving of clams though. This place does resemble an actual shack to call and get your order to go. Nt a sit down restaurant but you'll avoid making a public spectacle  of yourself by eating the crabs at home where you can be as messy as you want. And as a side note, the wins are addictive. They are incredibly well seasoned without being overly spicy.

Solid fries with a good selection of dipping sauces from cheddar to sriracha to BBQ.  They are very greasy, though, so it's not for the light of appetite!  The shakes here are very good, as well and I was quite happy with my toasted marshmallow shake.  Prices are reasonable and it's a nice treat for a day hanging out in Rittenhouse Square.

I love the turkey on challah. The meat is shaved and not overly salty; the bread is soft inside with a great crust. Plus the portion of meat is very generous. Prices are very good and the service fantastic. If you need catering trays, the assorted sandwiches option is inexpensive and will feed 10+ easily.

You have to take the time to look around but they have a great selection of designer bags and shoes.  Everything is in excellent condition and prices are amazing.  It's also a good place to find that perfect piece of vintage jewelry to complete an outfit.

They were open yesterday in the midst of the maelstrom, so dad and I stopped in to grab a few dishes.  We weren't that hungry but just wanted to get out of the house due to cabin fever so it was the lunch specials for us.  I had the chicken with cashews, which came with a very generous serving of chicken and cashews; the sauce was flavorful yet not oily at all.  They also used chicken chunks rather than slices, which was a nice plus.  Dad liked his doubled-cooked shredded pork with five spice tofu, but did comment that E Mei's version is more flavorful; I tasted a bite and found the actual pork to be a bit tough and the tofu a bit bland, although it was certainly better than anything that we would have gotten from any other Chinese place in KoP.  We also got an order of the spicy shredded beef with peppers.  This was good, but there were only a few shreds of peppers.  I'm not complaining, though, since they compensated for the lack of peppers with a plethora of meat.  It came to about $30, for all three, which isn't bad.  the lunch specials are around $8 each, and come with soup.  I highly advise getting the wonton soup.  The portions are generous, too, and a lunch special can easily last 2 meals since they give you a pint of rice.  Pretty solid.

Attended a seminar here and the event facility itself was decent although the temperature was either too hot or too cold.  The hotel itself seemed rather cramped and a bit disorganized in its layout (bathrooms on alternate floors, towel carts in the middle of practically every hallway).  The attached parking lot is a nightmare, though.  It is 5 stories of narrow spots and narrower navigation lanes, which basically turns the experience into a nightmare on Elm St.  The location is nice (right in Midtown) but the venue is almost subpar.

Love the ice cream and the staff here BUT the owner can come off as very brusque and even curt to the point of rudeness.  I asked for a lid for my parfait and he basically huffed and walked away.  The poor guy at the counter apologized and very kindly went to get me a lid and bag.  So in summation: everything is great...except for the owner who needs a lesson in customer service.  4 stars for the food but 0 for the owner so updating to a 2 overall.

The hibachi is okay but the chef there was incredibly nice, efficient, and friendly.  I asked him to go easy on the oil and he actually cleaned and scraped down the grill for me!  That's called service.  The teriyaki seasoning was also very good, and a concoction that he created in the cooking process, which was certainly taster than anything premade.  I was pretty happy with my udon, veggies, chicken, shrimp, surimi, and beef stir-fry, although I did wish that they had tofu, crawfish, broccoli, and mussels.  The sushi bar had a great cold calamari salad that was literally just tender, seasoned calamari.  It was delish!  And quite fresh.  The rolls were pretty standard but the futomaki was well made, as was the dragon.  No eel or salmon sushi during lunch but the albacore sushi was buttery and fresh.  The seaweed salad was pretty standard and everything was extremely organized with an open, clean sushi bar.  The other dishes were solid, including the bamboo leaf wrapped glutinous rice dumplings, honey-roasted chicken, and honey-roasted whole bass.  Our waitress was very sweet and attentive and checked in on our tea, plates, etc. every 5-10 minutes.  Desserts were okay and they had the usual frozen yogurt and toppings.  It was pretty quiet at lunch but the place itself was probably the cleanest that I have ever seen a Chinese buffet be.  The food is not as amazing as King's but it's only $7.25 for a lunch that includes the made-to-order hibachi, which makes it a great lunch option.  It's a solid 3 stars but I will add an extra for the service and hibachi chef.

It's a small Au Bon Pain branch but the service is friendly and they do have all of the essentials, such as bagels, croissants, salads, and sandwiches, for the same prices at any other location.  While you can't order accustom sandwich or salad, there are enough choices here that you will find something.  All I can say is that my Thai chicken salad was infinitely healtheir and better tasting than anything offered on the plane, and, for this, I was extremely thankful. This is the location in the F terminal near US Air.

My vegan friend and I came across this cute cafe in our hunt for a lunch spot.  My Americano was great but the highlight was definitely the vegan cookie that was dessert.  It was chewy and delicious.  My mozzarella and basil panini was tasty but not amazing; I would have preferred a more flavorful spread.  The ambiance is eclectic and artsy.  Perfect for a leisurely-paced lunch!

They have breakfast sandwiches all day so that makes me happy.  Because some days you just want a bacon, egg, and cheese for lunch, or in my case, second lunch (yes, I was probably a merry and/or pippin-like hobbit with a similar appetite in a former lifetime).  While I still like to head to Lenny's for my hoagies and roast pork, this is a solid option for breakfast.  Rolls are fresh and soft, prices are good, and service is fast.

They also do takeout sushi, which really isn't that great of a value in comparison to the AYCE option, BUT I was able to get unagi sushi for about $1 a piece.  The unagi was pretty fresh and tender, and the portion was generous (not paper thin).  Not bad if you want a lot of sushi and a good variety (you can probablyy taste 10 different rolls/sushi for $10) at a great price, but don't have the time to sit down and dine in.  The AYCE option at lunch (~$16) is still the best deal here but the takeout isn't bad and the sheer volume of diners, especially during peak meal times, ensures that the sushi and rolls are fresh.

The baristas here are great and it's definitely a great spot for people-watching on South Street if you are able to grab a window table/seat.  It's always busy but the service is very friendly and I have yet to receive an incorrect order.  Plus, they also have the Evolution Sweet Greens juice, which I haven't been able to find elsewhere.

We usually head to Ekta but decided to finally try its basically next door competitor.  We had the malai chciken tikka, which was marinated in a sour cream-like sauce and grilled; the meat was a bit on the dry side but very flavorful.  The chicken tikka masala is my usual benchmark, and I found it to be good here, but I prefer the  sauce at Ekta (that's just my own preference so your mileage may vary).  The meat was pretty juicy and full of flavor, so they definitely take the care to marinate, which is essential.  The vegetable samosas were delicious!  The shell was crispy and the potatoes and peas stuffing was spiced perfectly.  These are definitely better here.  We also had the onion naan, which was good but didn't really discriminate itself from the the one at any other Indian place in the area; I did notice that they used red onions so if you are looking for some color in your naan, this may be for you.  Otherwise, there's really nothing special about it.  The staff here are very friendly, and the service is pretty fast.  It is pretty small so I imagine that it can get pretty loud and crowded during peak meal times although it wasn't bad today.  Overall, a decent Indian option on the Main Line.
If you are in the mood for a creamy and savory cold dessert, try the Rosemary Honey Goat Cheese.  It tastes like a fluffy, cold, and milder version of your favorite chevre appetizer.

Decided to give this place another shot...and I was shot down.  I wanted to try the benchmark salmon avocado and spicy tuna.  It took them 20 minutes to make the rolls (4 chefs in the back and it was not busy at all) and they were very sloppily put together.  They were falling apart basically.  The spicy tuna was decent but not memorable and the salmon avocado was not that fresh.  At least it was part of the lunch special and didn't cost an arm and a leg.  The waiter/cashier was pretty nice and had a very cheerful demeanor.  For sushi, I'm heading to Bluefin next time.

This is a diner that rivals Luke's from the Gilmore Girls. Friendly, small, quaint, and just good.  French toast is yummy but I still love my eggs Benedict. It's just not too great for my waistline since I practically live across the street. The constant temptation...

This is very Americanized Chinese but sometimes I do want just that. And that is when I come here for my chicken teriyaki with brown rice. It's filling, fast, and cheap. And honestly, it's pretty good too. I would liken this to five guys, except that it serves Chinese rather than burgers. The sauces are flavorful and the ingredients are fresh. Plus, the veggies are crisp and given in ample amounts.
Expensive limited grocery selection. Head to Assi for a full food court and every sushi ingredient you could ever desire.

This market is small but has all of the essentials covered, in addition to some very tasty baked goods.  Some highlights from this year (opened in May, I think):

Daily Loaf :  organic flaxseeds and whole-grain flour

Marliscious: the pistachio torte cake is 3 fantastics layers of pistachio cake sandwiched between and enrobed in a pistachio-filled cream.  I have not found a pistachio cake anywhere else and this is just delicious.  The Prinzregententorte is amazing to even look at, with 8+ layers of super-thin sponge cake layered with chocolate cream and covered in a thin chocolate coating; it's very good and has just the right amount of sweetness.  She doesn't always have every cake every time, but you can always order a particular flavor.  
 
Farm Fromage: creamy, organic goat cheese - it's delicious paired with a spring mix salad and glazed walnuts.
 
Frecon Farms: hard cider.  need I say more?
 
Jimmies Cupcake Co.: James Taylor/Boston cream cupcake with a custard filling, vanilla cake, and chocolate frosting.  Personally, I just like the names.  Cupcakes taste pretty good, too, but aren't as fantastic as House of Cupcake's in Pton.
 
Livengood Family Farm - grass fed ground sirloin - makes REALLY good, tender burgers
 
MacDougall's Irish Victory Cake: You HAVE to try the sweet butter cake!  It's rich, buttery, and full of simple, delicious goodness.  They have other varieties but this is the traditional tried-and-true, and, in my opinion, the best.

Definitely stop by if you live in the area and don't feel like driving down to Reading or Ardmore for your farmer's market goods.  I only wish that they had more prepared foods and snacks, like sandwiches and roasted meats.

Thursdays during Lent are my burgers days so I decided to stop in to grab a cheeseburger and coffee milkshake.  The burger was just okay: 2 thin, kinda dry patties and 2 cheese slices.  I was kinda surprised at the size since they claim to be better than Five Guys.  Well, um...not quite.  The housemade chips were the saving grace; they were fresh, thick-cut, and crispy.  Much better than your Lay's or Herr's.  My milkshake was just okay; it was decent but didn't really stand out.  I actually would have much rather gone to Baskin a few blocks down.  So, in summation: come here for the chips, and get your burger and shakes elsewhere.

I love the Strawberry and Irish Mint.  The froyo here is creamy and smooth but it can definitely add up at $.49/oz. Nevertheless, I love the flavors and the fact that they have tapioca bubbles as toppings.  It is also extremely clean, which is another plus.  It's not Pinkberry, but it definitely cures a froyo craving.

I really really missed this cozy, eclectic cafe.  It's the prime place for studying or just catching up with friends on a weekend (or before a mixer/dance, if you're in HS...ahh, those good ole days).  My extra frothy cafe latte hit the spot and the baristas are still just as friendly as I remembered.  Make sure you grab a fresh-baked chocolate chip cookie with your espresso, even if it's to go.  Your mouth will thank you.

We had the pistachio pesto and apple crisp.  The pizza was delicious.  It sounds rather strange but the flavors meshed very well.  The apple crisp was also very good. Cooking instructions were straightforward and I loved that it was hot and fresh from our oven.  It would have taken longer for delivery.

The chicken here is amazing!  The last time I ad authentic Peruvian rotisserie chicken was at malecon in NY. The skin is crispy and flavorful and the meat juicy. I ordered a whole chicken meaning to save half but...  Oh well, it'll be time to hit the gym. After my sat gorge fest at a NY style deli of course but I digress. Anyhow great food and friendly people. I'll definitely be back because I love my meat.

I really do like this Shop Rite.  The prices and hours are great, and the service is generally decent.  The deli has usually has a special, which is a nice surprise everytime (like turkey for $3.99/lb!), and I always get samples of meats and cheeses to snack on while I wait for my order.  The bakery is usually well-stocked although the donut selection is not as fantastic as Giant's; they do have the essentials, though.  The store itself isn't the most well-organized but it has everything at relatively low prices.  Plus, if you shop on a Sunday morning, they have complimentary coffee, danishes, bagels, and cookies, which is a really nice gesture, I think.  I've also noticed that service has gotten a lot better over the years.  They also have an entire aisle dedicated to Mexican groceries, too, which most other surrounding groceries stores don't have.
